Bottle.  Pale, hazy, a bit sparkling. Subtle citrus and spice; tart but balanced. A wonderful interpretation of the style. Very enjoyable.

From a 650 ml. bottle dated 04/24/2012-0804.  I stored it a few months. It pours golden yellow with a quick fizzy white head and good clarity.  Noticeable aromas of pale malts, orange zest, light spices, and, as advertised, champagne. The body is light.  The taste is highly carbonated with more champagne qualities than a saison. That brings it down for me.  But it is refreshing enough.

Sofie poured a slightly hazy yellow like the second pee on a hazy post-drinking morning. The head was white and persistent. The aroma was of citrus and wild yeast and was very inviting. There was some zesty orange peel and a hint of vanilla in the finish. The finish was sweet and dry. 

Price was okay, but not great. $10/4

Bottle, thanks to Chipalsa. Sofie poured out a clean, crisp light yellow with a white head. The aroma immediately presented spice and pepper notes with a citrus and lychee note. Canned tomatoes also came to mind for some reason. The yeastiness really reminded me of a nice Belgian strong ale. The flavor is pretty similar with a nice oakey touch, some citrus, lychee, spicy yeast, and lightly sweet. A nice saison for sure.

Sofie pours a sparkly bright golden yellow with a fluffy champagne like and short lived had. A few slight lacing rings appear and quickly fall back to the dense packet of head. The aroma is zesty and peppery with a subtle earthen quality and woody notes. A hint of subtle tart fruit and a plethora of citrus fruits. The first sip has a hint of sweetness with a candy fruit taste. A hint of lemon zest and orange rind accompany a dash of peppery spice and coriander. A smooth and mild saison like flavor with a mild earthy and woody note. This is an odd beer with a great drink ability with a subtle earthy wood accent.
From a 12 oz bottle shared at home.  Spicy orange nose.  Bread dough, orange peel and vanilla notes.  Smooth finish.

650 mL bottle purchase from somewhere downtown but about $9. 300th rating, finally I’m there. Sofie pours a light chalky yellow with a fluffy white head two exacted fingers in length. Smells delicately and solidly of lemongrass, horse manure (but in a good way), sharp cheddar cheese, orange peel, pizza dough, farmhouse yeast and some brief noble hop bitterness. Tastes of Belgian yeast, chalk dust, sweat, tin, ginger, Bible paper, and pepperoni. Ends  lightly fruity (pineapple, pears and golden apples), toast, mint, mushrooms, and sawdust. Fun stuff, but I don’t really seeing myself drinking more than one of these.

A --> pale, hazy, sparkling
S --> full of floral, citrusy light aroma
T --> light and sweet with a tint of sour
M --> Body was light, texture was thin, with lively carbonation and long delicious vanilla finish
O --> overall one of the better belgian styles I have had. I truly enjoyed the floral and citrus elements combined with the light lively carbonation. It is a fun and refreshing drink. Would definitely recommend to anyone.

Pours a slightly hazy straw color with a fizzy white head.  Smells musty, lemon, orange, and very dry.  Tastes very dry - slightly funky, very yeast driven - lemon and orange peel come through cleanly.  Very carbonated - light body.  An interesting beer, brings to mind a white wine/champagne more than a beer.

Belgian Style Ale heaven, the finish is strange first taste but enjoyable after the first pull. Top 10 beer for me. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Definitely my favorite of the goose belgians in 4 packs. Pours a clear light gold. Grat aroma of brett and fruit. Mostly dry with some residual sweetness nice hoppiness and yeasty spiciness. light bodied with high carb.

Bottle - 2011 vintage - big foamy head, hazy medium straw color, dry fairly orange aroma and flavor, some Belgian spice notes

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Something didn’t quite gel here for me.  Aroma was rather pleasant, citrus and spicy pepper.  Clear orange pour with  a thin white head. Flavour was rather like the sweet pineapple juice found in tinned pineapple, not unpleasant, but not like a saison. Rather ordinary finish some little hop.
Poured from the bomber. Really champagne like bubbly. Aroma is slightly tart, as well as the flavor. Love it! Finishes a bit watery and less flavor. Overall though a pretty nice Belgium.
On tap at the house of 1000.  Light pale yellow. Very thin head. Tes, saison fer sure. Friendly and easy with that typical saison yeast . Slight bitter finish but never over the top.
This is a good saison. Smell’s sweet and taste of citrus?  Good pour with little head and almost no lacing.  Yellow in color. Good not great.

Vintage 2009 bottle. Very light gold pour with large white head. It’s constantly bubbling. Aroma is citrus and orange. Taste is citrus and orange with slight taste of bananas. Very champaign like style saison.

Pours light yellow with medium quick receding head. Smells sour with hints of orange and lemon peel. Spicy funky belgian yeast aroma. Nice Belgian funk flavor with a bit of citrus. Slight effervescence. Easy drinker.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a hazy golden orange with a small white head.  Aroma is citrus and spicy with a sour yeasty hints.  The taste follows the aroma pretty closely.  Nice refreshing saison.

Poured from a bottle, cloudy yellow. Lots of carbonation. Aroma of orange peel, lemon, grassy. Taste is great, lively, almost champagne like. Very smooth with a tart taste balanced with a slight sweetness. Very good. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Apricot and banana nose, lemongrass also prominent, a bit hot. Cloudy yellow with a very slight greenish hue, thick white head with poor retention. Tart overripe lemon, somw white grape notes, with banana finish. Tastes fine, but I like a spicier saison.

Sampled on draft at Zeno?s in State College PA this beer poured a murky yellow-peach color with a large creamy white head that left decent lacing. The aroma was tart Pez, pineapple, lemon and pepper. The flavor was tart and dry with notes of pepper, pineapple, lemon, bubblegum, Pez and faint bread with a prominent chalky presence. Long finish of tart citrus, bubblegum and bread. Moderately full bodied. Ok.
yellow with golden head. Smell is funky earth and bread, and citra zest. Taste follows with bitter zesty orange, herbal, and floral, spicy and frothy.

12oz bottle.  2012.  clear gold under a large, fluffy white head.  pale grainy nose with corn and a pinch of pepper.  flavors of corn.  a smooth, jelly-like body with a biting carbonation.  white winey notes, but mostly corn.
served on tap. Aroma is fruity with banana esters. taste of bitter grapefruit, but in a good way. overall, a nice beer

Aroma of a Belgium with a sparkling appearance, balanced taste and warming mouthfeel with a hint of floral and wine.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Rerate: Light pale gold color with large fluffy white head and lots of carbonation. Aroma is yeasty, cidery, with a big floral bouquet. Flavor is great, bretty and grassy with spicy belgian yeastiness, just slightly tart, and a smooth sweetness at the end. Light mouthfeel, crisp and refreshing.

11/16/2012:  (7)(4)(7)(3)(16)[3.7]:  Bright gold color with huge white head and nice lacing. Aroma and flavor are strong, with citrus notes, light fruits, and good brettyness.

Really appreciated this beer. Citrus and white wine aromas and flavours throughout this beer. Sampled on tap at JL Beers in Grand Forks. All the flavours worked together without overpowering each other. Sweet, tangy, sour, bitter. Nice.

Poured from a 22 ounce bomber into a Spiegelau tulip. Bottled on 11/12/11 printed on label. I’m drinking it exactly one year after it was bottled.

Appearance: Pours a nearly clear golden yellow with a 1 finger foamy snow white head which dissipates fairly quickly. Minimal lacing.

Smell: Nice fruity aroma blending citrus, pear and a bit of sweet white wine. There is just a hint of spiciness creeping through.

Taste: Dry white wine notes with a touch of apple and pear up front followed by Belgian yeast, mild phenols and a touch of funk in the middle before ending with a bit of black pepper. Aftertaste is dry and mild with Belgian yeast dominating. This is clearly a Belgian-style saison. 

Mouthfeel: Light-to-medium-bodied with a high amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: Excellent drinkability. You won’t have any trouble polishing off the bomber alone.

Overall: Very good beer overall. I would recommend giving this one a try. I’d like to try it fresh to compare. Now that Goose Island is distributing to Florida, I hope Sofie makes the trip down here along with their regular offerings.

2010 bottle. Pours a murky very pale yellow with a lot of stuff floating and a thick foamy white head that fades quickly. Sharp, yeasty aroma, with oranges, malt - a bit sour. Taste is sharp and tart, with yeast, spices, citrus, malt, wood. Lingering spiced orange yeast. Nice.
Hazy yellow with a large white head. Aroma is zesty citrus, lemon, earthy. Highly carbonated body. Flavor is earthy, sweet, lemony citrus, and tart. Nice saison.

22 ounce bottle, pours a pale light yellow color, aromas of light citrus, some pepper, light vanilla, and some chardonay.  Flavors are light citrus with a nice chardonay finish, light and refreshing.  Glad I got to pop open this bottle, a really nice beer overall.
Bottle. Color unclear yellow with big white head. Aroma malt, yeast, citrus, spicy. Taste sour, yeast, coriader, spicy, fruits.
Orange, crisp, great for a saison style ale. Not overly yeasty for a Belgian-style.
Draft. Hazy yellow pour. Nose of lemon and spices. Nice balanced flavors. Real nice saison.

A small glass at a Goose Island tasting, hazy golden hue capped by a white head. Nose and taste of cereal and clove. A bouquet of flowers on finish. Strong body, sometimes feels a tad thin. Yeah... 3 fo 3!

Hazy pale yellow body, moderate sized creamy white head, soapy lacing, Nose shows signs of orange, brett, light grains, gentle spices, and white wine. Flavor profile consists of similar, slightly more juicy notes.  Medium to light bodied, effervescent carbonation, light tartness and acidity in the finish, refreshing.

Bottle dated 3/10.  Pours a medium golden color with a billowing white head that has great staying power - leaves incredible lacing with little clouds that remain on the skin of the brew long after the pour is complete.  Aroma is great and intense - wine grapes, lemon, orange peel with some spice and wheat in there as well - wonderful on the nose.  Flavor is quite good as well...slightly spicy, yeasty and moderately sour - very enjoyable.  Medium bodied palate with a subsequently medium length finish.  Nice offering from GI!

Bottle. 2012 Vintage. Gold bodied with a medium, foamy white head. Aroma is spicy with peppery notes, dried flowers, fruit and dusty yeast. Taste is peppery spices, sweet malt, strong yeast notes, dried fruit, citrus, flowers, earthy hops and straw. Body is medium with a soft, creamy carbonation. Light lingering bitterness and spiciness to this along with a pleasant dryness during the finish. Ends with more dried fruit, sweet malt, peppery spice, yeast notes, bread dough, straw and flowers.

Sample at the Decatur Craft Beer Fest. This is a pale gold beer with a thin, off-white head. Smells musty, citrusy, and fructose. The flavor is sweet and a little sour. The mouthfeel is sticky and crisp. Overall, this a good, refreshing, and tasty beer.

22oz bottle, 2010 vintage, hazy golden honey hue, with a frothy white head, leaving some belgian lacing, with a yeasty, doughy, woody, fruity white wine tannin nose, with a faint funky, spicy lemnograss, coriander ,orange, lemon peel note in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a nice yeasty, fruity, soft woody, white wine barrel tannin, sour character, with some light pineapple, peach, pear, apple fruity yeastiness flavours, with a mild honeyed pale, pilsener, toasted malt backbone, with a spicy coriander, vanilla, funk undertone, leading towards a light wet woody barrel, dry fruity winey finish.

Bottle as an extra in trade, although CA gets it. Aroma and flavor of Belgian yeast, saison, very light banana ester, orange peel, and white wine barrels. This one has an amazingly clean and crisp palate. May be my favorite one of the series. Great beer.

Long Island, NY - 12 oz. 2012 bottle pours a hazy wheat color with champagne like head and no lacing. Aroma is slightly citric with some cider like effervescence. Taste is sour like champagne but has a bit of citrusy bite. The sweetness and bitterness linger just a hint to remind you of the backbone of this brew. Goose Island never fails. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Light straw pour soapy white head.  Lively aroma straw some bananna heavy carbonation leaves a sweet bread taste in the mouth.

2012 bottle purchased at The Davis Food Co-Op.  The aroma on this is a little estery with slight barnyard.  More citrus lemon peels than I would expect.  Floral and vibrant, and not too heavy on the yeast.  Pretty quaffable.  Lightly hazy blonde body present with a medium white head with lots of fine bubbles present.  Starts rather sweet and fruitier than I would expect.  Lots of lemon and citrus flavors to start.  Has a nice lively carbonation in the middle, before a little tart astringency comes through later on.  I am typically not huge on the style, but this is fruitier and less dominated by massive yeast esters than I am used to.  A nice change-up.

Bottle from Mari’s.  Pours hazy yellow with a big white head that hangs for a bit, then leaves a lot of sticky lacing.  There are some bubbles in the glass and on the rim of it.  The aroma is funky but has some lemon, orange, wood, and a big bretty nose.  The taste is really crisp, dry, a little sweet.  The finish does remind me of a nice chardonnay but not quite as dry.  This is really enjoyable.

Bottle at Pat’s Pizza...on special.  Pours bright yellow with generous but quickly dissipating head.  Initial taste is the usual Belgium sour but with a little more there...orange and a lemon as well to me.  Very tasty...went well with the Carbonara!
Chardonnay and pear cider aromas.  Flavors follow the aromas with chardonnay and pear with a little vanilla.  Overall a very good beer.

Fruity funky ass aroma of bret yeasts, mango, salt and white pepper. Looksa, and tastes, like bad lemonade. A lot like a Berlinner style wheat beer, only just tart rather than truly sour. Too much sugar flavor in the mix as well. Over the top for a style that emphasizes subtleties. Bad Goose, bad.

22 oz. bottle served in a Deschutes snifter. 2011 vintage.

A: Pours a hazy golden straw color with a 1 finger pure white head. Very lively head that leaves some sticky lace on the way down.

S: Funky yeast with a citrus fruit rinds. Lemon peel and some orange pulp are the dominate fruits.

T: Slight musty yeast with a little peppery spice. Tart citrus fruits. Green apples, rinds of orange and grape skins are all present with an oat-like malt bill to even it out.

M: Light bodied with a lively carbonation and tart fruit finish.

O: This more of a tart fruit forward saison, but it’s still got great flavor profiles none the less. Solid year round offering from GI.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-26-2011

11 ounce pour - $8.00 at Taco Mac in Kennesaw, Georgia.



Appearance: Served up a hazy, pale straw-hued body with a slim coating of white fizz.



Smell: A scent of casually chewed gum atop notes of reserved malts, coriander seed, meager pear, a little snippet of citrus, and ’nanana.



Taste: Starts with a very soft, very gentle maltiness, then the tranquility is tainted by a large dollop of icing sugar for a jarring initial sweetness. Orchard fruits, pureed bananas, and a nod towards the citrus component. All the while a taste of Chiclets. A little bitterness. Coriander spiciness, but also some pepper. Fruity Chiclet, sugary, lightly spiced finish.



Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium-plus carbonation.



Overall: It was merely okay. Just barely so-so. I had rather expected this one to please with ease. Time to fire up the Smokey Robinson song, "Tears of a Clown."

On tap at Euclid Hall. Pour is golden honey in appearance with a frothy white head and low lacing. Honey, straw, tang, spice, light pineapple, biscuit, and mango in the aroma. Taste is bready, biscuit, yeast, spice, pineapple, green apples, and pear with a lightly spicy finish. Light and crisp mouthfeel with fizzy carbonation. Nicely balanced saison.

THOUGHTS: Very wine like in flavor and very champagne like in texture, but still recognizable as a saison. An excellent summer sipper that could probably stand upt to colder weather as well. It should age incredibly well. Less hoppy than many saisons, but there was enough acid and sourness to create great balance with the malt.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a light to medium yellow that was almost glowing. It had excellent carbonation that constantly tried to rebuild the head, which was average to large, frothy, off-white and mostly diminishing. The aroma had light to moderate light bread and cracker malts; light herbal and grassy hops; moderate to heavy earthy, dusty and spicy yeast; slight funky yeast; and white wine. The initial flavor was slightly sweet, lightly acidic and slightly sour; while the finish was slightly sweet, light to moderately acidic; moderate to heavily tart and lightly bitter with an average on flavor and long on dryness duration. There was white wine, cracker, white bread, funky yeast, a little wood, apple, maybe a hint of vanilla, champagne, earthy yeast and dusty yeast. The light to medium body was very dry with very fizzy and tingly carbonation.

Almost clear golden yellow with a little head.  A small funky but nice aroma.  Flavor is a little orange, a little oak with just a hint of bitterness on the finish.  I like the fizzy tartness.  There is nothing outstanding but nothing bad either.  It’s a nice drinking beer for a hot day.

Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a sparse, white head. Aroma is citrusy. Lots of notes that you’d find in wheat beers, probably due to the wild yeasts. Flavor is wonderful. Light and refreshing, but definitely featuring a flavorful presence. Banana and vanilla with citrus...grapefruit. Not a whole lot of hop action, but it seems nicely balanced otherwise. Very good.

Pours yellow , smells like pepper, taste is not my cup of tea. Gross, too bubbly, nasty aftertaste. Drain pour. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy Deez nuts

2012 Vintage. Pours hazy yellow with a large sudsy white head. Smells a little vinous, and a little funky and sour. Taste is a little spicy, hints of orange, and yeasty bread. Medium-bodied with a smooth, wet texture and lots of mouth-carbonation, Goose Island Sofie finishes with a yeasty, wine-like dryness.
Very smooth, light for the alcohol content. Some spiciness, citrus, and just a bit of bitterness. Very nice finish.

May 1st, 2010 -  Goose Island was a name murmured in the back halls of beer bars and graduate student lounges around Seattle. I had heard of it before too; it was one of those breweries out East that folks would go into a frenzy for, grabbing their spears and performing weird rituals in the dead of night to secure a bottle of this or that. Goose Island was one of the names uttered in their shamanistic trances, but I didn’t think much of it. Out in Seattle we were too far away, and no amount of trading or haggling would be worth the effort to acquire a bottle. But then, one day, there it was. It occupied a spot on the shelf of my local QFC, as if it had always been there. I stared at it for awhile, until an old lady severed my achilles in half with a rusty cart. This compelled me to pick up the beer and hobble to the cashier to take my new prize home and see what the fuss was about. And I still don’t get it. A golden body pours from the bottle, and features a thick white head. The aroma is bright, but transparent, and seems rarefied, left with only slight scents of corn and wheat and a bland, generic sweetness. The flavor is bitter, far too carbonated, and sometime after the mid-taste it tapers down to a clean but simple lager and honey aftertaste. I’m comparing my notes with others on RB and simply can’t understand the stark difference. I think this one may be up for a re-rate.

9/13/12.  Picked up 4-pack at pinehurst wine shoppe.  First beer of session.

Nose is incredible.  Delicate sweetness, with lemon, honey, pepper, and a touch of coriander.  Fresh.  The sort of nose that I think is outstanding year round.  This is first time I've had it so will report back this winter

This beer rocks.  The spice, citrus, vanilla, and honey hits ya all at once, and the combination makes for one refreshing sensation.   When I swallow I get a hint of peppermint and outright pepper as well.   The mouthfeel is smooth and fuller than I'd expect.  And in the aftertaste the citrus comes back, but it's way more dry.

A solid and unique beer through and through


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Yellow beer with a nice lasting white head. Grapefruit aroma, perfume, pepper, grapes, floral, dandelions, woody, sour, some caramel. Sourish grapefruit flavor, perfume, floral, citrus, lime, dry, sour, pepper, coriander, grapes, some dandelions. Sourish herbal finish with perfume, hay, floral notes and some pepper. Exceptional!
Crispy, clean, and the orange peels definitely add to the fruity taste to the beer. Clear, champagne like appearance. And a smooth finish with a slight alcohol burn.

Draft at Blowtoad.  Clear gold with slight head that fades away.  Aroma is lightly citric.  Flavor is gentle pils malts, with interesting flavors in the background, all subtle and balanced.  Notes of pepper, coriander, orange, citrus, and gooseberry.  It was a touch on the cold side - I think that muted things more than I would have liked.  Would love to spend some time with a full bottle of this.  Nicely done.

Pours a yellow hay slightly dizzy color. Huge white fluffy head. Aroma is tart, citrus, a little funk, spice, belgian yeast, barnyard, white grape, malty. Nice complex aroma. Taste is slightly tart, spicy, maltiness, citrus, funkyness, barnyard. Very nice and complex brew! Refreshing.

I see these beers everywhere and never bought them but theyre all fantastic.  The GI belgian line have impressed me and this is no exception.  Really great saison here with lots of spicy yeast and citrus fruit with a nice rustic earthy taste.

22oz bomber.  Gentle yellow color, hazy, little bubbly head, slight lacing.  Kind of an ugly beer, actually.  I agree with the description - this is a "chamgagne-y" and I really like it but I think it’s a little bit over-rated, but not much.
Good beer by goose island, 2009 here. Oranges are barrel characteristics are still dominant but it is starting to oxidize a bit.

12 oz. bottle in a tasting glass. 2012 on label. Tasted along side of Goose Island Matilda. Pours a wheat color with a white head that fell away quickly. Bubbles continually rose up through glass. Aroma had a slight spicy touch along with a sour note and some grapes. Medium-full mouthfeel despite the light color...heavier mouthfeel than Matilda. Had a slightly sour taste along with the fruit. Plenty of carbonation. Little dry finish. Very good!

What a great tasting beer.  Being new to the saison beers, this is definately one of my favorite.  Smooth, a nice plume of fragrance from the fruit, nice abv, and the calmness of the beer is perfect for a fall evening.

Aroma: Spicy--pepper and cloves, maybe allspice--with hints of alcohol, as well as citrus and resin.
Appearance: Sparkling gold with thick, white head.
Taste: Light sweetness that fades quickly with hints of saltiness in the finish.
Palate: Light body, slick texture, lively carbonation, soft dry finish.
Overall: I’m not blown away by this beer, but I certainly would seek it out again. There is a champagne quality to this that makes me want chocolate, berries and to toast something.

22 oz. bottle poured into a tulip.

A: Pours a light golden color with excellent clarity - until the yeast is poured in, turning it into a rather hazy brew. The head is a two finger eggshell color with decent retention (it eventually settles down to one finger for quite a while) and good lacing. 

S: Lots of lighter fruits - pear, apple, banana, maybe some cherry - backed up by slight grassy hops and a bright malt backbone. Pretty interesting.

T: One word describes this: subtle. Subtle light fruit esters (apple, banana, cherry) are augmented by subtle malts, subtle spicing and a subtle hop finish, all backed by a subtle underlying funk. In addition, the finish is vaguely reminiscent of white wine at times. Truth be told, it’s subtle to the point of lacking flavor slightly...maybe I’ve had too many DIPAs lately. Only a modicum of complexity overall, although the barnyard funk does accumulate fairly well. In spite of all this (or maybe because of this?), it goes down very easy.

M: Fairly intense carbonation, with a tiny bit of yeast astringency along with low dryness, perhaps a little less than I want from a saison. Thankfully, the yeast has perhaps calmed down to where it doesn’t hinder drinkability with excessive heaviness on the palate.

O: Pretty damn good, especially considering saisons aren’t one of my more favored styles. At first I really liked it, then I started to grow slightly weary of it, but near the end of my glass (as the funkiness increased) it became more enjoyable. Well worth a shot.

One of the lightest color beers I’ve ever seen (watery yello).  Airy white head that disappears.  Very yeasty.  A bit sour.  Bitter orange in aroma and taste.  Bubbly mouth feel.  I’m not really a saison fan, and this certainly didn’t convert me.
Foggy yellow color - close to light beers. Fruit. Tang. Sour finish. I was really looking reward to thus beer but let down.

From notes: Poured hazy straw color, with lots of bubbling along the wall of the glass and a small, thin white head that dissipated quickly.  Tart, winelike aroma with a mild citrus note and a touch of yeast.  Palate is light and slightly fizzy, with a somewhat dry finish.  Taste was of orangey citrus with a winelike crispness to it.
Pours cloudy yellow with a medium white head.  Aroma is citrus, head, earthy and some funk.  Taste its tart and sweet.  Light bodied with a thin mouth feel.

Tap. Pours cloudy, pale yellow with thin, fizzy white head; decent retention and good lacing. Aroma is bananas, herbs, cloves, grassy and floral hops, cookie and bread malts, and wheat. Flavor is malt forward with good citrus esters and subtle hops; herbs throughout with a dry finish. Light body, medium carbonation, and low warmth.
2012 bottle. Great taste and aroma. I’ve never tried this before, so I might cellar a few bottles and see how they are later.
22oz bottled 5/17/12 poured a hazed yellow with not much of a head forming I can taste the citrus in the Belgian pop in and out while drinking.
Pours yellow with a big white head.  Tastes like peppery hay.  This is a quality farmhouse or saison.

Bottle from state line liquor - 2012 bottle - pours a cloudy lemon yellow with a white head. Nose is lemongrass, pine, a touch floral, little bit of brett. This is very light for a saison, body is on the thin side. It’s ok, but not not an outstanding example of the style. Seems kind of young, probably would be better if it cellared for oh, 2 or 3 years.

2009 vintage bottle- still has a huge wine and grape skin nose. Pale with excellent clarity and solid white head and lacing. Taste- Sweet white grapes, pink peppercorns and citrus. Finish is more creamy than expected as thought this would have dried over the years.  Really nice stuff

Complete update: Bottle (12 oz). Thanks to John! Hazy pale yellow/golden with a fluffy white head and good lacing. Aroma is white wine with orange peel, brettanomyces, lemon zest and light spices. Taste is slightly to moderately sweet with white wine, brettanomyces, orange peel, lemon zest and light spices. Medium body. Moderately dry. Winey mouthfeel. Superb Belgian Ale. Complex, refreshing, drinkable. I would drink this everyday.  Delightful!

Bomber.  Pours straw with a large, dense white head.  Aroma is citrus, earthy yeast, some spice.  Flavor is orange peel, lemon, a hint of pepper and wood, some bretty, earthy yeast, low sweetness, mild bitterness.  Medium mouthfeel weight, very effervescent.  A great saison.

Bottle at City Porch on Navy Pier looking at the boats. Pours an unclear orange with some white head. Little retention. Aroma has spicy sweet fruitiness with some straw. Taste is of sweet bread, a bit of fruit, spices and some muted citrus. Finishes fairly quickly; sweet. Very nice. Not overwhelmingly belgian, but with hints of it, and solid other contributions. A nice drinker.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours clear blond with high creamy white head, diminishing. Some lacing. Aroma is of wine, oranges, citrus. Taste is of oranges, citrus, malt, wine, sligth acidity. Dry finish. Overall: Refreshing. Interesting wine touch. Maybe a little ligth, but the drinkability worth it.

22 oz bomber pours yellow with a white head.  Aroma of yeast, spice and malts.  Taste is sweet malts, spice and yeast.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 oz bottle. Pours a straw yellow with a 2 finger white head.  Belgian yeast aroma with orange peel and spice. Citrusy flavor with more of that Belgian funk. dry and tart and peppery. Some oakiness. Dry palate with,in your face, carbonation. Very nice.
Good head, white, mostly diminishing.  Fruity aroma.  Has a dryness similar to champagne but has a nice balance.  Light body easy to drink.

Pours a hazy pale yellow with a medium slowly dissipating white pillowy head with some light lacing. Aroma of spicy fruity esters, some citrus and banana notes, light yeast fill the senses. Taste is biscuit malt, yeast, citrus notes with some spicy fruity flavors and some nice tart bitterness. palate is a nicely balanced medium crisp body with lively mouth tingling carbonation. The finish is a sweet spicy tropical fruity flavorsome nice citrus notes, yeast ending with a lingering sweet tart bitterness with a bit of nutty flavor. Overall a very good, tasty and nicely balanced Saison. Nice.

On tap, pours hazy gold, good tight white head. Nose is barnyard funk, sharp lemons, astringent citrus and hint of clove. Gets in your sinuses. Sauvignon notes right up front, champagne dryness, hay, orange peel and peppery finish. Nice angle on a saison.
Bottle from the Anderson’s. Pours pineapple with an inch of white foam which leaves some lacing. There’s a lot of pepper and farmhouse on the nose. Very dry on the tongue   Finishes clean. Fantastic!
bottle @ Jockey Club, Las Vegas. cloudy yellow, small head. earthy aroma. medium palate, some citrus

65 cl bottle @ Hotel room, Las Vegas.

Pours hazy pale golden color with a large head. Aroma of wheat, spices, yeast, lemon, apricot notes and some hay. Flavor of apricot, lemon, spices, yeast and mild wheat. Very close to witbier, not as stuffy though.

3335

65 cl bottle @ hotel room, Las Vegas. Bottled on 16.05.2012

Aroma is sour and tart with citron, some apples and spices. Flavour has rather intensive sourness and tartness with earthy notes, citron, hints of apples, wheat and yeast. Soapy citrus starts to occur at the end of the glass. Refreshing!
240712. Bottle at hotel in Las Vegas. Pours hazy yellow with a high head. Aroma spicy wit, yeast. Earthly aromas. Slight acidic taste, high carbonation. Medium palate. More like a wit, but Not Bad.

I found this at the grocerie store the other day, $9.99, vintage 2010.
Pours pale cloudy yellow, kicks up about an inch of white head. The aroma is full of tangy fruit, some citrus. Nice tart fruit flavors, sour cherry and some woody notes. Light mouthfeel with a very lively carbonation. Awesome beer!

Pure golden pour with foamy white head. Orange, pepper, and a slight wine fruity alcohol smell. More wine in the taste, but texture is more like a cider...thin body, tartyness and excellent balanced flavor of alcohol and fruit. Very admirable saison

Big thanks for this bottle I got from wchesser.2012 bomber..Pour is light gold and a thin white head..Nose is orange, brett, spice, fruit, earth, tartness..Taste is spice, orange, brett, citrus, funk,caramel, very faint wood..Very nice carbonation..Not to dry or bitter..One of the best saisons ive had

Beer Bloggers Conference 2012 

at Goose Island this was a very tasty Sasion

Poured a yellow gold, but much more opaque than the usual lager color.... I was interested. I could taste some lemon, but at the same time it had a subtle sweet taste. A sure winner, definitely would have another!

Bottle dated February 15 2012, poured into a shaker. Pours golden straw color with a big foamy head that evaporated quite quickly. The nose is lots of citrus and biscuit. There's very active yeast, and the carbonation is very active. The taste is quite tart, full of oily oranges. Quite acidic in the middle, but finishes well. The mouthfeel is pretty full and super fizzy.  Overall this is a super lively beer, very tasty, great for the summer.

A February 2012 bottle. Pours a hazy straw gold with a foamy white head and lacing. The aroma has biscuit, pear, and  some of the orange peel and a slight funk. The taste is stronger yeast and orange citrus up front, with a mildly sour and acidic middle and aftertaste over a very fizzy body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

sour, fruity nose; light yellow and murky, decent but thinnish head and lacing; sour and slightly bitter, a tad metallic, barely sweet, and certainly acidic; medium body, sticky texture, medium carbonation; very nice

Poured from 12oz bottle to tulip glass, 2011 vintage:

Pours a pale macro gold with a fizzing few fingers of head that settle down to a neat collar - tons of beading.

The nose shows a ton of clove, fresh straw, slight yeast funk. Like any good saison, it boasts a terrifically fresh nose at any age.

A slight fruit character surfaces in the taste - pear, white grape, apple. Those some clove and yeast notes show themselves as well.

Very easy drinking, I’m excited to see how this continues to evolve.

very hazy straw yellow with big fluffy white head, some lacing. lemon rind, yeast wheaty sweet aroma. light mouth feel very carbonated. citrus (lemon and orange) wheat twang. finishes clean with some lingering sweetness and very citric. very juicy. overall very good and drinkable. I just with it had a bit more body.

I’ve avoided trying this one for a long time, since it is omnipresent around the better bottle shops in Chicago, but decided to give it a chance today.  22 oz bottle dated 9/15/2011 pours a hazy yellow-orange with a small white head and some lacing. Nose is mostly Belgian yeast.  Aroma has pears, green grapes, orange, banana, and lots of yeast.  Taste has some wonderful spices I can’t identify, but is slightly sweet at first with a clen dry finish. Medium body with enough carbonation to keep things lively.  One of the better saisons and one of the better Goose Island beers I’ve tried, albeit overpriced for a relatively mass-produced beer.

Pours a pretty, slightly hazy golden with a thick, fine-bubbled, pale amber head. Aroma is hoppy, yeasty and fruity and just a bit sweet, not strong but still inviting. Yeasty flavor has hoppy, fruity (banana and pear) and malty notes, a touch of honey sweetness and a hint of butterscotch. Firm body has plenty of lively fizz and leaves a tingly, fruity, yeasty finish. This is to be sipped and savored in quiet reflection.
On tap at Blue 5.  Nice and clean saison.  Easy drinking.  Good break in beer to belgium yeast.

Bottle. Funky Belgian yeast, sweet floral citrus aroma. Hazy yellow with a moderate white head. Musty, hay, light sweet  fruity / floral, and tart citrus flavor with a soft bitterness and spice in the finish. Light effervescent body.  Very nice and refreshing. Sort of like a tart funky witbier.

On tap at Money Plays. Pours a a cloudy yellow with small white head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is yeast and floral hop. Thick mouthfeel with sweet hop and yeast with light dry finish. Easy to drink a refreshing saison from Goose Island.
Poured from a 22 ounce bomber. The nose is very interesting, there is an aroma that reminds me of citrus fruit rind with the bitter pith. Fruity, sweet, slight tartness, nice acidity. Very nice beer.

Beautiful saison/farmhouse ale.  Frothy pour with citrus and floral hops in the nose.  Lush mouth feel with a dry finish, tight little bubbles.  Sweet and sour, citrus and hops with a smooth nillin finish.  This is why I drink saisons and farmhouse ales.

A: Light yellow, slightly hazy, moderate head, little lacing.

S: Grapes, spices, and enticing brettanomyces. Brett is such an inviting aroma.

T: Very crisp with white grapes, orange and/or orange peel, white wine. The wild yeast is tasty and well integrated into the overall flavor.

M: Very crisply carbonated. Nice feel.

D: A tasty beer that I really enjoyed. I’ll buy this if I see it and I’d certainly drink it again.
Pours a slightly hazy pale gold with a small white head.  Smells of raisin, spices, vanilla.  Taste is mildly sour, bitter and sweet.  Refreshing, an easy drink.

Very light straw color with billowy porous short-lived head. Lemon zest aromas and in the taste. Lightly tart and refreshing not bad for a saison.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The Sofie grew on me. A very refreshing & pleasant beverage. It won’t affect your palate & the taste is delightful. It won’t blow your mind & I doubt you will lust after it. In the end I would enjoy having another.

4 year vertical ’9-’12, Pours clear straw golden in color with with an off white head. The aroma brings sweet spring fresh floral notes, but not hops as much as the saison yeast brings a grassy meadow style. The body is quite bubbly like champagne, as described, and not as dry as I expected. The wine comes out stronger with the fresh batches, sweet grapes ending nicely with citrus orange notes as well settling on the tongue. So refreshing and delicious!

(22  oz. (bottled 3/8/12) from Bootleggers) Hazy yellow-gold. One finger of off-white head. Aroma of spice, citrus, yeast. Very light mouthfeel. Flavor is sweet and sour, probably more sour, borderline acidic. Spice, light pepper, yeast and citrus.

Pours a hazy golden yellowish color with a one inch head that falls apart quickly. Some mild lace sticks to the glass. Barnyard funk with honey and citrus notes. Belgian yeast dominates the nose. Starts off with subdued bitterness and a playful saison yeast and finishes a little tart. Picking up more lemon and straw upfront with a lingering green apple skin sweetness that’s equally tart. Elegant usage of spice notes from coriander to clove to white pepper. Light juicy apricot note. Chalky yeast finish with some caking. Enormous complexity as there are fruit and yeast components I can’t quite pin down. Light and airy in the mouth, smooth and drinkable, mild citrus/floral aftertaste, not drying or overpowering on the palate. A subtle, and yet complex saison, definitely seems to have mellowed out with age, smooth and mild.

26th May 2010
Hazy pale gold beer. Short lived white head. Light palate, crisp and semi dry. Delightfully light malt. Tiny bit of sourness. Shandy like lemonade with elderflower. Finishes soft and semi dry. A lovely light saison.

Pours yellow with a nice white head. Aroma of lemon, citrus, yeast. Light bodied with a nice taste and a nice crisp palate.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity and citrus. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 160512
Pours bright straw with a small head. Aroma of spicy yeast and orange peel and white wine. Taste is quite tart with sour apple and pale grain.

Bottle pours a golden yellow white head. Smells tastes fruity hay yeast citrus. Tastes very same has a small bite. Dry. Sweet. Grapes taste funky smell. Kind of like a pineapple. I like this tastes fresh and refreshing.

From the bottle. funky aroma from the yeast, bitter orange and some white grape present.  some tart notes on the palate, not overbearing and a little sweetness to balance, slightly vinous. Light carbonation with a soft mouth feel. Dry finish, overall a pleasant beer

Bottle sample at a tasting at DSG’s place. Thanks DSG, Pours bright with a small head, aroma of honey, spice, some funky tones, leaf and nutmeg, flavor of some brett, lively carbonation, nice acidity, wheat, warmer, milkish tones, medium bodied

On tap. Nice hazy yellow color. Little white head. Good light fine carbonation, more dry texture. Nice tart sweet taste. Aroma of spices, interesting (belgian?) yeast, citrus peel. Nice light refreshing saison, a good choice for the summer. Sort of a belgian wit / saison hybrid.

Pours cloudy blond. Smells yeasty. Agree with the guy before about the white wine - I couldn’t put my finger on it. Has a lot of fruitiness, almost a cider like apple taste. Different feel from the other saisons I’ve had. A little hay in there as well, but the barnyard tastes are pretty absent for a saison. Bottle from Lebanon Health Food Store, NH.

Bottle @ DØE meeting. Pours light yellow with a white head. Aroma of yeast, some sweetness, spices, citrusly frui. Taste is yeast, pepper, white wine, spices, fruity, citrus. Medium body, soft carbonation. Quite nice. 160512

Decent sized bright white head of fine bubbles that reduces rather quickly.  Light and fruity aroma with some lemon and pears, straw and some mild cheddar cheese.  Color is a bright medium gold.  Wow, what a refreshing beer.  Light crisp and very satisfying.  The perfect brew to have after standing around out in the sun all day.  More light fruit, grains and some dry grass.  Light white grape in there also.  Very easy drinking.  A very, very good light and refreshing summer saison!

On tap at Chappy's in Dayton, OH. On the heels of a barley wine and with spicy food, I just don't taste anything. No head, no lacing, no discernible flavor. I smell slight licorice, but barely. Licorice, citrus taste, but very slight. Wrong time, wrong place for me and this beer. Disappointed. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Appearance: Sofie comes out of the bottle to the tulip as a light, pale golden (almost glowing) bubblyness. A massive three-finger head burst and pop beautifully and cling to the glass like foamed milk atop a cappuccino. It’s a sight to behold and you’ll have a short time to watch. Stunning.

Smell: A sweet, sour funkiness stand up top. Green apples, grass, hay, This scent is so intoxicatingly tart that I find myself getting lost inside it. I’m in love with the smell and I can barely describe it. Maybe that’s why I’m so in love.

Taste: Crisp light sourness up front with a green apple center. It’s got a pale malty taste that helps highlight the gorgeous sour flavor that shines. Easily one of the most drinkable beers I’ve had. A favorite of the Belgian because the yeast stands next to the sour bacteria. 

Mouthfeel:: Sofie is light and bubbly across the tongue. Like a champagne that’s starting to go flat. Everything dances so well.

Overall: I’m in love. I’ll be snatching up as much of this gorgeously drinkable beer as possible and I suggest you do the same in your area. (Unless it’s Southern Illinois)
12 oz bottle.  Cloudy golden pour with a thin lacy head.  Aroma of yeast, grapefruit and barnyard funk.  Even, smooth taste with a great slightly sweet and sour finish.
Bottle.  Golden pour with quickly disappearing white head.  Banana Bread, citrus, orange, pepper, western spice.  Nice balance of dryness and carbonation.  Nice summer beer.

Bottle from Spirits Toms River. Pours out a decently carbonated, mostly clear golden color with a small white head. Aroma is slightly acidic tartness, orange peel and some spices. Taste is of dry, fruity yeast, some spice, orange peel, light tart funky, subtle fruits and a touch of bitterness creeps in on a very dry finish. Solid, and bound to go down hill now that AB owns it. Wonder when the beechwood aged version comes out.
Clear yellow/ light golden color. Scents of yeast, fruit & a slight sourness. Flavors of orange, fruity Belgian yeast, some hop bitterness. Light bodied & bubbly- a great summer beer!

Bottle, 2011 @ DØE Syd. Clear golden with medium white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, yeast, spices and a little hop. Flavour is malt, fruit, yeast, spices, little sweet, little citrus and a little bitter.

Very well done. This beer starts out with a week looking pale yellow color and a small head. I don’t give much credence to appearance though. The aroma has fruit and a bit of sourness. The flavor has a bit of lemon along with a touch of bread. Very crisp and clean. Finishes quite dry and refreshing.

Bottle sample at a tasting at DSG’s place. Thanks DSG. Hazy pale golden, frothy white head. Smells a little stale, a little like apple cider. Tastes mildly sour, then sweet. Light body, tangy, sweet finish that stays on the tongue for a while. Good.

2011 poured in a duvel tulip. Pours a hazy gold with a inch thick white head that lingers with ok lacing. Aroma is white grapes, yeast, and mild pepper. Reminds me of a pinot grigio. Taste is white grape, golden raisin, Belgian yeast, and some pepper. Thin mouthfeel with crisp carbonation. This beer resembles champagne. Not bad.

Bottle shared at a tasting at home. Clear golden with a frothy white head. Fruity aroma, pretty funky, with some yeast. Flavor has light sweetness, mild sourness, yeast, light grainy notes, nice fruitiness and a dry finish. Medium-bodied. Quite pleasant.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is pale golden. Aroma and taste are fruits, yeast, malt and hops. Sweet and medium carbonated.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a tulip.  2012 vintage bottled in Feb or March of 12.   Pours with an inch of very light white frothy head. Head rapidly disappears into nothingness leaving no lacing.  Very nice aromas of grapes, leaves and agave syrup.  Mouthfeel is very light with a touch of tingle from the abundant carbonation.  Taste is very much like the bottle says, champagne.  Tastes of grapes, grass, funk and ginger.  Overall, I liked this beer.  Glad I bought a four pack so I can try another and then another two a few years out.

CHAMPAGNE BARREL VERSION: Nice clean flavors on this beer. It is a little sweet and cloys a bit, you can definitely tell it has been aged. The champaigne comes across and compliments the light, clean fruity flavors very well. I really enjoyed this beer a lot.
On draft at the Morris Tap & Grill.   A nice looking unfiltered pale golden yellow.  The flavor is well described commercially by the brewery.  Glad to see Goose Island finally available in NJ!

Bottle. Pours a golden yellow with zero head and spotty lacing. Nose is orange peel, salty ham, honey, lemongrass. Taste is pepper, earthy farmhouse notes, spicy grains, and white wine. This was a decent saison from a brewer whose quality is sure to fall off due to the recent acquisition by Anheuser-Busch. Try them while you can. Note: quality hasn’t fallen off yet.

2011 bottle, poured a slight hazy yellow, straw like, with a foamy white head. Aroma is spice (pepper) with notes of yeast and crisp citrus. Flavor was spicy, with a touch of dry grape tartness, like a sparking wine. Pretty enjoyable.

Tasting at World Wine & Liquor in Mentor Ohio. Poured into a 4 oz. Plastic cup a slightly hazy straw color with a big and fluffy white head. A musty, funky aroma of lemon & orange peels, the trade mark bubblegum, pepper, and a yeasty spiciness. Full-bodied and a creamy. The flavor starts with bubble gum and bananas. Lemons and oranges at the end. There is a vanilla quality along with pepper and a yeasty spiciness throughout. This is my favorite of the G.I. Belgian brews.

It pours hazy pale blonde with a fluffy white foam. On the nose its quite lactic with acidic pineapple and a touch of brett. Its a light touch in the mouth, reminding me of the hibiscus flavours from Goose Island Fleur with a touch of white pepper in the finish. Sparkling carbonation as fine as champagne.

I love this stuf!  It always tastes best on a warm afternoon, very refreshing.
Love those citrus aromas, lemons oranges.  Just the right amount of tartness from those wine barrels.  Well balanced flavors of citrus.  Leaves a wonderful taste in the finish.

Sampled on tap pours bright gold with a frothy huge head.  Aromas of grapes some aromas of bright malts and some straw.  Flavor is cloying sweet with some peppery champagne flavors.  Body is medium and finish is dry
Tap. Hazy honey color with decent foamy head. It does smell winey, peppery, and citrusy. Kind of like a Sauvignon Blanc. Tastes almost peachy plus dry. Clean and light but not quite crisp. Not bad.

Poured into a Duvel tulip from a 12 ounce bottle bottled on 3-14-2012.



A: Hazy straw colored body with a very thin white head with poor retention.



S: A semi-sweet, yet dry blend of dry red wine, oak, semi-sweet citrus, and a funk I can’t describe. This is very complex, there’s a lot to grasp, but I really like this. I feel as it massively changes each time I smell it.



T: Whoa, super complex and each sip reveals more. This beer is sweet, dry, and tarty all at the same time. Tarty lemon and slight spice starts the flavor into a very noticeable dry red wine flavor (reminds me of a valoplicella wine) with a mild funk throughout with a pretty strong orange sweetness. I like this.



M: Crisp medium body with a sharp finish.



O: I like this a lot more than the rating indicates, this is my new favorite saison. This is very complex and should appeal to wine drinkers and beer drinkers alike.
Aroma of corn, wheat, and yeast.  Pours blonde with a small head.  Tastes nice and bitter with a great wheaty taste and a bitter yeast champagne finish.  Nice beligian but not gulp able.

Poured into a Brugse Zot glass. Very light colored; transparent yellow. It has a perfect finger and half of white head the held nicely.
Smells like cottoncandy and orange. Too faint though.
Mild citrus fruit, sour something and seltzer water.
The mouthfeel is amazing. It was so soft at first, then a little crisp and bubbly. Really, really nice.
It looked and felt good but the smell and taste were really lacking. Easy to drink because it tasted like flavored water. Not really impressed.

Nice saison with a bit of pepper but I prefer a bit spicier saison. Glass maybe not have been as clean as possible taking away from the possible fizziness. 

On tap from rock n brews. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Originally reviewed: 9/13/10. Bottle picked up in Findlay, OH in June. Cellared since. Bottle on date: Oct. 23, 2009. Poured into a tulip glass. 

Pours a uber-cloudy deep gold with a large frothy white head capping it off. This looked like a dessert with whipped cream on it. Big scents of pineapple, tart apples, orange zest, and yeast. Very nice nose. 

The body was crisp, bordering on effervescent. Finish was mild. Tame white peppery spiciness right off the bat, followed by a wash of tart fruits, and capped off with a mild funky yeast quality. Flavors really meld together well. So glad I’ve got another one of these away for later. Really standout offering here. Drinkability is lowered, as this needs to be savored. I’d find no problem splitting this with good friends. Highly recommend.
Pours golden with a white head.  The real champagne of beers.  Grapefruit sweetness.  Very appealing, crisp, clean taste.  Tried this on a couple of occasions, and every time I like it more and more.
Pours foggy gold.  Aromas of wheat and spices with a hint of honey.  Really taste citrus to begin with.  Followed by an array of spices.  Not strong at all.  A very pleasant beer.

Picked this up at Bert’s Better beers. 2012 Vintage. Stuck it in the fridge and poured into a Hill Farmstead glass.



A - 2-Finger crystal clear head, okay head lacing and fast dissipation of what head was there. SRM of 3. Honey colored, light golden tan appearance.



S - Wild yeast, honey and spices.



T - Nice notes of orange and wild farmhouse style yeast. :Very mild spice almost barely there. Lingering taste of a cheap lager which is disappointing. 



M - 80/20 carbonation on a mouth swish. Light bodied, dry finish and that annoying Schlitz taste on the after taste.



O - Tasty. Would be better if something sweet were added like honey, berries or a bit more aging.

Slurp slurp... this is a beautiful beer.  Rich bubbles rising up in this lively wine barreled saison that has great aromas of grapefruit, orange peel and peppery spice.  The flavors are well balanced and refreshing !  Its not quite as complex as some other saisons on the market but it pure, zen like balance make this a top pick in my book !

On tap taste at Congregation Ale House in Long Beach, CA on 4/9/12.  Poured into 8 oz. snifter. 

Clear, pale yellow with very fine, small white head and fair to good lacing. 

Aroma of citrus, flowers, spices and earthen yeast.

Taste is fruity, lony and mildly tart, 

Medium/light body and soft carbonation. 

Very nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark Golden.  Spicy.  Blinded w a slight sour taste.  Very thin head. Low, subtle ibu.

Bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy golden with bubbly white head.  Fades rather quickly. Smell is soft yeast, white wine, lite citrus.  Taste is light spice, more soft white wine, some yeast and bread.  Good brew.

Bottle, bought in Chicago in October 2011.

Hazy golden with a medium white head. Aroma of yeast, citrus, bread and spices. The taste was very dry with spices, yeast and hay. Also nuts and some malt and brett. An ok beer.

Len och frisk doft. Smaken är lite sträv eller lite brett. Frisk men ganska torr och jag hittar en tydlig nötighet i eftersmaken. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden yellow color with a white head. Aroma is very lemony, with breadiness, hay, spices like coriander and clove, orange peel and some sweet sugar like notes. The flavor follows the nose with lots of citrus and lemon notes, orange peel, the spice of coriander and clove, subtle vinous notes, hay, breadiness and some of the sugary notes. The body is light with a dry mouth feel. Overall a pretty tasty Saison.

Tragedy struck at my home early Monday morning. Either a tremor of a passing train caused a box of bomber bottles to slide off its shelf in my beer cellar. Only one casualty, though: my 2009 bottle of Sofie. Luckily, when I went to GI Clybourn to train for their sampling program, they had it on tap. Color is bright Belgian pils or tripel gold, and pretty hazy. Almost a whole finger’s width of white parfait foam. Smell has a very light orange zest and Belgian light malt. A bit of spice in the aroma, too, but my nose is too stuffy to best describe it. Taste is effervescent, and my first impression is of light pepper after all. Maltiness settles in to leave a nice sticky aftertaste. Maybe some Belgian candi sugar, but not too sweet. Alcohol is not a big player here. Just a nice golden ale flavor with extra depth.

Bottle from the Louisville Beer Store. Light pale gold with thin white head. This has a nose like a wit with Brett. Saison-wit mash-up. Sweet. Orange peel. Lemon. Lively palate. Dry finish. Not incredibly complex, but good.

on tap at GI Cly, all I get from the taste is rotten oranges, like a musty acidic orange flavor.. the nose doesnt have this only the taste, obviously there is a good amount of carbonation and nothing to make me seem its junk? glad it was only a glass.

Mousse savonneuse, liquide blanc doré et opaque. Des arômes de zest citronné, de blé poivré, de vanille qui se transpose doucement en bouche. Un côté vineux fait son apparition en finale. Très délicat, légèrement acide avec une présence boisé brillamment enveloppante.
Bottle. Clear golden colour with a small white head. Yeasty aroma. Orange spicy flavour.
Fragrant and sweet, this light-colored beer has a nice bit of head and a mild flavor. Good in summer, but not a year-round beer.

Pours a slightly hazy yellow with a tall fluffy white head. Smell like fresh citrus, wheat and yeast. Taste is fruity, malty, tart with notes of lemon, peach, wheat, and white wine. Nice malty after taste with a clean tartness. Med-light body, silky texture, little carbonation. This would be great on a warm day and with light food.

Poured on draft into taster glass
Aroma:  sweet, vanilla, peaches, mango, oranges
Appearance:  very light and pale.  very clear
Taste:  very sweet, medium sour, tiny bit of bitter
Palate: Medium body, thin mouthfeel, very carbonated
Overall: very crisp and refreshing.  light and airy.  Extremely lemony.  Would be great summer beer.

Cloves, must, yeast, acidity, and earthy nose - complex and so amazing.  Flavor acidic, earthy, dry and balanced with some citrus.  Carbonation is dry and almost champagne like.  Amazing beer - I’d like to try an unblended version and 100% BA... just my 2 cents.

Bottle. Pours a hazy, straw color with a thin white head. Aroma is light with notes of, orange, green apple, and a bit of funk. Taste is pretty much the same with some Belgian yeast in the mix. Quick, crisp finish.
Spiced aroma.  Hazy gold in color.  Moderately sweet orange taste with complex spice tones and slight wood and wine notes.

One of the few beer of this sort available in 12oz bottle four pack. Aroma is Belgian yeasty spiciness and subtle fruitiness. Flavor is more this spice but with a interesting almost bubblegum flavor. A little tart and funky note comes in later. Smooth finish. Nice beer.

(Bottle, Monk’s Café Wallingatan, Stockholm) Pale golden colour with frothy, white head. Malty, fruity, spicy nose with notes of tropical fruit, grass, hay, pineapple, spicy hops and a touch of yeast. Malty, fruity taste with grass, bread, tropical fruit and a generous grassy bitterness in a finish with a touch of sweetness. Medium body, mainly dry but with some sweetness in the finish. A solid and well made saison with a touch of triple. Very nice.
Pours a murky gold with very little white head. Very light aroma. Nice saison flavor with orange, spice and some earthiness.

Bottle shared by Lagunitasfan. Thanks TIm! It pours a nice golden color with a white head. The aroma is fruity with apricots, orange, mild spice and whiffs of brett. The flavor is the same with a nice citric tartness. Very nice subdued bretty finish. Theres some funk and Belgian yeast spiciness in there as well. I was pleasantly surprised by this one, as it had kinda fallen off my radar. I would buy this again.
On tap at Dexters.  Not impressed by how out looks but I like the flavor.  Good profile and easy drinking.

In the garage with Joenugs.  Light golden amber with light haze. Great funky light citrus and yeast. Beautiful and light. Spicy and citrus. Lovely. Lots of movement between spices and funk and tart and golden happiness. White wine and champagne. Just lovely. Must run to bottle shop to get more at $8.49 while still in stock.

From notes.  First reviewed 4/23/2010.  Poured from a bottle into a pint glass. Bottle date 12/11/2009.

Sofie has a very hazy golden yellow color, with a 1 inch head with large bubbles. Some refreshing carbonation visibly rising from the bottom. Decent head retention.

Herbal and earthy aromas, with some citrus rind. Yeast and pepper notes as well. Complex aroma. 

Biscuity malt and yeast flavors up front, with a dry sweetness that reminds me of white grape skin. A spicy peppery flavor comes in toward the end, with an grassy oiliness. There is a slightly tart aftertaste. Nuanced and very pleasant. 

Average carbonation, slightly dry feel. Slightly grainy.

Sofie is deceptively complex. I enjoyed the mild but complex taste. An easy drinker.
Golden pour with a large white head.  Citrus and yeast aroma.  Crisp tart fruit, orange, lemon, dry wine like finish.  Fantasic beer that pairs well with sushi.
This one is very tart and sweet. There was a lot of head, especially when I first opened the bottle.  This one is a bit too tart for my taste.

Golden color, citrusy and nice carbonation. Dry but fruity. Very flavorful saison, as flavorful as you can get before it drops off. Almost like a saison foret

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sofie pours a hazy golden color with a huge fluffy white head. Nice carbonation throughout. Just a good looking pour. The smell is fantastic. Yeasty, funky, spicy, and fruity. Taste is fantastic and refreshing. A good amount of funk from the wild yeasts. White pepper and other spices. Round that out with citrus and lemon. The mouthfeel is slightly sour and tart and has a nice dry feeling to it. Between light and medium bodied
This is a very nice, crisp beer. Orange esthers introduce a slightly bitter/orange finish.

Aroma is vanilla, yeast, citrus. Taste is wheat yeast vanilla citrus, orange, coriander, balanced out with light hops. Served in Belgian goblet at goose islAnd.  Winner here!



---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, Capital Grille. Hazy bright yellow, light and spicy aroma, orange peel and grains.  Taste is crisp, light, more orange peel and lemon.  Dry finish.  "Elegant" comes to mind in describing this. Complex and subtle. Well done for such a light bodied beer.

Great looking beer! Tan-yellow and a bit hazy with a fantastic, thick, fluffy head and very nice lacing. Smells slightly sour, fruity and yeasty, earthy and pungent, spicy. Very nice.

Tastes really good, pungent and earthy flavors accented nicely with apple, pear, a touch of oranges, and ample spices.

Feel is quite rich and full despite a medium body. Very nice lingering spicy tastes. Lots of carbonation.  Pretty dry finish.

Drinks great. A terrific beer in every respect.

Bottle to snifter. Pours pale golden yellow with a quick white soapy head that dissipates to a thin collar. Aroma is fruity with a little spice. Taste is more fruit and spice with some yeast and a warming finish. Palate is medium and crisp with a dry warming finish. No complaints on this one.

Pours a pale yellow with a big, long lasting white head. Aromas of citrus, grass, leather, and wood. The flavors are medium sourness with hints of some sweetness. The carbonation is fizzy with a light to medium body. Overall a very nice saison. The Brett flavors meld well with the citrus. Great experience!!!
Pear, orange peel, vanilla and white pepper notes.  Thin and watery texture.  Slightly tart and dry.  Not picking up the 20% wine barrel.  Needs some carbonation.  Good, but not great.

genius. So great. Tons of layers of enjoyment. Sweet, refreshing. Crisp like champagne. Awesome. Yeasty and citrusy. Pours a hazy yellow. The head dissipates fairly quickly leaving small circles of lace on the surface. I reinforce the tasting not above with the addition of the tartness. Wonderful brew
Light color with tart and sweet aroma.  Tart flavor with noticeable carbonation but very balanced and a nice citrus finish.  Palate leaves me wanting more.

Hazy straw gold with plenty of white head.  Wonderful aroma of tart citrus, peach/mango/pear, light pinot, vanilla, mild funk, and yeast.  Fresh citrus flavor, white wine, and peach.  Nice dry finish with lingering tart citrus.  Springy carbonation.  Clean.
Sour spicy aroma. Similar flavour with some extra lemon sour at the end. Yum yum.

On tap at ckbb. Golden straw pour with slight haze and a monstrous white head. Grassy herbal lemon, wheaty straw, lead to crisp doughy bread and the slightest brett hint. Medium body with ample caressing carbonation, finishing dry.
Pours hazy yellow. Citrus and pinneapple aroma. Flavor is pinneapple, citrus, spicy with hints of corrainder. Some tart flavors as well. An excellent tasting beer

30 dec 2011, bottle. Pale yellow, slightly hazy, steady bubbles. Faintly tart, faintly cobwebby farmyard ale. Thin body and a bit fizzy. Very light and refreshing. A tally a quite refreshing beer. I’d say it is more of a saigon, though it has some faint tart notes and is probably fuzzier than a Saison.

A - pours very light deep yellow with fluffy light head. S - Aromas of bready yeasts, apples, and pineapple. M - very light great palate. lively bubbles with a nice dry feel. T - light bready yeasts on the nose. Subtle hints of apples and citrus fruits; pineapple and lemon. Tangy with a ligh pepper hint. O - A fantastic beer. Very subtle, yet complex. My favorite belgian saison. Something I will always have on hand. 8

Delicious, yeasty, dry, crisp, sparkly. Thick white head that dissipates with abundant lace. Refreshing with a good alcohol content. Cloudy golden appearance. Much carbonation. Just like the description: "A subtle, spicy white pepper note, a hint of citrus from the orange peel and a creamy vanilla finish".
Bottle.  2/19/2010.  Golden pour, highly carbonated.  Thick lasting white head.  Floaters.  Nice spicy, barnyard aroma, pears and hints of baked bread.  Light, dry and peppery.  Refreshing.

had this from tap and poured into a snifter. Clear gold color with a small head that doesn’t last all too long.

Very aromatic with a good amount of citrus aromas and spices with some florals.

medium/full bodied with a very smooth feel. Polished with a touch of funk along with citrus flavors and spices.

this is a 2011 bottle. Should develop more funky aromas and flavors with more age, but the citrus base of it right now is very nice.

22oz bottle - 



What else can be said about Goose Island that already hasn’t been said. World class brewers. Sofie makes its way into today’s rotation and what a beautiful beer, I don’t care what the season is. From a really plain looking label comes a clear, bananan-yellow colored beer with a bright white fluffy head, that looked like it could support something. Aroma is just sooo incredibly refreshing. Tons of zesty lemon, yeast, light funk, leathery and some orange juice to it too. Flavor is so incredibly sharp and crisp. Lemony, peppery, yeasty/bready...lots of honey-like floral flavor mixed with some Bosc pear. Stunning beer and it’s so easy to drink.
Bottle.  Cloudy pale yellow pour with a white head.  Aromas of citrus and spice.  Well balanced, light and refreshing with lots of spice notes.

Pours a slightly cloudy, pale golden yellow color with a 1.5 finger white head that quickly fades into a thin ring. Minimal lacing. 

Slightly earthy aroma with hints of sweet fruit, earthy funk and alcohol. The estery fruit notes counter the funky yeast with hints of apple, pear and grape. I’m also picking up notes of grass, bread and peppery spice. 

Crisp medium body with soft carbonation, earthy funk, sweet light fruit, zesty spice and alcohol. Up front there is a strong fruit presence with hints of apple and pear followed by some musty/earthy notes of grass and straw before finishing with slightly dry with more sweet alcohol flavor. A nice amount of zesty spice and bready yeast add another dimension and fullness to the palate. Very nice balance of flavors going on here.

12oz bottle 9/02/2011 pours pale hazy gold with 1 finger of dense, white creamy head, some visible streams of effervescence, nice lacing.  Aroma is has a pleasant tartness, lemon and orange peel, peppery yeast, french oak, honey, pretty funky and bretty overall.  Taste is reminiscent of Orval with funky barnyard hay, pepper, and sour bitter lemon, finishes with orange peel, wheat, and more tartness.  Body is medium, sticky, highly carbonated and thus frothy, finishes dry as a bone with lingering spice.  Overall, my favorite from Goose Island.  I am a big brett fan and the fact that GI is still brewing good stuff after the AB InBev buyout is reassuring.  Not to mention a great price point on a wild yeast beer.

Bomber, 2010. Clear pale golden with a white head. Fresh, spice, pepper, chardonnay, yeast. high carbonation, below average body, mild sweet, some lemon and chardonnay at the end, bit of booze, very light and fresh. Leaves a sweet taste on the palate.

Bottle @ home. 2010 vintage. Cloudy, golden yellow appearance with a big, fluffy, white head. Lightly vinous, Belgian yeasty, mild barnyard, mildly funky, pale malty, mild citrusy aroma. Mildly tart, lemon/orange citrusy, slightly funky, mild barnyard, slightly vinous, Belgian golden ale flavor. Tangy, mildly tart, lemon citrusy aftertaste. Nice beer.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours clear bright yellow (almost like mountain dew) with small bright white head.  Little light lacing, thin body, watery texture, and medium carbonation.  Aroma is light citrus and taste light tart citrus malt, hint of yeast, and light hint of pepper.  Not as yeasty as many saisons and much thiner body.
Pours a cloudy pale yellow with white head, funky nose with slight citrus, first sip is disappointing kind of bland oak dominates, slight bitterness at finish.

This poured a cloudy darker yellow color with a white head.  Aroma was grassy, light barn, yeast, and some citrus fruit.  Flavor was very lightly tart, somewhat spicey, light funk, and lemony. Pretty good saison.

Bottle @ party in LA. Blonde-yellow. Bright floral hop aroma is bony and resinous like mastic. Yum! Nice balance of sweet-tart. Dry and nuanced. Great carbonation level. Just when it could be too sweet, the hops rescue. Finishes with a candi kiss, after a journey of hoppy dryness. Quite a refined brew!

Bottle from 10/23/2009
Bottle opens with a nice crack and then a volcano of foam that almost made it into the sink. When it all settles down it pours a mostly clear golden straw color with a pillowy white head that sticks around forever. Smells sweet and fruity with lemons andgreen apples dominating the aroma. There’s some funk in there that reminds me a bit of spoiled meat? Luckily its not to strong but its there. Taste is a bit sweet, green apples and honey mixed with a bit of funk. Spirited level of carbonation, medium body, sweet almost sticky mouthfeel. Despite the misstep upon opening, this beer isn’t half bad.

Hazy pale golden pour with a huge foamy white head.  Aroma of soft phenolics, orange, with a whiff of sourness.  Mild sour flavor with hints of apples.  Crisp tingly tart bitter finish.  Light bodied, not quite as carbonated as I would prefer.  Nice delicate sour beer.  Very refreshing.

12 oz bottle, 2011. Pours cloudy gold with white head. The aroma is lemon, some fruity esters, coriander, some phenolic spiciness, mild sweet honey note, a hint of sourdough. The flavor is nice smooth maltiness with some cracker and lemon cookie notes. There is a pleasant subdued Dupont-esque spiciness with white pepper, coriander, hay, very slight dank cellar note. There’s just a touch of acidity to the finish, which is itself nice and dry. Lovely brew.

22oz bottle from Pick’s poured into a snifter. Bottled on 2/19/10. Been aging this one for a little bit. The cap popped off like a bottle of champagne. My glass is half full of just foam and it takes about 3 minutes to go down. Pours a cloudy gold with about (as of now) 4 fingers of frothy bright white head. Sweet yeast aroma with a nice scent of citrus. Slight aroma of clove also. Taste is lightly sweet and lightly sour. Taste of grapefruit and citrus. Medium bodied with a thick yet sticky texture. Lively carbonation and a long sweet finish. Overall, very good. I wish I could get more of this stuff.

bottle in a pint glass -pours cloudy yellow with thin white head and minimal lacing.  Nose is pepper and orange/citrus. Aroma is lemon peel or some other peel and that Miller High Life smokiness.  Taste is sweet and tart.  Finish is medium-length.  Aftertaste is stale.  This is another bottle that was mislabeled - this should not say, "Belgian style ale" - but, "saison’ or at least humor me with something more vague like, "beer style beer."  Too tart and disappointing.

Bottled.  A very light yellow coloured beer with a good white head.  Fubky in the mouth bit tart rather than sour.  In fact it’sa bit too tart.  good fubky lemony peppery hoppy nose.  A bit too brash in the mouth with the lemon being too tart.  Not my knid of saison.
Belgian in style and in look. Pours an orangy/amber colour with thick white head. Very good.

Had this in a bottle poured into a pint glass.  Foamy head in the glass.  Very sweet flavor.  Golden pale color.  Smell is sweet grain.  Full bodied.  There is a slight hint of barley at the end.  This was pretty good and fairly interesting for the style.

(bomber, 2009 vintage, sampled 7/12/10). Clear golden color. Large white head. Moderate citrus aroma. Moderate sweet honey/sugar flavor, with light pepper. Avg duration. Light alcohol finish. Thin/slick texture. Moderate to high carbonation. Fair lacing.

Draft at GI Clybourn on 8/4/11.  Pours a straw color.  Small white head.  Spicy aroma.  Citrus flavor.  Really gives me a feel of champagne.  Soft and mellow feel. Dry finish. Very solid beer.  Only disappointment was that it left me feeling too much champagne and not enough farmhouse saison.  Will need to rerate this one in future.
12/23/12 - Just drank a two year old bottle (1/29/11).  This beer ages very nicely.  Still definitely gives a champagne feel, but the belgian spices are more present then in the fresh draft version.  Wasn’t sure how this one would hold up, but based on this experience I wouldn’t be afraid to age this one for quite awhile.  It was still very much alive.

Location/Date:Bottle during Hurricane Irene on August 27th, 2011..bottle from Feb 2010.



Appearance: Pours a golden cloud. 
 

Aroma: Sweet aroma, nearly pineapple-ish.
 

Taste: Didn’t really taste like a saison to me, more like a belgian blonde. Light hop, some citrus.
   

Palate:Can sense the "champagne"-ness of this beer from the second it pours. 



Summary: Surprisingly, this beer aged well.

Glass, 5-ounce, on the premise, savoured on July 5 2011; eye: yellowish, opalescent, no effervescence, tiny ring of white head, light lacing; nose: slight farm, slight fruity, wheat, light acidity; mouth: slight farm, slight fruity, light acidity, spices, finale in malt with slight hops, medium body, below-average carbonation, a bit thin; overall: ordinary

FRANÇAIS 

Verre, 5 onces, à la brasserie, savourée le 5 juillet 2011; œil : jaunâtre, opalescent, pas d’effervescence, petit anneau de mousse blanche, légère dentelle; nez : très léger ferme, très légère fruité, blé, légère acidité; bouche : très léger ferme, très léger fruité, légère acidité, épices, finale en malt avec très léger houblon, corps moyen, carbonatation sous la moyenne, un peu mince; en résumé : ordinaire

Vintage 2010. Pours a clear pale yellow with a huge billowy head. The aroma is funky, barnyard, cheese, Belgian yeast, orange, peppercorn. Very fragrant and complex. Light bodied and crisp with high carbonation. The flavor is equally complex. Starts out slightly sweet, lots of grass and straw, orangey citrus, banana, clove and peppercorn, and funky Brett flavors. Finishes crisp and perfectly hopped. This is seriously a damn good beer. Light and refreshing but extremely complex. I’m gonna get a few more bottles and sit on them for a few years, let that Brett do it’s thing. It can only get better.


Vintage 2015 (5/13/16, in Chicago) Very similar to my deScription from 5 years ago. Grassy, funky, leathery brett notes. Crisp yeasty finish. Banana notes.

I poured a 12oz bottle dated in late March. It poured a light, straw yellow with a hint of light orange to it with a billowing white head. It smells delicious, a nice blend of yeast and citrus aromas with light sweetness. It tastes excellent as well. Once again, a great mix of breadyness and citrus flavors with a subtle sweetness. It drank very crisp and didn’t lose any carbonation in it’s six months after being bottled. This one is very, very drinkable and delicious on tap or out of the bottle. I can’t wait to try this one aged.

Tasted on 8/10/11 from a 12oz bottle purchased at Lush Roscoe, 2011 vintage.  Pours clear golden-yellow with an average white head that slowly recedes to a bit of whispy lace with a thin collar.  The nose is lightly sweet with some candi sugar, floral aromas, spicy Saison yeast, orange peel, and light spices.  The flavor is also lightly sweet with candi sugar, orange flower, white peppercorn, and some spicy Saison yeast.  The body is medium and somewhat oily with lively carbonation and a long spicy yeast and lightly sweet orange flower water finish.

12oz bottle. Pours a cloudy yellow color with a huge soapy white head. Good lacing. Long lasting foam. Very funky smelling with a lingering floweriness and light bready notes. Taste is hoppy, a bit vinous, with a decise barnyard flavor to it. Medium bodied. Very complex brew.

22 oz bottle. Pours a hazy yellow with fizzy white head. Aroma of citrus, farmhouse, popcorn and butter scotch. Flavor is much the same with a touch of grass, banana and nice funk. Mouthfeel is light body, soft, with fizzy carbonation. Overall, solid brew.

Bottled. Aroma- definite hints from the wine barrel, citrus and yeast. Poured (into a chalice) a nice golden with just a bit of head, nice bubbling. Nice subtle beer. Some sweetness but a tart finish of a granny smith.

A hazy, light yellow pour with a white head.  The aroma is peppery with some citrus.  The light body has sparkling texture with lively, almost fizzy, carbonation.  The taste is tart with a dry finish.
From a bottle poured a golden color with a fair amount of head.  Nice light refreshing malty tart flavor with a quick finish.

Poured into a chalice. Immediate aromas of citrus and yeast typical of belgians. I thought the taste was good but the aftertaste was off for belgians. It had a bitter/hoppy taste typical of IPAs. Memorable but I’d say it’s not true to the style.

750ml bottle:  This one pours a pale, straw yellow color.  There was a huge frothy white head on it that didn’t linger long, nor did it leave any lacing.  Nose is mainly peppery and coriander.  Some citrus also.  The taste is very good.  Somewhat lighter body, but very flavorful.  Some wheat notes, coriander and peppery notes, and some citrus, just like the nose.  Subtle, yet a bit complex and very tasty.  I will definitely have another.

Bottle: &nbsp Dirty straw, hint of gold, large rocky white head, falls quickly, spotty lacing. &nbsp Pale floral and citrus nose. &nbsp A little bit of straw and mealiness. &nbsp Smells decent for an American made Saison. &nbsp More barnish and musty on the tongue than the nose suggests. &nbsp Not all that mealy, not spritzy or bubbley either. &nbsp Semi-sweet, a bit grassy on the backside, smidgen of lemon. &nbsp Still remains a little musty and barnish. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are actually quite good, not bubbley but its smooth. &nbsp This one was pretty flavorful from start to end. &nbsp Probably one of the better American examples that I have had. &nbsp Thanks Kevin for this one!
bottled, thanks to pawola22, golden yellow with white creamy foam ,aroma of lemony yeast, flavor of lemon, floral and citrus soft acidic, yeast, good carbonation and finish

June 18, 2010. 22oz bottle shared by blankboy with me, gregclow, jerc & mabel.  Hazy pale yellow pour with a smallish white head.  Mouth-watering aroma - lemon, spice, sweet malt, some lactic sourness, grassy bitterness, alcohol - a lot going on!!
