The taste delivered, add in coriander bitterness, sour funk, fruity green apple crispness - damned nice.  Thick, lively mouthfeel, acidic, dry, tart and spicy in the long, shifting, fairly complex finish - really, really good stuff.
Pour is a light gold with a white head. Nose is of lemon and spice.Taste is very similar. Smooth on the tongue but nothing all too special.

Date: July 3, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Beer Tasting, Bloomington, MN Appearance: Translucent yellow with slight amount of head Aroma: Tart, sweet and citrus Flavor: Consistent with aroma and dry Other: Great saison, went down very easily.

New 750 bottle size on July 28, 2013 in my Goose wine style glass. Picking up the wine and barrel aromas. Nice mix of spice and tartness. Dry finish. Bumping up overall by one from original rating.

Tap at Sunset Grill in Boston. Hazy yellow pour with a foamy head. A subtle but delicious beer with notes of peppery spice, yeasty bread, tart fruit and wood, a bit of sweet vanilla, and some nice citrus hop presence on both the nose and the tongue. Palate is soft, supple, dry, and drinkable. Not aggressive, but well crafted and tasty.

Great aroma, scents of green apples and tart citrus. The appearance a faded gold, cloudy with a small egg white head. 

The taste comes on very tart at first, with citrus flavors of apple, orange peels, and mild vanilla. It’s a light sour, with little bitterness. More tart than it is sweet.

The palate is light and tickling. This beer has a very mild fizz with thin texture coming to a light puckery finish.

Bottle brought back at Christmas from Andersons in Toledo.  Aroma is soft lemon, straw and light spices.  Tastes are the orange peel, pepper, barnyard funk, wood and bread.  Crazy good texture.  Nice surprise - excellent brew.  Right up there with the best saisons I’ve tried.

Hazy straw/gold color; Light to medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of yeast, floral/fruit, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, citrus (notably orange), spice, and some fruit; Finish is dry; High carbonation; Very tasty - quite good overall.

Honestly this is a brew of genius. So great. Tons of layers of enjoyment. Sweet, refreshing. Crisp like champagne. Awesome. Yeasty and citrusy. 

Pours a hazy yellow. The head dissipates fairly quickly leaving small circles of lace on the surface. I reinforce the tasting not above with the addition of the tartness. Wonderful brew.

Found on tap at Maxie’s Southern Comfort restaurant in Milwaukee. What a treat! A perfect mate to the fried oyster po’ boy sandwich. A full-bodied saison that had all sorts of fruity flavors happening. Will have to try bottled version.

A: Nice golden hazy yellow. Big carbonation at first but dissipates quickly. A few minute floaties in there as well.

S: Funky and zesty, I love this smell. Almost like a gueze actually, but not nearly as sour. Lemons and brett.

T: Just like the smell. Tastes funky and with a blast of lemon and pepper. One of the best summer brews or year round.

M: Crisp, carbonated and thin.

O: Excellent. One of the best saisons I’ve had and I’ve had a lot. This is worth seeking out.

Big bottle, poured a light golden color with a generous head.  Aroma of orange peel and some coriander, slight banana from the yeast possibly.  Taste is lite sweetness with some lite bitterness touch.  Dry finish.  Soft creamy texture.  Not a huge fan of the saison style, but this has to be one of my favorites of the style.

2011 vintage. 22 oz. into Estrella Damm tall pint glass (not ideal glassware, but it’s what I have to work with). Hazy gold-orange. Thick, sticky foamy head. Smell of funky yeast and spice. Aroma reveals really pleasant barnyard and fresh citrus (oranges) notes, and some herbs. Lively mouthfeel. Great, layered malt profile, and flavor stays citrusy. Leans towards sweet, but has a bit of a tartness in the finish. Bitterness is very low. Outstanding rendition, superb drinkability. This is sessionable at 6.5%.

On tap. Aroma is peppery and and yeasty. Appearance is hazy straw with a thick white head of foam. Taste is yeasty and peppery, much like the aroma. Medium bodied and fairly quaffable. Interesting little beer.

straw color, fast settling head with almost champagne like bubbles and slight haze. solid carbonation, with slight funk and citrus flavors. one of my favorite beers to smell. slight sour on front of flavor. great beer.

A hazy, pale blonde color with a quickly dissipating white head and an aroma that is strongly lemon and yeast.  The flavor is mostly lemon and yeast up front with a spicy, peppery finish filling in from the back of the throat.  It takes a few seconds for all of the flavors to come through, making it a complex and interesting drink.
Bottle. Pours cloudy pale yellow with a thick white head. Aroma of citrus fruit, champagne, spice, and sour fruit. Flavour of citrus, low hops, mainly malt. Mild hops. Average.

22 oz. bottle, pours hazy straw yellow with a white head. Aroma of champagne yeast, spices, light fruits and citrus. Flavour is very yeast, dry chardonnay, light fruits (citrus) and light spices. Solid saison.

Yellow color with lots of particulate floating, small white head and white lacing.  Smell of lemon, tart malt and orange.  It has a complex flavor of citrus and sour, almost like an artisinal ale.  this beer seems to be a more flavorful and complex belgian ale.  Do not fruit this beer.
Pours yellow with a huge fizzy white head.    Sour aroma and soft sour flavor.  Great beer.
Pours a clear orange with a finger of stark white head.  Slight sour malt notes in the odor.  Tart flavor to it with a bit of a sharp aftertaste.

A very special beer that everyone should at least try. I immediately fell
in love with the aroma. It was citrusy, yeasty, with a huge fruity character. The taste is dominated by sour orange peel throughout and it culminates with a very yeasty feel. Carbonation is very light, I’d call it sparkly, and the 6.5% ABV is formidably well concealed. It also has this wine-like feel to it. I liked it very much.

Having to drink non-IPA’s like this because that is what the old lady prefers, but might as well rate them.  I try all of her wheat/white/saison/hef, etc. beers that she prefers.  This one  was pretty tasty actually.  banana, vanilla, golden, clear, minimal head, light sweetness, light body.

Not sure why it happens, but this is a beer I have drank a lot of starting with the early versions at GTMW. Point is, I love this beer. The current bottle is a 22oz that is 11mo’s old. Most of the ones that I have had were 4 packs with a little less age on them. This beer is nice fresh and really nice with a bit of age on it. Yeasty, fruity, bretty aroma with a touch of wood. Taste is moderately dry with a nice tartness and flavors of candi sugar, pils malt, hosreseblanket, citrus and vanilla. I was thinking the other day that I am always so sad when I run out of this, it as nearly a perfect beer for all occasions.

2010 vintage, bottled Nov 19, 2010. 650 mL bottle from Beers of the World in Rochester, served in a tulip. Pours hazy straw-golden with a medium, dense white head and champagne carbonation. The head remains and leaves a moderate amount of fine lace. The nose has notes of coriander, orange, banana, lemon, oak, flowers, pepper, pale malts and yeast. The flavour is dry and a bit sour with a touch of acidity. It has citric notes, spice, a touch of vanilla and some hops. The finish is long and citrusy-peppery. On the palate, it is medium in body with a smooth, creamy texture and lively carbonation. Overall, this is a very nice saison with a delicate citrusy character. Bright and floral, it is refreshing yet moderately complex. 2011-05-11
Golden in color, with barnyard funk and a strong sour note that glides above orange peel citrus and white pepper spice. Nicely done.
Bottle Light but very flavorful. My girlfriend loved it and finished it ha. Good taste but not what I’m looking for in a beer. =)

Tasted 5-10-2011 at home from bottle.  2011 Vintage drank young.
Aroma:  Classic wild yeast exciting nose.  Musty nose transitions to savory spices with citrusy orange everpresent.  Also a bit of bubblegum sweetness present for me.
Appearance:  Slight haze with the bottle conditioning.  Pours a muted yellow apricoty color with head that disappears surprisingly fast for a bottle conditioned beer.
Taste:  Nice sweetness present at the start offset by the mustiness.  Orange peel dominates the mid-palate while the beer transitions to a bubble gum and estery finish.  There is also the oaking "vanilla" supporting the alcohol and tampening down some of the rough edges.
Palate:  Nice effervescence present throughout bringing the delicate volatiles to the fore.
Overall:  Surprisingly restrained.  Classic saison with a moderate to restrained yeast character (at least for a belgian).  Extremely enjoyable.

Pours a murky apricot yellow with a head of tightly packed bubbles that quickly dissipate into a thin foam. It’s an appearance that I would normally rate lower but the consistent champagne like effervescence catches the eye... Apricot, caramel, floral, and citrus aromas dominate with notes of herbs, cheese, alcohol, banana, bubblegum, butterscotch, and vanilla. For me the aroma is the high point of this brew.  Tastes way too sour and salty for me with a weird oily finish... First impressions lead to disappointment.

Pale straw yellow/golden pour thin white head little lacing ... aroma of floral hops, fruity yeast and peppery and orange peel .... taste of fruity yeast, peppery, citrusy orange peel, floral and bitter hops with a dry bite in the finish little lively mouthfeel smooths out as it warms sadly I don’t taste any oak not a bad saison

Bottle. Pours hazy orange, thin white head, spotty lacing. Nose is soapy, with peach, light funk, some salt, some bacon, quite pretty. Flavours of spice, citrus, some funk and cheese, very tasty. Solid Saison. Great stuff!
Bottle at Dark Lord Day. Thanks for the share. Light golden yellow with no head. Very floral, fruity with kind of a thick body. Overall very well done. Would like to try again.

Bottle courtesy of Styles. Pours a hazy yellow, with a huge white head. Aroma is peppery, with citrus, and a nice brett character. Body is light & crisp. Flavor is candied fruit, with spices, and a little brett in the finish. Very nice.

Got it from the bottle.  The carbonation was very bright which I liked.  It doesn’t actually say its a Saison (which is typical for Goose Island) but it sure tastes like one.  

It had enough hops that it was clearly American but not over the top like many of the West Coast brews.  It was very versatile and floral.  Definitely a fav.

 It’s really too bad it was purchased by Anheuser-Busch.  Hopefully it will merely effect distribution and price and not quality.

Bomber. Pours a hazy gold color with thin lacing and head around the glass. Smells of lemongrass, citrus and honey. Taste is like a cross of a belgian wheat beer and a saison. Some tart notes as well. Really enjoyable.
On tap at McGregors.  Very clear, somewhat pale, narrow serving glass.  Bubblegum nose.  Banana and fruity palate, somewhat tropical and exotic.  Savored the taste on this one, great stuff.

Bomber bought a year ago at Holiday Wine Cellar ($7.59).  Pours a hazy light yellow-gold hue with big white head.  Aroma of musty grains, fresh lemongrass, citrus peel, flowers, yeast, and a hint of funkiness.  Flavor consists of some tart funk, apple, pear, light citrus, and some pepper.  Dry finish.  Okay saison, and very different from the Brewdog Tokyo* which preceded it.  (492, 520)

Tap at Jimmy’s 43.  The aroma is pepper, lemon, sweet, malty.  The appearance is hazy yellow/orange, white head.  The flavor is fruity/malty/sweet, light pepper.  The finish is sweeter, and light on pepper.  Almost like a beer in reverse, in that it got sweeter and less spicy as it was consumed.  The mouthfeel was creamy, medium in body.  Quite good.

Cloudy gold with a generous frothy head, nice retention and lace. Barnyard-like aromas with hints of citrus and pepper. Pronounced tart taste, almost sour, with tangy orange and lemon accompanied by barnyard yeast and grains. White wine grapes and chewy bread are also apparent. Medium to full body, nice creamy mouthfeel, lively carbonation, and a clean finish.

Pours a super light straw yellow with some haze and two fingers of lacing sticky white head. Nose is very zesty and spicy with notes of lemongrass, white pepper, and a slight funk over a backdrop of dry character and pineapple. Lots of spicy notes and pineapple in the flavor, very dry and zesty with mild earthy notes and some horse blanket. Dry palate and light bodied with a nice carbonation. Very nice.

An excellent saison.  Pours a hazy yellow with a thick, very lively white head.  Aroma is pure saison.  Lots of sour notes, a little hops, and a fresh wheaty undertone.  Taste is sour and citrusy to start, then is finishes dry and hoppy, almost like a Pilsner.  This is certainly my favorite Saison to date.
Pours a hazy pale yellow with a large fluffy white head. Aroma of spices and yeast. Flavor of bubblegum, sour citrus, and hay. Light  and bubbly. Decent.
Sampler at the W&C in Ballwin, Mo.  It poured a hazy yellow with a white head. The aroma was of citrus. The taste was sweet with a little bitterness. Very good!

Bomber served in a tulip. Straw in color with a large fluffy white head that stays a while. Nose of spices, pepper, underripe banana, and soft champagne-like belgian yeast. Orange peel shows up in folds upon reaching the sediment rich bottom. This really enhances the aroma. Slightly tart and sweet flavor. Light-medium body, fizzy carbonation, sticky texture, and a dry, yet creamy finish.

It pours a light cloudy straw with a finger that has poor retention, but does leave a little soapy head. The lacing is decent.

The aroma is what you’d expect. Some light flowers and hops with a little hops.

I don’t like farmhouses in general but the taste is better than most. Its soft and light but has a nice balance of sweet and floral bitterness.
I tasted some spicyness from this one. Very strong yeast and the orange peel is evident.

pure white foam sits upon a golden cloudy pour.  Yeasty nose with tropical fruit - I was expecting maybe a simple trippel.  But I was wrong.  Quite light and tart.  Citrus come through and it a bit drying on the palate.  If this were a bit stronger, I’d rate it higher.
Very light and golden in color with a great head.  Aroma is fresh and citrusy.  The taste is different than anything I’ve ever had.. its tart.  Good one.

Pours to a pale golden body with a ton of sexy visible carbonation and a starch white head.  Lots of gorgeous lacing.  The aroma is spicy hops, orange peel, and peppery yeasts.  The flavor is oranges, hay, spicy hops, clean yeasts, and a light white grape.  The palate is super easy drinking.  It’s quite surprising that the heavy carbonation doesn’t conflict with the beer.  It makes for a velvety texture.  Kind of like a sweet champagne.

[’10 Bottle] Pours clear (until the yeast pour at the bottom) gold with a nice big white head that quickly diminishes to nearly nothing. Aroma is mainly light citrus (lemon) and wheat. Taste is light papaya, a little orange, mild acidity, alcohol, some peppery notes, tannins, and nice underlying wheat. Good, creamy mouthfeel, above average length finish. A bit hot, but overall a nice saison. I really like the level and influence of the wheat.
Tap. Pale gold. Aroma is fruit, light sour. Taste is somewhat sour, fruit, peach, wheat. Pretty good.
This is a nice, light, crisp drinker.  Aroma is full of citrus and spices.  Taste is subtle with orange notes, spices and a great fizz..  It is light in nature and not filling at all.

12 ounce bottle from Beverage Barn Garden City Park in Duvel glass.  Hazy golden orange with white ring.  Fruity orange floral spicy aroma.  Very fruity sweet pineapple orange pineapple syrup vanilla with lingering sweet and spicy orange candy finish.  Medium body.  Too fruity sweet for my tastes.  Certainly doesn’t need extra orange peel in there.  Overwrought.  Decent, but not near the tops in saison (imho).    

Fresher bottle (9/21/13) much better. Something weird in the aroma  BUt nice complex tropical fruits and peppery finish.   From 3.0 to 3.8.

nice presentation here, don’t remember where i got this, probably stole it .. . Pours a light gold, foam is waynes world .. . light hay, bitter funk, lemon, and light wood scraps .. . quite a light mouth, a summer refresher .. . a good brew and another solid offering from Goose Peninsula .. . You idiot! These pictures are of me!
Simple, attractive label.  Big, foaming head.  Light pour.  Very fruity aroma.  A pleasantly sweet Belgian ale.

22 oz. bomber. 2010 vintage. Bottled 02/19/10, bottle 1632.

Pours a hazy golden peach color with a small foamy white head that dissipates quickly. It leaves a little lace but not much.

It has a clean, typical scent for the style. It is definitely in the style of Saison DuPont. It has an abundance of fruitiness atop a slight mustiness form the yeast. It has a farmhouse scent, but not an overpowering one. It is still a young beer though.

The taste follows the nose, but with a heightened fruitiness. It has a lot of lemony tartness. It pretty much is a lemony bread. It tastes like the countryside. There is a bit of banana and clove int he aftertaste. Not much funk in the taste though.

The mouthfeel is a bit over carbonated but it makes for a refreshing beer. This one is supremely drinkable, it is the perfect summer beer.

Overall this is a great one from Goose Island. This is the quintessential flavor I look for in a Saison.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-16-2010 03:14:24



 this is a staple at my work and ive tried it a few times over the years but its gone downhill.
Bottle. Pours hazy gold color. Aroma of citrus, yeast.  Flavor was pineapple, with a kick.  Definitely citrus.  Light and refreshing.  Not too alcoholic.  Great beer.

bottle - Pours lightly hazy gold with a lingering white head.  It smells of citrus, yeast, and some light malts.  The flavor is sweet up front with citrus, spice, and particularly pleasant notes of grapes and oak sneaking in there.  It’s bubbly on the palate and has some dryness in the finish.  I really enjoyed this one.  Excellent saison.
Aroma is Belgian yeast, spices and light lemon.  The flavor is Belgian yeast, spices, lemon and a tart/sweet finish.

Bottle - Pours clear orange-yellow with sediment floating around and a huge fluffy white head. Smell is lightly spicy lemon pepper, yeast, and a citrusy sweetness. Really drinkable, lightly sweet and spicy, with hints of chardonnay, lemon, orange, and oak. Creamy finish, with a bit of alcohol and hop bite. Woudl have liked it to be a little drier, but overall really nice.

pours an opaque pale yellow with a huge foamy white head...very lively looking...nice retention and lacing.  aroma has notable bret...tart, leathery, funky, sour...fresh orange, orange blossom.  flavor is tart at first followed by nice peppery. spicy notes, some funk, and a bit of orange blossom...not as sour as the aroma suggests unfortunately but still tasty.  mouthfeel is super lively...light and crisp with a very dry finish reminiscent of a dry white wine.

Draft. Pours gold with a white head. Sweetish aroma with saison-yeast, spices, and a light funky note. The flavor is well balanced with sweet and spicy notes, some lemony funk, and light notes of anise seed. Very good.

Pour started out clear golden which clouded as the yeast entered from the bottlom of the bottle.  Huge pillowy white head and pretty good lacing.  Fruity and spicy aroma.  Flavor was sweet fruit and yeastiness with some slight barnyard funk.  Dry yet rich mouthfeel.  Very good beer that avoids the common "too sweet" shortcoming of many US efforts at this style.  I liked it.

2009 Vintage.  Pours a slightly hazy golden yellow with a generous white head. It produces a wonderful aroma. Dominated by that familiar wheaty/spicy belgina yeast. Also some orange peel aromas as well as a sweet white wine such as a riesling.. It’s aroma leads you to the complex flavor. At first a tart, citrusy flavor, and follows with some sweeter oaky, vanilla flavors. Drinks very much like a wine. Light to medium body with fizzy carbonation and snappy finish. Not my preferred style but a pretty good Saison in my opinion.
Pours a hazy yellow color with a thin layer of foam.  Vanilla in the aroma.  The flavor is light with a slight clove aftertaste.
Disappointed.  Not my taste, I tried 2 sips.  Very fruity, champagne like citric.  Nowhere close to drinkable for me.  Dumped down the drain.

2010 bottle from EricAndersNavy, thanks! Pale blonde, hazy. Oaky aroma with orange peel and leathery notes. Initial mal, yet very dry. A soft oak character with leather and orange peel. Anis. Brett even. Delicious with some complexity.

When I tasted this for the first - and second time I wasn’t sure but I thought it was possibly a Belgium Strong Ale. I would never thought it was a saison. I’m not a big fan of saison but this is really delicious. I usually find a bit of a grassy  taste almost like a wheat beer but this is great.  Crisp slightly malty  noticable hops. A really nice beer
22 oz. bomber.  Poured a light orangish color with a white head.   Crisp and refreshing.  Very drinkable.  not as tart as I would prefer but all around a nice belgian style beer.

bottled. pours light golden color with a large tight white head. aromas of citrus, grass and hay. moderately sour and fizzy with a load of carbonation. it is light bodied with a lasting finish of citrus and yeast. only complaint is an odd flavor i can’t place after the flavors wear off the tongue. decent, but not great.
Nice stuff but slightly unusual. A little sour and a little spicy. Almost a dryness to the taste. Serving: Bottle
A nice golden pour with a thin white head. Smell of yeast, a little citrus, maybe banana? Good flavor of yeast, banana, and spices. Smooth finish, really nice saison! Would definitely drink again!

Wow recent ratings for this are all over the place. It is a pretty drinkable refreshing saison but nothing to warrant the rating swill crap. Pours a cloudy yellow. Grassy herbal earthiness running through the whole thing like fresh cut grass on a spring day. Not sure if it is appropriate for the freezing ass weather going on outside but who’s watching. A funky musty sort of aroma. Pretty effervescent texture and mouth feel as well. Pretty entertaining beer her and a pretty entertaining example of this style. Getting a little more complex and interesting than what I am used to.
a white golden cloudy mess of a beer that is yeasty and wheaty. flavor of wheat and coriander and funky like infected wheat, but sweet. brought to you by the dirty lines @ r& h nyc.

Sampled at the Black Hills Beer Fest.  Hazy yellow color.  Very unique taste but all in all it was nothing special.  I’m glad I didn’t piss any money away for a bottle of this.  Has nothing on the bourbon stout.

Very hazy golden pour, lots of yeast in suspension, large fluffy white head, good retention. Aroma is pear, floral, champagne, butterscotch comes out as the beer warms. Medium light body, brief tingly carbonation, sweet up front that slowly fades to a mildly dry finish. Good one!

Since we did not want to pay the cover at Lovin cup, we were only allowed to stay for one beer. We then went to McGreg’s were I found this one I never had before. Bottle. Pours a hazy yellow beer with a large white head. The aroma is malt, fruit and yeast. The flavor is malt, fruit, yeast and some  sweetness. The palate is sweet. The distinctly Euro aftertaste I did not enjoy.
Very light in yellow/gold pour. Yeasty and very light and refreshing. Lemon zest in the aroma. Flavor is clove, banana, a bit sour.  Almost a champagne flavor and palate. Great as a sipping beer.

22 oz. bottle from Woodman’s in Madison, WI (bottled June 18, 2010).  Pours pale yellow to light orange with a bubbly champagne-like head.  Aroma of orange zest, peppercorns, and pinot grigio.  Wonderfully refreshing flavor with citrus at the forefront but with funky and spicy notes on the finish and just enough sweetness to balance it all out.  Exactly what a saison should be.

Bottled 23/04/2010. Bottle bought in Dublin, Ireland. Appearance: Absolutley beautiful hazy orange, literally vibrating with carbonation with a gorgeous thick snow white head. One of the most beautiful beers I have ever seen. Aroma: Delicious yeast, farmhouse, sour, lemon rind, just delicious. Flavour: A nice sourness at first, lemon, orange, lots of yeast, a little mustyness, wonderful carbonation on the tongue with short yeasty finish. Simply lovely.

(bottled 4-23-10) Pours a very hazy light yellow with a medium white head that soon subsides to a thin cap that leaves splotchy lacing.  Aroma of pineapple (brett), must, grass clippings, lemon zest, toasted fennel seed, and orange creamsicle along with a floral character as well.  Really great to smell.  The taste has plenty of cracker, honeydew melon, orange, and baked bread with some pepper showing up right before the finish.  The finish is very dry and earthy (mushroom?), and it actually comes to resemble white wine as it warms.  Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation is very lively and effervescent.  Overall, this is a well-crafted saison that is not overwhelmed with spice.

Bottle. Pours cloudy yellow/gold, with a white head. Aroma is citrus yeast, pepper, and a touch of vanilla. Flavor is oranges, yeast, spices, white wine, and vanilla. Ends slightly sweet. Very nice, I like this one a lot.

Pours a cloudy gold with a nice white head. More hoppy than I would expect from a Belgian style beer but overall nice flavor. 

12oz botle

Poured into a tulip.

4.5 A: Nearly clear golden straw color. Two and a half fingers of creamy/pillowy white head that retains excellently and leaves tons of pillowy lacing.

4.0 S: Good amount of barnyard straw funkiness. Lemony citrus. Some clove and a pleasant yeasty spiciness. Good aroma overall, but could be more pronounced.

3.5 T: Not as fruity in the taste. Actually, it’s a dry fruitiness if that makes any sense centered around lemon. Unmalted wheat is one of the more pronounced flavors. Straw funkiness again, but not as much as in the nose. Pleasant yeastiness with pepper and a touch of clove. Decently bitter.

3.0 M: Light body. Too light actually, even for a saison and thus could be a bit creamier. Carbonation is very spritzy, but fine.

3.5 D: Good brew. I like a good brett’d beer every once in a while and this one didn’t disappoint.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-19-2009 03:47:43

4oz sample @ Rattle N Hum, New York



Fruity, sour, a bit sweet, proper Belgian styled saison. Pours light yellow, clear. Palate isn’t that great.
Hazy golden color in the glass. Spicy yeast aroma. Smooth mouthfeel, good wild yeast character. Nice to see someone putting effort into a relatively uncommon style.

750ml bottle. Very light in color. Yellow gold with a finger sized foam head. Yeasty and very light. Somewhat of a lemon zest in the aroma and flavor. Does have somewhat of a champagne type flavor to it, made for a nice enjoyable, sipping beer.
Deep golden pour with a white head. Aroma is funky, spicy, earthy and tart. Flavor is tart , funky and fruity.. Nice tingly carbonation. A nice brew.

Pours a turbid blonde, head is thick lacy and lasts a fairly long time.  I am partial to dark looking beers, but this is a very pretty pour.  Aroma is that of orange juice, orange peel, and yeast.  Tastes of mostly orange, light malts, and nutmeg with a hint of bittering hops.  The mouthfeel is nice, thick, good carbonation, definitely adds to the beer.  This is a very nice light belgian and I would definitely buy again.

The color is an absolutely gorgeous cloudy gold. I mean really beautiful, almost-jizzed-my-past-while-pouring-it beautiful. Of course, unlike women (or maybe not...), appearance counts for little in comparison to taste and smell. The aroma entices, very sweet, very floral although spruce and caramel also come to mind. With a pleasant but overly potent presence of alcohol, the aftertaste satisfies.

From a 65cl bottle.  Pours a yellow color with a small white head.  Drank half one day and the rest a couple of days later and amazingly the taste, smell, and even carbonation was the same.  Very sharp and crisp.  Flavor is spicy, coriander, lemon, with just a touch of fruit sweetness.
Bottle. Hazy pour with some white head. Citrus and spice aroma with a touch of leather. Fruit, spice and funk flavor are smoother possibly due to barreling.   Belgian like notes are memorable.

Hazy gold with several inches of brilliant white souffle head. Aroma is spicy with peary esters.  Taste is light, dry and bretty, with mild sweetness and pear and citrus into the finish.  Vigorously carbonated. $4/12oz

A nice saison that pours the typical color of the style and creates a huge, foamy, white head.  The nose suggests a sourness that is never fully realized, as the taste only presents a very subtle sour twang.  Otherwise, there’s a bit orange peel, subtle cloves, and just a bit of hops.  Very nice beer.

12 oz bottle.  2010 vintage.  Pours a cloudy yellow with a large amount of soapy white head with good retention.  Aroma has some coriander, yeast, lemon, orange, and some hops.  There is definitely some funkiness to the aroma.  Flavor has some sweetness to it mixed with a hint of lemon and orange peel.  There is some definitely some spiciness with the coriander in the flavor.  The finish is really interesting.  It is indeed creamy and dry.  The creaminess is really unexpected from the first taste, which makes this a fun drink.  The back of the palate, is really funky, but not necessarily in a bad way.  It’s pretty much a transition from spice to pure funk.  The beer is medium bodied with marginal carbonation.  The first sip of this beer was really jolting, but the more I drank, the more I liked the finish and the more I admired its complexity.  I will definitely seek these out again when I see them.
Straw yellow in color with plenty of sediment... Citrus aroma... Flavor is belgian yeast, citrus... Slightly yeasty finish... Pretty good.

pours a thick white head, fruit like aroma i associate with belgian ales, but very strong at first, then mellows down to a light citrus aroma, slightly cloudy blonde appearance, fruit like flavor, very sweet, a good beer overall
Pours a very fizzy yellow with lots of small white bubbles. Smells and tastes just how a Belgian saison should.

Enjoyed from a 16.9oz bottle in an English pint glass.  The beer pours a fairly clear yellow color, with a large white head.  The nose shows notes of citrus, peppery spices, and a slight farmhouse funk, more brettanomyces than other souring agents.  The palate is lightly tart, citrusy, spicy, and highly effervescent.  The latter adds further dryness to what is already a bone dry finish, and cleanses the palate.  The finish is nicely crisp, allowing the beer to be highly quaffable.  Overall, absolutely excellent.

Bottle. Poured into a chalice a slightly hazy straw yellow color with a nice fluffy white head. Nice lace as the head settles. The aroma is that of straw, lemon, grass, orange, and very mild barnyard. The mouthfeel is light and refreshing. The citrus really come out in the flavor and are nice followed with some mild bitterness. Some floral type flavors as well. Nice wine like notes as well. A very solid, slightly wild beer that is pleasant to drink.

12 oz bottle. Pours a hazy, bright golden yellow color with lots of bubbly effervescence that gathers at the surface into a small off white head. Some soapy drips of lace slides down the glass. The aroma is nice and complex showing notes of lemon, orange peel, coriander, and spicy pepper atop the base of candied pale malts. There is a hint of mild brett to go with the dry, Belgian yeast profile and some balancing hop bitterness on the back end. The flavor follows and is even better than the nose suggest with the citrus fruits, spicy pepper, and lemon grass up front followed by some creamy oak laden vanilla and touch of bretty funk. Medium bodied, dry with prickly carbonation with a nice dry, bitter finish from the grassy hops. Great brew and perfect for the hot summer time. Really nice saison.

Huge head a little soapy looking, shiny, golden slightly hazy... Some fruits, apple light aromas, tart, sour aroma, belgian yeasts come through.... Dry finish, quite a bit yeasty in the finish, not overly sour/tart though some barnyard/funk does come through nicely, just enough..,. kind of has a duvel meets orval feel to it...

bomber.  Pours a light lemon gold color, cloudy, with fizzy white head.  Aroma is tart and peppery, sour citrus, cherry and currant, floral pepper notes, but also with a sweetness present, vanilla pudding.  Medium bodied, medium to high carbonation, dry, definitely has a champagne like feel.  Flavor is cloying, a mix of tart citrus notes and light floral notes, with a finish that is at first somewhat vanilla sweet but ultimately evolves to a lingering tartness.  This is a nice saison and was clearly crafted by a great brewer.
Bottle.  Clear yellow effervescent pour and a spicy, light orange aroma.  Flavor is bitter orange, grass, spicy white pepper and a nice wine aftertaste.  Really well done!
Pours a hazy marigold color with small white head.  Smells of yeast, pepper, and citrus.  tastes of orange peel, spice, green grapes, yeast and wine.  lively carbonation and very refreshing.

A: Light gold with a tremendous bone white head and a stunning amount of lacing. 

S: A bit of yeasty funk over a slight peppery aroma. Mild hops underneath, though they don’t challenge the yeast character. Also, some white wine characteristics--green grapes and a bit of sweet, tart fruits. 

T: Little bit of funk combined with some pepper flavors. Much the same as the nose, but the taste has more distinctive fruity characteristics with the green grapes/apple coming through over the top of the pepper. 

M: Fairly light with a good bite of carbonation. Not much of an alcohol presence.

D: Quite refreshing. Nothing too complex going on here, but quite a good and refreshing saison nonetheless.

Serving type: bottle

Wonderfully light, yet complex beer.  Orange peel, bubblegum, oak, almost chardonnay in the nose.  All the same goes into the taste on top of a wonderful tinge of sour from the yeast and some bitter from the orange peel.  Such a tasty ale.

22 oz. brown bottle with a classy label. A cloudy glowing golden yellow with a nice billowing head. The aroma has citrus and is kind of funky almost like sweat but in a good way which makes me wonder if there is Brett in here. The taste is refreshing and sparkly, clean, very smooth. You know this is an easy drinking beer and would be nice to have on tap specifically for your house. This is another good beer that surprised me in a weekend of good beers that surprised me.

Pours a golden amber with a nice head. Smells of yeast, orange, bubblegum and a funky spice aroma I can’t put my finger on.  Medium mouthfeel with a dry yeasty barnyard palate that does remind me of a dry champagne. Follows up with a mild pepper bitter that works in to a bitter orange peel note. Not bad at all with easy drinkability. Great summer beer.

22 oz bottle. Pours pale yellow with large foamy head. Highly carbonated...latter pours create a dance of bubbles and sediment. Yeasty aroma with hints of citrus. Very dry in the mouth with a not-so-subtle taste of wine/alcohol.  Very drinkable.

[Tap] Pours a very pale yellow color with no head. Fizzy carbonation made this beer look more like a sparkling wine. Aroma of champagne yeasts, apples and tart grapes. Tastes a bit like a cider, with apple and light spices throughout. Barnyard notes are light and come out primarily in the finish. Highly carbonated and solid body. An interesting brew, but not really my style.

Bottle. Moderate aromas all around, with light bread and grain for the malt, lemon and herbs for the hops, musty for the yeast, with hints of white win, berry, sour apple and wood in the background. Head is huge, frothy/rocky, white with good crispy lacing and is fully lasting. Color is clear gold, but hazes up on the last pour. Flavor starts lightly sweet and acidic, then finishes faintly sweet and acidic and lightly to moderately bitter. Palate is light to medium, watery with a lively carbonation. A nice lively aroma, but a little light in the flavor, this is still a very good Saison.

bomber shared by jsprime. bottled oct 23 2009. pale gold with a lasting white head. minimal aroma, some light malts, some bret, some sourness. the flavour is pretty much the same. light and playful. would drink well in the summer.

On tap at the brewpub in Chicago. Hazy pale yellow. Aroma is perfumey lychee, gooseberry, with acetic undertones. Lightly yeasty and tart, with lovely lychee and berry fruit, soft subtle spices. Absolutely fantastic!

650 mL bottle.  Hazy yellow-gold with a nice white head.  Appealing aroma has dried orange and apple skins, wild yeast, and a little graininess.  Theflavour is fairly subtle, with neutral/tart citrus, wheat malt, and a hint of wood.  Quite dry, but no metallic notes.  Highly carbonated.  A well constructed beer, but one which doesn’t greatly appeal to me.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: Poured as a glowing yellow hue with a tint of white and a minimum amount of haze sediment floating about.  Tiny formation of head while the aroma holds a zesty dosage of spiced yeast in a typical Belgian fashion. The flavor is close to the aroma with a strong serving of zesty yeast with dashes of spice such as clove and coriander and a noticeable orange peel that taste more authentic then some other saisons being made in the USA. This reminded me to appreciate the saison style because lately I had tasted some boring ones that made me want to steer away from them.

Brewed in the USA !!! Courtesy of AFI96..Thanks Waylo. Pours a hazy yellow color with a very small white head. Aroma of sour white grapes, lemon peels and some barnyard funk. Taste is also kind of funky with some mild spices, wheat, yeast and cloves. Mouthfeel has a slight bite on the tongue when you first sip this saison yet it doesn’t  finish in the same manner.

22oz bottle, dated 1/29/10, courtesy of daknole. thanks, dak! pours a beautiful, pale yellow-gold with a thick, bubbly, bright white head leaving a tight ring of lace. aroma is fantastic with sweet fruit notes of pear, green apple, kiwi, and tangerine backed by floral white wine, oak, and belgian yeast with a perfect blend of white pepper, coriander, and clove and just a touch of lemon grass and funky, wild brett. flavor is delicious as well with the smooth notes of oak, vanilla, and white wine coming to the forefront ahead of the fruit notes of orange peel, berry, and apricot with a blend of cinnamon, clove, and sage adding a unique spice element just before the slightly tart, dry, funky finish. palate is medium bodied with dense carbonation making it almost creamy on the palate with a dry, herbal finish. overall, an absolutely wonderful saison and definitely a pleasant surprise.
Bottle. Clear pale gold with a thin head. Aroma of corianger, nectarine, and musk. Spicy and complex flavor with fruit, nectarine and peach, and lots of spice. Very drinkable. Smooth, full bodied.

Pours a fizzy, white head that laces with a body that is golden and clear (top pour).  Aromas of green apples, citrus, and yeast.  Flavor is yeast, green apple, some clove and banana notes, spicy.  Finish is dry and clean.  Drinkable body.

Appearance: Pours a pastel yellow with a thin white film.



Aroma: Orange zest, spicy yeast, pronounced barrel notes and a little bit of sugar.



Taste: Orange peel, lemon, spicy yeast, barrel, candi sugar and a spicy kiss of hops.



Mouthfeel: Full bodied with prickly carbonation.



Overall: I found this beer to be just awesome. Super balanced, bold and tasty. Very inviting.
Bottled. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is fruits, some earth, mild spices and dishwater. Flavour is rather much the same.  Quite thin and not all that exciting.

Bottle.

A - Nice crisp, golden color with a fairly large, foamy, light fluffy, pearly white head. Great retention that finally settles into a nice foamy layer of lace.

S - Wonderful juicy golden fruit is strongest with lots of pear, apple, golden raisin, lemon and some other citrus. Grassy (especially lemon grass) along with hay. Some barnyard saison and wild yeast and funky aroma. Touch of a white wine and spice. Very complex and enjoyable.

T - Taste is also very complex. Plenty of fruitiness that mirrors the nose. Mid-sip, it definitely has a white wine type of flavor, although it isn’t particularly vinous. A nice woody flavor with a good dose of vanilla also comes out to support that wine flavor. Has an underlying funk that is a great compliment to the other flavors and doesn’t overtake them. There is always a strong underlying orange/lemon rind and lemon grass citrusy flavor, but toward the finish it comes out particularly strong along with a nice spiciness featuring white pepper, clove, coriander, and a hint of cumin amongst other spices.

M - Medium body with a bit above average carbonation. A zesty, active feel with a drying finish. Very champagne/sparkling wine like feel that accompanies the white wine taste well.

D - Complex but balanced beer that is a delight to sip. Nothing overpowers the other flavors, and the body is great. A little strong for the palate to want another right away, especially compared to some other saisons I’ve had, but I had no trouble finishing the bottle.

Notes: Very nice and enjoyable beer. Complex and balanced drink that had some nice funky/barnyard aspects of a saison, but it had some other flavor aspects that were similar to a Chardonnay, a biere de garde, and some BSPA aspects as well. It definitely had a nice Belgian flavor though. Funk, fruitiness, grassiness, grape, and sweetness all present. And that woody/vanilla flavor just steps it up more. Definitely worth a try and is a great beer.

Poured on tap at Dexters in Madison, WI, pours a clear golden color with a thin white head and slight lacing, the aroma is fruity with a hint of booze in the nose, the flavor is nicely balanced with malt and fruit, it even has a touch of sourness in the finish, pretty enjoyable.

22 ounce bottle(2010 edition) pours an effervescent, hazy, yellow gold body with a large and delicate white head. Good retention and some sheet lacing. Aroma is funky and yeasty, with fruity honeydew melon, white grape skins, kiwi, orange peel, lemon, and some herbal hops. Dry and silky on the palate with a champagne like carbonation. Taste nirrors aroma. Funky wild yeast character is apparent but could use more time to develop. Subtle barnyard, kiwi, white grape skins, orange peel,  and lemon, with some dry bitterness from herbal hops. Would love to have a few bottles to age to see if some time gives it some more pastoral character. Very nicely done.
Dark yellow pour.  Sweet, citrusy aroma.  Refreshing palate, yet medium hop content.

Bottled 02/19/2010. Purchased from some dive store in San Diego Mission Bay. Colour: White-yellow with cloud. Nose: Young berries, lively yeast, dopple of perfume, glue. Taste: Mmmm...berries again, but more ripe...and red grapes perhaps? Medium bitter middle with grapefruit. Late surge oak mixed with yeast. Pretty solid stuff.

2010 bottle:  poured a light golden color with a big fluffy white head that retained a half inch. Lots of floating spice and sediment in the glass. aroma has light spice, orange peel, and a nice bright citrus. Smells much like a Belgian Wit beer. Mouth feel is light and crisp with high side carbonation. Taste has banana yeast, citrus and pepper spice with maybe vanilla?  Would I buy again?  Yes, I’m geting two more bottles to put in the cellar.

Pours a golden yellow, with a thick, forthy white head. Aroma is very fruity, especially banana and oranges. Very fuity taste to this one, which had some ctirus and hoppy feel to it. Very nice feel to the mouth, has a nice bitter finish to it.

[bottle]
Pineapple and sour banana aroma with some honey and a woody character. Hazy yellow under a thick, white ring that laced the glass. Tropical fruit flaovur with a woody bitterness and a touch of horseblanket and white grape. The woody bitterness transcends the whole tasting experience and is a nice counterpoint to the horseblanket. Light body, medium carbonation, woody bitter finish.
Poors a golden hue with a medium sized head.  Very carbonated up front like champagne.  A tart flavor is noted that is not overpowering.  Clean finish.

On tap at Anchor Bar in Wichita. Pours hazy yellow-gold with small white head. Aromas of orange, a bit of tartness, yeast, and a bit of the barrel. Flavors of light spices, orange, lemon, yeast, bit of tartness, a bit of vanilla, and some wet wood.  Very tasty brew and a hell of an american saison. Very proud that this brew came out of Chicago.
Hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma of exotic fruits and brett funk. Sweet and fruity flavour with peach and spices

Big bottle pour is effervescent, releasing lots of fluffy white head.  Body is a nice golden yellow.  Aroma is citrus and yeast, very natural.  Mouthfeel is crisp, perfect carbonation level.  Flavor is very citrus intensive with some tartness and light finishing bitterness.

As I sit and drink this beer it seems to be getting better and better.  That, to me, is the mark of a quality brew.

12oz 2010 btl. Great color on this a nice crisp golden slightly hazy with a foamy white head. Refreshing citris aroma. Nice fresh bottle a bit spicy, a bit hoppy, and a bit citric. Awesome balance. Looks great tastes great.

2010 bottle poured a light golden color with a big fluffy white head that retained a half inch. aroma has earthy yeast, light spice, wet orange peel, and a nice bright citrus. mouth feel is light and crisp with high side carbonation. flavor has banana yeast, green apple, light citrus, mellow spice, orange, and a mild barrel wood thing. nice and crisp and has a lot of saison character but there is a slight funky dry twist thrown in.

Blond and effervescent with a fluffy white head. Nice white pepper spicy zip to the nose. Fairly clean yeastiness, with piquant white pepper and a delicate ripple of orange and a small wave a pinot grigio. Refreshing, piquant, balanced, crisp, and altogether enjoyable.

On draft @ ChurchKey in DC.  Hazy golden pour, small white head.  Aroma was an array of some citrus, sour fruitiness, and maybe a touch of wood.  Nothing overpowering.  Flavors were somewhat traditional saison flavors.  Some sourness, big fruitiness, very crisp and refreshing.  Smooth finish with a light bitterness, somewhat vinous and a bit of heat.  Easily one of my favorite saisons that I have tried.

2009 Bottle:  Pours a bright straw color with a light haze and a finger of bubbly white head.  Fruity aroma is green apples, yeast, vinous fruits, and something that reminds me of raspberry jam.  In the flavor I can really pick up the orange peel and hints of pepper, along with the yeast.  It has a dry, vinous note that blends well with the pepper and keeps it from being too fruity.  Crisp.  Enjoyable.

I’d look at this as part Saison, part sour in character.  The wine and orange peel give it a good bit of sour feel.  Nose and body are that of a Saison though.  Looks of like bitter/soul flavor.  Very carbonated, maybe a little too much, but that’s normal for this kind of beer.  Definitely worth a shot, and has a unique flavor.
Bottle as part of a mix a six.  Aroma is raison, vanilla, bread and citrus notes.  Its very bubbly, like a mild champaigne.  Delicious all the way around/

Bottle: Pours a Light Cloudy Golden into a tulip. After having the dupont, it’s well. not quite as good for me. You get that slight funk in the aroma, with a bit of spices. Flavors are spiciness, funk, hay, citrus, oranges, and .... i dunno. It’s interesting for certain. I can’t say I get the "vanilla finish", but it’s fairly smooth, for sure. Nice brew

Bottle: Pours a golden yellow color with a very large fluffy white head. The nose is tart and bright with acidic orange and coriander notes. The yeast is there, but it’s covered up by all the fresh yeasts, the light earthy hops and spicy esters. Light effervescent body and a refreshing finish. Nice to see something created authentically locally.

I love saisons. And I REALLY loved this one! Goose Island has never really impressed me with their Belgian styles before. Don’t get me wrong, I liked them all, but this stands out. hay, bread, caramel, dough, banana, raisin, vanilla, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, golden, Awesome!

Pours from 22 oz into tulip glass.  Lots of carbonation, and hence, a nice white head on top of the golden brew.  Very bubbly, but that fades.  Aromas of orange, clove, and spice.  Fairly thin on the palate, but true to the saison style.  Nice funkiness in the wild yeasts too....leaves a nice finish.  Very nice brew for summer

Rating is for the 2009. Pours a slightly hazy yellow with a good sized foamy head that lasts. Aroma is very nice. Tart tangy fruits, some hop like a summer breeze across a field of hay and a little white pepper and creamy vanilla. Mouthfeel has just the right tang and zip with an underlying creaminess hinted at.  Taste is orange zest and mildly bitter fruitiness, straw and vanilla. My favorite American saison.

Rich golden color; nutty and spicy aroma with substantial sweet maltiness. Fairly cleanly malty and sweet flavor, lightly soapy and herbal. Lightly bitter finish with some effervescent banana notes; well integrated. Towards the sweet and less spicy side for saisons.
12 oz bottle at Blind Tiger. Hazy yellow pour. Tart tangy pepper lemony aroma. Light tart body with hints of fruit and pepper spiciness. Delicious.
Bottle at ChrisO "I’m Trying to see the Stool" pre GBBF2010 tasting. Cloudy pale gold.  Decent wit.  Some soap.  OK lemon.  Zesty.  Still it is too soapy.

Clear yellow, full white head, dissipates quickly, light lacing.  Strong sour aroma, barnyard and floral.  Tastes great, mild malt sweetness and floral sour bite, bitterness on the finish.  Light body and high carbonation.

From the Bottle at Chris O’s pre GBBF tasting, Kensal Rise 31/07/2010 (2009 Version)
Fruity aroma. Silver coloured and hazy in appearance. Fruity with a hint of dryness and spiced flavour in a floral and bitter finish.

A Mes rate. Bottle thanks to Ang.
Hazy yellow with a big frothy white head and lots of suspended particles. Nice yeasty nose with some pleasant fruit and obvious orange and barrel. Drinks like a sour weiss. Really well balanced, the orange and barrel show through really well but are not at all over powering. The wine notes add plenty of complexity and the overall impression is that of a very well crafted and balanced brew. Like it.
Bottle. Pours a hazy yellow beer with a large white head. The aroma is malt, fruit and yeast. The flavor is malt, fruit, yeast, sweetness and brett. The palate is sweet. Overall a good fruity beer.

Huge head on this beer.  Just nice drinking and well done.  The nose is very, very mild and the appearance is pale gold and cloudy.  The taste is just solid and light and fruity.  No specirfic taste to me just a very well structured belgian.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from State Line Liquors. 

Aroma:  The nose full of spicy Belgian yeast notes.  Clove, light lemongrass, and fresh cut grass in there too.  Good stuff!

Appearance: It pours a cloudy, orange gold with a huge, foamy, white head.    This is one active brew.  Great head retention and spotty lacing left behind. 

Taste: Light and spicy with Belgian yeast really coming through.  A bit of anise, clove, citrus peel, a peppery note, and lots of floral hops.  Perfect for a hot day. 

Palate: Light in body with above average carbonation and a slightly dry, floral finish.  

Overall: A very nice brew indeed and certainly worth trying  

Score: 8.4.8.3.15

12 oz, capped bottle, fresh 2010 bottle: hazed lemon-straw body below a creamy, ivory head that slowly dies into a wisps and collects at the edges.  Light, airy orange rind aroma that has a wonderfully subtle, while at the same time striking floral, honeydew melon and sourdough starter presence.  Tingly pepper on the tip of the tongue that becomes gentle though the mouth before a second citrus hop resin and pepper finish mixes with a fruity sourness catches your attention.  Another wonderful belgian style ale from the folks up in Chicago!  Thanks Nit!

Had this on tap at the 2010 Oregon Brewer’s Festival. Colour... golden straw with a thick head. Nose... acetic, yet fruity. Palate... lightly sweet, with quince, pear and lime zest and a delightfully long finish.
2009 bottle at ChrisO’s "Raise the Roof" tasting, 31st July 2010. Hazy very light yellow. Light citric nose. Delicate beer, pretty decent.

Bottle at Empty Bottle.  Hazy, yellow orange color.  Pronounced floral barley and sugary Belgian yeast aroma.  Yeasty and rich, a well executed beer.  Creamy, with some slight alcohol warning in the finish.  Excellent.
Big soft white head. Sweet fruity aroma, with flavor of raspberry, green apple and yeast. Smooth and very drinkable.

Bottle @ Chriso’s pre-GBBF ’Raise the Roof’ Tasting ’10. Light, golden yellow coloured body with some haze and a dense and frothy white head. Herbs & spices, some creamy vanilla and sharpish citrus aromas. Quite bright on lemony with estery yeast, pepper and wheat and a touch of pithy orange. Some light carbonation sting, light in body with a relatively short estery Belgian bitterness in the finish.

On tap pre-GTMW


I have a bottle of this in the cellar at home but free trumps having to take a risk any day. Now that I know what I will discover it might get opened this month. An excellent saison the result of Goose Island’s work is a fine summery beer that helps beat the heat. If it has a weakness that would be the champagne like aspects. Because of the carbonation this would take some time to work through.



Aroma / Appearance - Golden blond and crisp the head formed a white halo around the edges of the glass. Lemon pledge, citrus, and orange glo give it a warm nature. Overall it kind of smells like a corn field after a heavy rain with the sun shining through partly cloudy skies.



Flavor / Palate - Orange zest, lemon peels, and a minor tartness perform their jobs well. The peppery kick is so subtle that it does not sneak up until the very end. The carbonation in the mouthfeel can be a little much. Overall I would have paid $4 for a pint of this and not been let down by the result. Once again Goose Island proves they can play with the big dogs and hold their own.
Not a fan of Saisons at this point.  So maybe my rating is biased.  Its a beer of strong characer and spicieness, Im just not a fan of the flavor.
A nice golden-yellow pour. A light aroma of citrus and lemon. Smooth texture with a light body. The finish is clean and slightly tart. Some fruit juice characteristics.
Awesome golden color with a head that will not quit. Took me forever just to pour it. Some fingernail polish notes, orange peel, cloves, and maybe even some hoppiness in the back. A good beer.

12 oz bottle shared by willblake. Poured a golden body with a hazy bright white medium fluffy head. Aroma of yeast, hint of mint, corriander, bubble gum and tropical fruit. Medium mouth feel with average carbonation. Flavors of yeast, grains, rotting oranges, grass and a touch of earth.

Tricked. With all the wheat in this I thought it was a Belgian wit with fruit. Cloudy yellow appearance. Some wheat up front; a bit of fruit later, fairly wheaty. Quite zesty and light, almost fizzy.  Good but not worth $9 to me.

Draft at the Stable. A hazy pale in the glass with a creamy white head that left light lace. Sweet aroma of fruit, spice and black licorice. The flavor found fruit and spice. Medium body. Update - 2011 Bottle (BD 09/15/11). Poured golden with a white head. Aroma of fruit, spice, and a light yeast back. The flavor found fruit, citrus hop, and a light spice back. Light to medium body, slightly tart, and a yeasty aftertaste.

Bomber brought over to Leems’ house by our friend CRK. Hazy yellow colored with a thin, bone white head. Aroma was bits of yeast and citrus fruits, particularly lemons. Perhaps a little orange and pear thrown in there as well. This beer tasted very sweet, lots of citrus fruits, roses, light bit of earthiness and some definite pepper notes at the finish. Unique tasting brew, and quite tasty.
Pours cloudy yellow with a white head. Aroma is malt, yeast, fruit, marcipan and light brett. Flavour is malt, brett, marcipan, fruity and alcohol.

bottle: golden orange pour, grassy, spicey arouma. Velvety soft and smooth body, funky with a touch of tart with sharp carbonation. Touch of lemon and flowers, nectar honey. Yeasty, light caramel and cracker malts, peppery finish. Lovely spice.

22oz Bottle. Pours clear honeyed golden/straw in colour. Later cloudy as I added the sediment. Bright white reasonably dense head which persists more than I would have imagined. Aroma is classic belgian blonde/saison/wheat beer-ish. Lots of lemon citrus, lots of lemon peel and obviously orange peel. Spices, yeast, and bread in the back ground, also a slight sulphurous/farmyard character, wet hay and so on. Classic aromas a plenty, basically. Flavour is more of the same, citrus is the flavour of the day, with loads of lemon and orange, fruit peel, not as tart as I would have expected - but this is good, I think. Nice use of balance between sweet and sharp. Lots of bready yeast and malt to balance. Reminds me of a tart lemon drizzle cake. Slight lemon sherbet quality to it in the mids and into the finish. Some sharp Lemon meringue as well. Very refreshing. I know only 20% of the beer used was aged in barrels, but still there is little, if any oak flavour imparted into the beer... I don’t know if this is a good or bad thing. On the one hand, showing no oak, basically makes this a very well made Belgian beer out of the US, but this makes me think it’s essentially a bit over priced for what it is. On the other hand, would an overly woody element done the brew any favours, perhaps not, though arguably there is the faintest touch of vanilla sweetness, which I suppose is the oak, but this is very subtle, so the debate still stands, is this a very well made, but somewaht overpriced Belgian/US beer, or does it deserve the price as a pint of solid beer? Mouthfeel is spot on, better than most Belgians could have pulled off. What’s scary about this brew, is that it would appear that the Americans are now producing Belgian beer better than the Belgians themselves. Kudos to Goose Island.
Notes of fruity esters, citrus, spicyness.  Taste is spot on it has just the right amount of sourness. Full bodied yet easy drinking, crisp, and refreshing.

Bottle pour to Trappist glass. Clear yellow color with foamy white persistent head.  Aroma citrus, light fruits and spice.  Taste matches with citrus, Belgian yeast, spices, sweet malt.  Finish tangy and abrupt but very pleasant.  Palate carbonated, smooth.  Alcohol not apparent.

Nice saison, just a hair behind Hennepin for US saisons but very good.
Light golden color.  Aroma is full of coriander and cloves.  Flavor is full of spices.  I can taste a bunch of coriander in the finish.  Definitely a good Belgium.

On tap at Cole’s in Buffalo, NY, drank with Ender from TBS.  Very enjoyable beer.  I couldn’t distinguish the citrus notes, but he made sure to let me know that they brewed it with a ton of orange peel.  I got a distinct pepper finish - definitely spicy finish.

Pours a light straw yellow with hazy floaties and a fizzy white head.  Aroma is intense citrus and orange.  Taste is a flash of citrus and a light body.  Very carbonated.  Slightly peppery in the aftertaste which is really nice finish.
Happy father’s day to me.  I have to be honest, I didn’t take good notes so here’s the memory.  Golden color with not much head.  Nice fruit smell and a decent taste but, nothing overly special.

12 ounce bottle from Siciliano’s in Grand Rapids. 2010 vintage. Pours a hazy lemon yellow color with a large frothy white head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of citrus, yeast, peach and pear. Lightly tart. The taste is very fruity... citrus, pineapple, banana. A bit yeasty and a tart finish. Medium bodied. Pretty nice.

Tap @ OBF...  Incredible Saison!  Poured pale, straw, yellow, with a white head that last with a thick layer on the surface.  Aroma was tart, with flaky grains.  Melon, honeydew, grassy with a strong yeast spice.  Citrus hop notes to counter the fruity, dry tart tones.  Dry finish with a yeasty tanginess.

22 oz bottle.  Clear gold pour, with fizzy white head.  Aroma of sweet grapes, citrus, orange peel, banana, and bread.  Flavor is more focus on the bread, but still sweet and fruity.  Light peppery hay notes.  Body is pretty heavily carbonated and sharp.  Overall a very interesting twist on the saison.
Pours a cloudy blond with lively carbonation and a foamy white head.  Aroma is lightly citrus with a barnyard smell.  taste is lightly citrus.  palate is tingly and slightly chewy.

50cl traded bottle. Very light yellow, slightly hazy with a nice white head. Foamy lacing. BIG aroma of banana, sugar, Belgian yeast, and some citrus peel. The beginning and end of the flavor are pretty classic but the middle is a little heavy on the orange.  Still pretty tasty and the 6.5 ABV is nice.

Bottle from Utobeer. Hazy golden with a fine, white head. Peppery citrus aroma, hints of oranges. In the mouth a lot pepper flavours, nicely balancing acidic orange fruit, though mostly on the bitter side. Very Belgian in character- very elegant.

Pours out looking just like champagne. Lots of bubbles! Lacy white head. Aroma of citrus. Flavor is as advertised - tart orange with vanilla finish. Very drinkable. This could become my new summer brew! Note to Goose Island: put this into six-packs!
This was a very good saison that i had over the fourth of July. It was a little warm when i had it but that shouldn’t take away too much from the flavor.

Bottle. Poured a nice yellowish color with a long lasting pillowy white head. It left lacing on the glass as it went. Aroma was citrus, orange, and lemon zest. Flavor was grass, spices, zest, and corrider. Great aftertaste. Goose Island does it again with another great beer. I love all goose island offerings. They don’t make a bad beer.

Bomber. Bright glowing gold. Complex, spicy, fruity aroma, with biscuity pilsner malt, citrus and grass. Peppery dry hops, a bit of honey, big orange, spice. Really good, though a bit too sweet and spicy, and a touch too much orange. Not as refined as the best, but a very nice saison indeed. Maybe the best I’ve had from to US to date.

Bright yellow, slight cloudiness, huge white head, tiny carb bubbles, great lacing. Orange and lemon peel up front, hints of stone fruits, mango/peach/apricot, bright floral character, not sure though, daffodil, yeasty. Perfect citrus zest up front, lemon/orange peel again. Light cereal, white grape and pepper through the middle. Oaky/vanilla finish. Effervescent mouthfeel, fades to soft/billowy finish. World class.

My bottle [650ml] shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, jerc & mabel. Pours a cloudy yellow-gold with an average size diminishing foamy white head. Aroma is sweet and yeasty along with herbs, spices, fruit and some alcohol.  Flavour of yeast and herbs foremost followed by fruit, honey and a lightly spicy bitter finish. Average to medium bodied. Really good, not as amazing as I expected due to some of the high ratings but still very, very good stuff.

Poured from the bottle a light golden orange-yellow. Ocean foamy head, and lots of bubbles. Aroma of citrus: orange and lemon. Mouthfeel is bubbly -- maybe too bubbly. Texture was like club soda. The finish was clean, with hints of orange and lemon, and slight bitterness.

2010 bomber from bevmo on 5/9/10

hazy pale orange with a soft white head.

it smells or orange, pale malt, straw, flowers, bubblegum and a touch stinky.

the flavor is the same with the addition of some spiciness on the finish. it is sweeter than i’d ideally like which covers up the funk and crisp texture the style needs. 7/3/6/3/14/3.3

5/1/11 12 oz. bottle from 4/23/10. Serious brett nose and dryness on the palate. Highly carbonated.

Pours a bright yellow/orange color with long lasting white head.  Fresh orange dominates the aroma.  Taste is very floral & earthy with notes of clove, chardonay & orange.  A touch sour, but mellow belgian malt is forefront.  I’m not crazy about the style, but this is pretty solid.  Light with a solid malt backbone, drinkable, fruity.  I’d buy it again.
Bottle@Blind Tiger NYC. Hazy yellow body with a medium fuzzy white head. Aroma is fruity, spicy, pepper and orange. Flavor is also spicy with notes of pepper, orange and fruit.

Bomber! Clear yellow with a big beige head and vigorous carbonation. Crisp spicy and herbal aroma. Flavor is very dry and herbal, with a lot of dry winey and spicy notes. Crisp finish. Easy drinking and enjoyable.

pours hazy yellow with a thin white head and no lacing.  slightly musty citric aroma with coriander.  Very rich taste.   somewhat tart with orange peel, coriander, yeast, clove and bubblegum.  spicy, sweet finish with yeast bitterness.

[2908-20100618] 650mL bottle. Spicy citrus juice yeast aroma has great fruit characteristics coming through. Hazy, light orange brown body with a medium-lasting foamy white head. Sour lemon spicy zest flavour hast bitter tart hints and a nice gentle fruitiness throughout. Medium body. Tasty, nicely balanced with carbonation.

(c/o blankboy, w/ him, GregClow, HogTownHarry, jerc)

was really excited seeing this, thinking it was Juliet.  Oh well, here we go!  Hazy yellow with small white head, not much lace.  Yeasty spicey cereal aroma--nothing interesting or unexpected.  Taste is the same.  Meidum to light body on the palate with effervescent carbonation.  Overall: all saisons are the same to me, and it just ain’t my style--very 1D IMO.  And where the F are the "wild" yeast???

aroma of cloves, grains, and citrus, some fresh cut grass and light wood.
cloudy light orange, filmy white head.
sweet and spiced in front, with a light bitterness.
light-medium body, lively carbonation, wheat-like finish. a bit too sweet, but this is good.
Overrated: this brew is average with decent flavors although it skanks up as it warms. The head is on the spritzy side and the aroma is very mild.
Bottle: Brewer say Belgian Ale! we should respect the brewer. Great. Food Pairing: Brie.

This is a nifty little/big beer.  It’s got some serious spices to it alongside some orangy citrus.  A little bit yeasty and sweet.  Summarizes the flavors.  The aroma is similar to the flavors.  The appearance is nice with a nice ibg fluffy head.
2010 vintage.  Pours turbid gold w 3f white head.  Nice look.  Nose is limey fruit, hopcitrus, spicy.  Tastes rich, very citric, spicy, peppery, with hopcitrus, perfumy florals, and orange zest.

Bottle.  Pale golden pour, lots of yeasty particles in it (thanks to me shaking them up), fluffy white head.  Very bright, lemon and orange citrusy nose with coriander and pepper spice and floral characteristics.  Tastes sweeter than I was expecting, as well as very yeasty.  Creamy moderate body.  Lots of lemon and orange citrus to this, apple/pear, a little tart acidity, dry herbal, coriander, and pepper on the finish.  Refreshing and complex.

12 oz. bottle.  Light yellow golden pour, slightly cloudy.  Good carbonation, medium head that fades to a small persistent one.  Aroma is yeasty, some tropical fruit notes, hint of clove.  Medium heavy body, good carbonation. Little alcohol prescence. Finishes long and malty, somewhat dry, notes of pears and bananas.

Bright, funky brett nose, lots of golden fruits, light pineapple, touch of peach and some honey. Taste is fairly dry, lightly bitter, some citrus hops, fresh herbs, lots of tart unripe fruits, touch of cotton candy.

Probably my fifth saison on this 4th of July.  Very nice pour.  Not quite the top, that would go to the Jandrain Jandrenouille IV, but this is pretty nice, like IV lite.  Pours a straw yellow, slightly hazy with a thick fluffy white head.  Very fruity and floral.  Flowery aroma with light spice and fruit.  Moderate sweetness.  Some citrus and lots of flowers on the tongue.  Mostly dry, somewhat funky finish.  A touch of brett.  Lightly hopped.  Good for a summer day.

22oz bottle.  Pours a hazy whitish golden color with big white head.  Aroma has a bit of brett, some sweet fruit, yeast and a bit of alcohol.  Flavor is reasonably dry, with sweet fruit, cereal, alcohol, citrus peel, vanilla and some sweet herbal hops.  Finish is somewhat bitter, with grapefruit and lemon peel, followed by a touch of malt.

Light aroma of citrus and yeast followed by flavors of tangy citrus and tart spices.  Stars off a little sweet and ends with a dry finish.  I’m not the biggest fan of saisons, but this one impressed me.

22oz., bottled Oct. 23, 2009, cellar aged for most of that time.  Pleasant lightly tart, fruity, flowery, citric nose, also showing some very light sugary sweetness and peppery spice, along with faint hints of wild yeast in the background.  Pale, hazy golden straw color with a respectably foamy, lasting head.  Flavor profile is remarkable, quietly complex, with a gentle blend of tartness and bitterness up front, fading into juicy citrus and light malt sweetness, finishing drier with suggestions of spice, wood and lingering, faint yeast esters.  Palate is light and airy with plenty of soft carbonation, paired with a medium body.  Drinkability is through the roof.  Chilled for about 90 mins and served in the exact manner of glass suggested on the label.  This is very nice indeed.

On tap. Pours a hazy gold with a tight white head. A very floral aroma with some yeast. Flavor is amazing; a cross between chardonay, champagne and beer. Very refreshing and drinkable. My girl loves this stuff and I am becoming a fan also!

"Hazy yellow colored body with a big rocky head and thick lacing...the beer sparkles in the glass. Medium bodied and mildly sweet with a spicy hop bite. Oranges, grass, apricots, musty yeast and spicy noble hops. Fermented citrus flavor along with biscuits and straw as well as a heavy earthy yeast. Seems to have a nice white wine influence tucked in there as well. Interesting brew."

Doughy spicy nose.  Hazy straw yellow color, big long lasting head.  Sour cotton candy, bitter, tart, rich, good balance.  Huge carbonation, medium body, incredibly fresh spicy citrusy finish with nice light funk and alcohol warmth.  An outstanding beer.  Full, complex, yet approachable, a must try.

Draft. Pours golden with a medium white head. Aroma is hay, yeast, and herbs. Flavor is quite complex with spices including coriander and allspice, citrus fruits, yeast, hay, grain, malt, and some pepper with a good earthy taste to it. Light bodied with high carbonation. Very good brew.
Bottle from Tiffany’s. Clear yellow colour, sparkling white head. Aroma is citrus, yeast. Flavour is citrus, yeast, some malts, a bit earthy. Good stuff.

Pours yellow with white head. Very quick dissipation. No retention. Nose is very strong peel, lemon, citrus, coriander and yeast. Taste if peel, lemon, white pepper, vanilla and light spices. One of the juicier and tastier saisons I’ve ever had. Quite phenomenal drinking. Perfect for sitting out on the porch on a hot day and chasing kids off your front lawn.
Don’t remember who let me have this, but thanks!  Slightly funky and fruity.  High carbonation.  Pretty good and refreshing.

A-pours a slightly hazy pale straw color with a thin bubbly white head.

S-light toasted biscuity malt up front taken over by yeast and sweetness.  lots of yeast, notes of lemon, touch of orange, hint of musky cellar, herbs and some floral soapy notes.

T-sweet lemon right up front, lots of wheat and yeast, hint of toasted biscuit, a good bit of floral sopay notes, hints of herbal hops, citrusy orange, and a touch of bitterness in the finish.

M-very grainy feel, quite chewy and thick, full bodied and syrupy with a good carbonation and a strong crisp finish.

D-this is pretty darn tasty with a good balance of sweet and toasted malt, I really enjoy this and love the thick chewy body.

On tap at Coles, Buffalo 

Aroma  soft aroma , light hint of hops with drop of citrus. Mild softness wraps the experience.

Appearance  golden ale with white top and ornamental lace.

Flavor and Palate :  light and clean. Meadow like hints with golden malt below. Light hint of hop noted. Pleasant brew.

(Old BA rate - bottle)
ight greenish-yellow hue; mostly clear; poured with a thinner pure white head. Fresh white grapes; yeasty; a bit tart and sour; bit of earth/wood. A little vinous; green grapes; bit woody; touch of sweeter apples and pears. Medium to thinner; very vibrant and bubbly carbonation. Great stuff here; lightish and dry overall; tasty. Overall, an interesting take on the style and I very much enjoyed this one.

2010-06-18. Hazy pale pastel yellow body with a modest white head. Modest aroma, floral character, grassy, touch of spice. 7+ Flavour is similar, light bitterness throughout, interesting melange of spice and mild herbal notes. 7+ Average palate is very lightly carbonated which make sit feel lighter than it really is. Very very drinkable, but just a touch mild overall. A little bit more of everything would step it up a notch.   Enjoyable. Bottle shared by Blankboy
Sampled at American Craft Beer Fest 2010. Pours dark golden.  Aroma of doughy malts with the Belgian, spicy yeast.  Thick texture, and a nice spiciness to the finish.  A good beer.

pours very clear and could easily be mistaken for a pilsner or kolsch from its appearance. However, when you take a sip you are treated to very rich flavors of orange, coriander, straw, and hay, with almost a creamy flavor (not texture) quality that’s hard to describe. Very clean and not bitter in the least. An outstanding brew.

From a 22oz Bottle.  Mostly transparent, brassy gold colored body with a thick head of pillowy white foam.  Notes of apple and pear esters with a prominent orange citrus note that gets stronger as it warms.  Faint herbal hops and bready malt.  Light bodied, moderate-heavy carbonation with a dry, yet soft texture.  Fresh bread dough malty/yeasty flavor accented by the orange citrus.  The orange is a fresh, clean flavor, but less would be nice.  Hints of vanilla and lemon meringue.  A suggestion of brett in the finish with a light, pinot grigio-esque vinous character lingering on the palate.  Could use more yeast character; the body is nice and light, but the lack of malt or hops focuses the attention on the spice additions (i.e. orange peel) and more fermentation character (e.g. pepper, tropical fruit) would help add some depth.

22 oz. bottle. Bottled on 02/19/10. Pours a light, fluffy, lasting white head, of long duration, over a slightly hazy yellow (SRM 3) body.....nose is apple/pear, light citrus, bit of coriander.....taste is light sweet malt to start, then clove, lemon, finishing with a light pepper bite and light bitterness.....mouth feel is medium, carbonation adds a pleasant spritz. This is true to its style. It is light, refreshing, and has all of the spice and fruit flavors it should. BJCP 7/3/15/5/7

Shared with a friend on a warm evening. Nice appearance in the glass. Poured hard to get a nice 2 inch frothy head. The aromas where sweet, peppery and some citrus. Flavors the same, including more pepper and orange. A nice Saison. Very drinkable and enjoyable.

2010 bomber on 11/5/11.  the Brett has developed well over ~2 years in the bottle.  huge 4 finger rocky white head over an orange pour.  big Brett nose with layers of oak, spices and orange peel.  medium body with funky Brett, orange peel, lemon, oak and grapes.  dry Brett finish with more orange peel and spice.



shared bomber on 6/6/10.  hazy yellow pour with a 1 finger white head.  orange / lemon nose with Belgian yeast and a touch of oak.  Medium body with a slight tartness, orange peel and a general softness.  tart finish with light fruit notes, more oak and orange.  Curious to see how my 2nd bottle does over time in the cellar.

golden with huge white head.  fruity esters to nose.  high carbonation.  some bitterness before fruity esters, tart notes, with some oak.  remarkable complexity to this brew.  bone dry finish.  i can’t think of a better saison that i have had, stellar

(22 oz bottle).  Pours hazy straw yellow with small carbonation bubble and white head.  Aroma of lemon, coriander.  Taste is sweet with a slight bitterness.  Orange and vanilla are present; this is a surprisingly rich beer with good depth.  Finish is more vanilla and chewy.  My expectations were very much surpassed.  Excellent!
Drank this last night so I can’t quite recall all the details, but it was crisp, refreshing, and delicious. Heavy spice notes and just a bit sour. Awesome.

From the bottle, pours a clear pale yellow-orange with a thick bubbly white head.  Smells like a Belgian--wild yeast, cloves, sweet malt.  Taste is very good, a hint of sourness at the end, but otherwise smooth, yeasty, much like the aroma would lend you to expect.  Bad rating, my apologies, but it’s a good beer worth trying.

bottle..Hazy light golden pour , big fluffy white head , excellent lacing . Aroma of citrus and spice . The flavor is sweet upfront with notes of orange , pepper and vanilla . Tart and dry finish , very faint wild yeast touch , medium to high carbonation . Very refreshing and well balanced , excellent .

Gosh it’s nice. Barely filtered gold blond look with intricate side lacing. Aroma of earth, mixed green grape and lemon. Taste is same with varied white grape flavors, light mineral. Pretty and elegant Saison that really seems like wine!

22oz bottle poured into a Tulip at 43°.  Color is a hazy yellow gold with good carbonation and a white head that is tight in the center and loose on the edge.  Aroma of sour yeast and hay.  It has a lighter medium body that goes down with an easy crisp feel.  Finish comes in sweet with fruity yeast, flowery hops and white pepper.  After taste lets a mild sour come out that leaves you with a dry feel.  Overall its a very well done and refreshing Saison.

From a trade via Strykzone.  Thanks.  This was from the 22 oz bottle as hazy gold with a big fizzy white head that took a while to face and left moderate lacing in the glass.  The nose is more like a hefe than a Belgian showing banana and other ripe fruits, and some spices. The body is medium and  the mouthfeel dry and light.  The flavor is all over the place with fruit, citrus, and spices.  It finishes dry and lightly bitter.  A well crafted beer.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy pale yellow color with a medium sized white head.  The aroma is floral with some mild/moderate citrus notes.
