The flavor is a well blended combination of citrus, yeast, mild peppery spiciness, floral notes and orange peel.  Finish is dry and tart with a slight bitterness.  This is a very drinkable saison.

Pours a pale yellow colow with a thick white foam head.  Has an aroma of honey, grass, citrus, with hints of floral.  A bit bready and doughy perhaps.  Has a light citrusy bitter taste.  I get the saison on the light airy feel.  But I think it borders on a belgian strong (too low an abv) with the carbonation level and an american tripel with the hops and banana notes.  Very interesting brew.

Bottled sample from 2009. Straw coloured with strong carbonation. Strong floral and orange peel aromas, along with a hint of vanilla pod. More pilsner malt forward in the mouth than expected, but the peppery spice and drying quality achieve a good balance. Very faint fruit and wild yeast character (I had hoped and expected more of both). Fairly good overall.

Very light golden coloured body with a thinnish, fast-dying white head. Aroma of pepper, malt, wheat, yeast, spices, bananas, hay and way more spice - very nice! Medium-bodied; Assertive effervescence with a large spice and sweet flavour that just packs the mouth with taste. Pepper, hay and sugars come through nicely and leave the mouth very dry. Aftertaste shows a lot of spices with curacao, coriander seed, pepper, allspice, clove and anise very prevalent. Overall, a very nice beer - a lot of character and a great complex saison/belgie ale. Definitely nice to sample, get it if you can find it! I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Chevy Chase Wine & Spirits in Washington, DC on 13-May-2010, sampled at home in Washington on 01-June-2010.

Pours slightly hazy yellow with a foamy white head. Aroma of lemon, clove, honey, bready malt, citrus. Taste has bready malt, some yeast spice, very zesty, some funky bitter finsih, light tart. Medium body, lively but smooth carbonation.

Pours opaque sand to straw to gold hay in color with white head. The aroma has notes of spiciness and yeast to go along with a mild level of grainy malts and sweet apple fruitiness. The taste has a similar layout as the nose with spiciness, some yeasty spices then moving into modest grain and apple sweetness. It picks up a bit more spiciness into the finish.

pours a cloudy yellow with a very thin white head, above average carbonation, and a little lacing.

smell is of lemon, some banana, and a touch floral.

taste is crisp, fruit, malt, banana, and lemon, ends refreshing and a little tangy.

Sample at the 1st annual Columbus Beerfest on 05/28/10: This beer is a mostly clear golden color with a thin off-white head that burns away quickly. Rings of lacing. The aroma is peppery spices and yeast along with some malt. Medium body with flavors of yeast, citrusy hops, malt and spices. The finish is lightly hopped with a yeast aftertaste. Above average overall.

Bouteille de 22 oz, rapportée de Chicago. Arômes de levure de saison, belle touche d’agrumes. Robe blonde et trouble, très belle mousse et effervescence active. En bouche, la levure est présente avec des touches de bananes et de fruits, mais semble moins rustique qu’au nez. Belle touche d’agrumes. Le passage dans les fûts de chêne se fait sentir par une finale légèrement vineuse et boisée. Intéressant.

Pours a rather bright golden color with very slight haze, large bubbled head, and tons of lace.  Tons of carbonation in this beer that is mesmerizing to watch.  Nose has some orange & funky yeasty aromas.  On the palate there is a nice citrus flavor with light wheaty malt.  Easy drinking and refreshing.
very very good.  Had this paired with Grilled Salmon and Swordfish - amazing flavor and light enought to go well with Seafood and dinner.  Can’t wait to try again

Bottle. 2010 vintage. Light golden beer with a whitish head. Yeast and spice aroma with a light fruitiness. Fruity (orange and white wine) flavor with spice and yeast. Medium bodied. Fruit and yeast lingers with light spice and light sweet malt.
Aroma of hay cereal perfume banana and clove. Sweet with citrus yeast and floral notes.Soft palate with a creamy mouthfeel and lingering aftertaste. Nice saison.

Appearance: 22oz bomber poured into an Einbecker Dunkel glass. Pours a fairly transparent golden color with a 1 finger white crown that rapidly dissipates and leaves behind small swirls of lace.

Smell: Belgian yeast, pale malt, a touch of orange, and some spice notes.

Taste: Loads of belgian yeast and a good portion of curaco(sp?) orange peel, and a slightly bitter finish.

Mouthfeel: Crisp and on the lite side of medium bodied.

Drinkability: Easy drinker...

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-17-2009
Loved it. Nose of orange with a little funk. Clear, crisp sharp bite of tartness and zest. Very drinkable!!!

Bottle.  Pours a light and clear golden yellow with a short-lived foamy white head.  Nose is sweet, spicy, and fruity with moderate citrus and some vanilla.  Light, heavily carbonated, dry.  Nice spicing and a good hit of fruity tones with some mild yeast.

Bottle (Gotta love the label -- gorgeous packaging).



Probably my favorite goose island beer to date, especially if I don’t view it as a saison. Aroma is the distinctive house character of their belgian-style yeast, plus a very nice tart oaky bite from the wine barrels. Too strong on the banana esters for my taste and too sweet for a saison in my book, it nonetheless is a very nice beer largely because of the magic that took place in the barrels.

Bottle.  Aroma of orange, vanilla cream, oak and a subtle sour funky fruity note that is just so delicate and charming.  What a sweety of a beer.  Pale yellow orange hue with a large white foamy head that diminished and left good lace.  Taste is sweet and fruity with a creamy finish.  Palate is medium bodied and lively.  What a beautiful, charming and sweet beer.  Like a refined young woman kissed by the late afternoon sun.  Elegant and delecious.  Sofie, I love you, now give me some sugar baby :)
Bottled sample.  Pours a beautiful golden colour.  Great tasting. Nice spicy finish.  Wonderfully carbonated.

Pours a lightly hazed orange with a large white head and lots of carbonation. Aroma is belgian yeasts, citrus, orange peel, esthers, white wine. Flavor is belgian yeasts, pepper, citrus, oak, esthers, spices and fruits. Dry sparkling refreshing and flavorful.  Good stuff.

22oz bottle.   Brilliant gold with a creamy, medium-sized white head.   The aroma is fruity and sweet with prominent apricot and tangerine backed by frosting sweetness and a touch of oaky white wine.   The flavor has a sweet candied pils malt thing going on with a touch of vinous character that manifests in alcohol and oak.   Big orange fruitiness.   Sweet and lightly syrupy in the finish, but light in body overall with lively carbonation.   Somewhat interesting but too sweet and orange-dominated ovaral.
Bomber. Pours pale yellow with plenty of rising bubbles. Tastes like a crisp, dry saison. Aromas of bubblegum, citrus, and slight pepper. Citrus, sugars, oak, vanilla in the taste.

Bomber from Bevmo. Pours light, straw yellow with a fizzy white head and specks of lace. Smells bready and yeasty sweet with hints of wine barrel, biscuits and straw. Tastes sweet and bready and yeasty. Grains first, than sweetness. Slight wine flavors and barely any wood character. Medium body, vibrant carbonation.

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with James and Tony. Pours a cloudy golden-yellow with a thin, bubbly white head. Aroma of lavender, corriander, vanilla, dry grapes, yeast, orange peel, grass, and small notes of honey. Medium bodied with a clean, slightly dry, sweet palate. Finishes with a floral sweetness. Excellent saison from Goose Island.
Had with James and pat. Pours a hazy light gold. No noticeable head. Aroma and flavor are similar to a wheat. So much corriander and orange peel. Spices are well balanced.

Bottle split with Pat and Tony. Pours a bright, hazy orange body with soapy white head. Aroma is tart, and slight farmhouse. Mouthfeel is medium. Taste is almost like a tart witbier with lots of flavor, mostly notes of orange peel, coriander, yeast.
Very crisp, light, tasty and all around delicious.  Would buy from again. A++++

22oz bomber into snifter. Pours golden yellow with a tall fluffy white head. Hints of funk on the nose followed by a little bit of spice. Medium mouth-feel with moderate carbonation. Taste is spicy followed by a little bit of sourness. Great offering from goose island

Pours cloudy yellow with a nice white head and a citrus aroma. Thre is a yeasty light malt flavor featuring citrus and spice. The mouthfeel is at first smooth, but turns to carbonation. This brew has all the elements of a good Belgian-style saison and is a pleasure to drink.

Pale yellow with a finely carbonated billowing white head.  Sour, yeasty Belgian nose right off that follows into the first sip.   True to the Belgian style with a peppery, sour flavor with a touch of lemon and cloves.  You can definitely taste the wild yeast here but it’s very well balanced with the other flavors.   I’m not a big fan of Brett, so for the other 2 of you out there who aren’t either, don’t worry, you’ll like this beer!

Bottle drank during the May 2010 Utah tasting. Pours a cloudy yellow color with a huge white head. The aroma is dusty, sweet malts, light fruit. The flavor is nice and straightforward; sweet malts, light fruit, spices and banana. Enjoyable.

Bottle from miketd, thanks man!  Poured a clear, pale yellow color with an inch and a half thick, frothy white head that slowly receded to a thin layer and left some spotty lacing.  Light, crisp maltiness with hints of hay, a soft barnyard yeastiness presenting some light phenols (bubble gum and band aid), soft, dry citrus fruit (orange peel and tangerine), and some light oak on the nose.  Crisp, lightly tart entry with soft hints of white grapes that transitions into a clean maltiness with some hay and light cereal leading into a lightly dry yeastiness with undertones of pepper, orange peel, and grape skin that linger into the finish where they are paired with a distinct wine barrel oakiness that imparts a nice dryness.  Fine, tight carbonation and light body combine to create a crisp mouth feel.  Overall, this wasn’t what I would call a real traditional saison/wild ale, but it was pretty tasty and a pleasure to drink.  Thanks again Mike.

Bottle shared by eric, thanks again 

Appearance: Hazy light yellow with a nice white head and some lacing 

Aroma: Spices, yeasty and some tart fruits 

Taste: Some sourness and citrus, spices 

Very nice saison, with a twist.

Pours a two finger white head that fades slowly leaving a good lace. Good carbonation and light-medium bodied.  Cloudy light yellow color.  Nose is citrus.  Flavor is sweet and sour citrus, hints of yeast. Good summer beer. Bottled 12/11/2009. $8.45 for a 22oz bottle from Colonial Spirits, Acton, MA.

22 oz bottle, dated 2/19/10 1313. Pours crystal clear golden with a very nice white head that retains very well, leaving some nice lace work behind. The aroma is peppery, spice, malt. The flavor is sweet, malty, bread, spices and yeast. Finish is peppery and bitter. Overall a very nice beer.

Aroma is spicy Belgian/golden ale. Nice citrus hop balance. Fresh orange peel. A tad grassy, especially when agitated.

Appears golden yellow, hazy with lots of fizz. Italian ice lacing, not much of it. Nice color but not much body.

Flavor is grassy lemon citrus and orange. Full of nice, sweet (but not too sweet) spring-y flavors. Green apple and white wine champagne. 

Feels fizzy and bubbly on the palage. Creamy; dances on the tongue. Somewhat ashy finish. Crackles like cereal. Dry wine finish. It’s dry, fizzy, sweet and grassy overall. A nice summery brew.
Batch #1323 - bottled on 2/19/10 - Aroma is floral hop, a little basement, fruits and a little brett. Flavor is citrus, with some herbs. Finishes clean.  I am liking GI’s Belgians.

Bottled 02-10.  The pour is very nice with a very hazy, straw color and an average, white, very frothy head which leaves a small layer throughout and leaves lots of frothy lace.  The nose is a bit off and a bit bland; the orange is apparent either from the orange peel or the wild yeast, a slight barnyard hint, some floral, light white pepper, and bit of corn also.  The flavor is better with minimal corn notes, vanilla really does filter in nicely, white pepper, subtle orange notes, a bit vinous.  The palate is lively, creamy, medium.  It finishes with just a touch of dryness, orange keeping its presence, vanilla still, and pepper lingering.  Odd beer, and not what I would consider to be a saison; it lacks the tartness, it is sweeter and less bitter, and lacks a refreshing character to it.  It is, however, like a Belgian Blond and fairly well done.  The wine barrel aging is minimally apparent, and the wild yeast notes are very subtle.  Nice but not great.

22 oz bottle, dated 2/19/10.  Pours a hazy straw yellow with a smallish creamy white head that retains well and leaves a lot of lacing.  There’s lots of tiny little floaties suspended.



The aroma is peppery spices and some musty yeast with a little banana.



The flavor is sweet bready malts, with some spices and earthy yeast and a little banana.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied with lots of spritzy carbonation that subsides some as it sits.



Overall, a nice saison.  A little too sweet and too much banana for me.
Pours a hazy pale yellow with a big white head. Aroma is tart lemon, yeast, and peppery spice. Flavor is lightly sweet, lemony, tart, spicy, with ample carbonation, and a peppery dry finish.

Bomber from South Bay Drug. Joey da man. Pours very hazy gold with a decent white head. Aromas of fresh citrus and light yeast. Medium body with sharpish carbonation. Flavor is citrus zest and lots of peppery hot bits. And it’s like fresh fruit. That pepper bit hangs on into the finish. Or maybe that’s the zest. Very good, whichever. After awhile there’s a light funkiness, and something like an oaky astringency. Really good stuff.

22oz bottle $7. I bought this after reading the description, the label was nice also. It was a nice orange color in the glass and smelled a little floral and kind of odd. The taste was nice like a saison but with a definite orange flavor to it, the peels really shined in this beer. This was so damn easy to drink, nice beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-29-2010 03:33:24

hazy bright gold body with a tall white head.  nose is heavily floral with the white grape/wine and wood character either present in small amounts or easy to pick up when suggested.  malt is biscuity, slightly toasted (perhaps barrel character?) and semi-sweet; yeast is floral soap and dried herbs.  hops are light citrus and a little bit sour/moldy.  moderately thick body for the style.  fortunately drier than matilda but still too chewy and syrupy.  herbal green finish.  will drink occasionally but I think the syrupiness and malt chewiness could be dialled down.  dry this out some more and we’re talking about something good.

2010.  22oz in Goose Island stem at Toad in the Hole.  Very pale, cloudy with thin diminishing head.  Initial aroma is dirty diaper; mellows into more pleasant aromas of sweet corn and cantaloupe esters.  Flavors are subtly fruity with hints of dried apple, pineapple, and stonefruit.  The palate is the kicker -- it’s only carbonated to a medium-high level, but the mouthfeel kicks off with an exciting, prickly pepper sensation,  This example registers pretty young, with characteristics desirable in a witbier; I’d imagine it would age into a more elegant experience within a few months.
beautiful yellow light orange color. bold Belgian yeast smell.  tart. acidic. almost wine like. taste really sticks to the tongue.

Bottle. Nice pale yellow pour with fluffy white head. Aroma is quite winey, slighty tart and citrusy, bretty and wild, quite complex. Taste is a bit tart, a bit bitter, completely awesome. Notes of citrus, wheat, and a bit of sweetness. Palate is smooth and silky, very enjoyable. This is it, best saison I’ve ever had.

Bottle (2015 vintage).

Head is initially small, fizzy/frothy, white, mostly diminishing.
Body is hazy medium yellow.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (flowers), with notes of citrus candies, ginger ale, coriander.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Light to medium body, watery texture, fizzy/lively carbonation.

This gets closer to a witbier / soda pop every time I try it.  This might be the last try for me.
Pours golden with thin white head.  Aroma of oranges.  Taste has nice citrus flavor mixed with spices.  Smooth finish.

bottle-neon yellow hue with a fizzy humpy white head.  lots of spitzy carbonation going on in my glass.  nose of spice, lite vineous note, oak and grapes.  very nice!  Wow!  lots of woody green grape notes, spice and a touch of oak and lite yeast funk.  really nice woody flavors to start followed by estery/fruity notes long into the finish.  very tart here, but not like a jolly pumpkin.  the finish went for a while, then all of a sudden stopped.  still nonetheless, a very tasty saison here but i wish it was unfiltered.

22oz bottle at a tasting.

Aroma : Lots of herbs with coriander and orange peel. some wheat. Spicy and fresh


Taste : Coriander and orange peel. Hints of honey. Spicy and fruity


Overall : Nice hints of honey. Very fresh. Nice beer.
Yellow body with a white head.Aroma of melon,orange zest,and white wine.Flavor gies me much of the same.The finish is very dry.
Bottle from beverages 4 less.  Light, easy drinking brew.  Lawnmower brew.  Okay.
Bomber shared by iowaherkeye. Nose of yeast, wheat, and a hint of wine. Clear yellow with a small white head. Flavor is lightly sweet, with hints of bitterness and citrus and yeast.

Belgian Saison I’ve only had one other, Clear yellow with a big beige head and vigorous carbonation. Crisp spicy and herbal aroma. Flavor is very dry and herbal, with a lot of dry winy and spicy notes. Crisp finish. I could have drank an awful lot of this. but I just got a sample from a Distributor show.

22oz bottle from Big Z Beverage.  Pours a slightly hazy but otherwise transparent straw gold with a tight, slightly creamy white head.  Aroma is heavy on the orange and orange peel, light lemon, lightly malty, a little coriander, a little light pepper.  Flavor is sweet with plenty of candy sugar right on the front, white pepper, oranges, lemon peel, light spice.  Finish is medium bodied and dry.  Wild yeast?  I don’t get any of it.  Wine barrel?  Where’s the wood?  I guess perhaps there’s a little buttery flavor/texture like a Chardonnay, but I’m missing the uniqueness of this.

22oz bottle, bottled 02/19/10 from Holiday Wine Cellar, $7 or 8.  Minimally hazy effervescent bright golden yellow with a one finger white head, creamy with good retention.  Big yeasty aroma, lemony with plenty of white peppery notes.  Definite orange peels as well as light dusty pale malts.  Flavor has a little more citrus notes leaning more towards the orange.  Some herbal hops are also present.  I get a tinge of vanilla somewhere towards the finish, which was semi-dry with bitterness peaking at a 3.  Just a tinge of white wine, along with a little burn noted at the end.  Moderately high carbonation with a medium body.  Very good example, and quite tasty.

Bouteille de 22 oz partagée lors d’une dégustation Ratebeer Montréal chez Fred82. Arôme: Odeur d’agrumes avec une pointe de miel et d’épices. Apparence: La couleur est blonde légèrement voilée avce une très faible densité de bulle. Présence d’un mince col mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût d’agrumes avec une pointe de banane et d’épices. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement minérale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence d’agrumes en arrière goût. (Rating #2995)

Bottle from SL. Pour was golden to slight yellow. Nice initial head, white color for the most part, good lacing. The aroma was fruity esters, yeast, wheat, Belgian Strong Golden-like. Flavors followed, bananas, vanilla in particular, bready yeast, somewhat tripel like, yet hops light.  Didn’t get much saison/farmhouse/spice out of this, perhaps the yeast the only thing contributing there? Citrus finish, oranges... mouthfeel is smooth balanced carbonation, a touch sweet.

Bottle; poured a clear gold color with a smallish white head.  Aroma of yeast, orange, citrus, wine, vanilla and a dash of spice.  Flavor was solid with some nice complexity.  Yeast and wheat up front, which transitions to orange and citrus.  In the finish you get some spice and vanilla.  Pretty easy to drink and could have some mass appeal.

Bomber, 2010 vintage, poured into a tulip glass. Pours a pale gold color with a thin fading white head. Aroma has some light esters evoking fruit salad, including apple, pear, and banana. Some clove notes lead me to believe this is made with some wheat. Nice smooth spiciness, also getting some vanilla. Flavor is bright and slightly tart, some lemon now emerging with the banana pith. Distinct but very well-integrated pepper note, along with mild notes of cooking herbs. Fruity tropical hops blend well with the esters, just like in the better Belgian IPAs. Light honeyed malts provide a soft background for all the yeasty and hoppy complexity. Dry finish, but not in an astringent way, which is a very significant accomplishment for a beer partially aged in wine barrels. Crisp and clean, a little hefty to be considered refreshing. A nice satisfying beer, somewhere between tripel, saison, and Belgian IPA.

22oz bottle  Jan ’09 4/17/10 (Binny’s Naperville)-58° in Snifter-Pours a hazy yellowish golden with a big white head. Aroma of yeast, brett, and pepper. Taste of the same with a bit of a tartness along with some orange taste. This medium bodied brew is very well balanced and quite tasty. Nice job.
Bottle. Wonderful bretty aroma. Pale gold with evervescent carbonation. Creamy white head. A little dry at initial sip. Plenty of flavor though. Excellent example of the style. Crisp and refreshing.
Clear yellow with a fizzy white head. Lively palate. Nice banana and pear aroma and taste with candy sugar and a dry orange taste to the finish.

Bottle.  A light golden yellow color with a white head.  A light spicy fruit (pear and orange peel) and peppery aroma.   Smooth and creamy with a pepper bite and hint of vanilla in the flavor.  A touch of cardboard and mustiness.

hazy gold pour with a thick foamy head.
aroma is orange blossom floral and grassy hoppiness. I get this tangy mustard seed spice too...
light biscuity pilsner-ish malt underneath. 
Flavour is tart orange and lemony and floral. somewhat dry. light biscuity malt.

Bottle from 2010 picked up at SL. Weak head for a saison... Nice light orange color. Good aroma of yeast, flowers, citrus, lemon, orange and some spices. Taste is better than it looks. Dry, yeasty, little lemon and orange, spices with a touch floral and citrus hops. Smooth and dry, but not bone dry... Nice saison, thanks to robert for picking up GI in MD or at least at SL!

Creamsicle in a bottle baby!! Alright, not exactly.  Bottle pours yellow gold with a creamy white head.  Aroma is heavy orange, vanilla, and yeast, with a backing of hay and white pepper.  Flavor shows the same but also displays some light banana and oak.  The orange leans more into orange peel at this point, and some tart pear starts to poke it’s head out as well.  Overall body weight is moderate, with a soft and creamy mouthfeel.  Goose Island is quickly impressing me with their grasp and interpretation of Belgian styles.  Bravo.

650 ml bottle from Bev4less. Pours a cloudy yellow gold color with a small while head that soon fades to a fine ring. The aroma is soft with Belgian yeasts, apples, maybe some orange peel and straw. The flavor is subtle with fruity notes of apple, pear, oranges and cashew. The palate is smooth but unsatisfying with adequate carbonation. The finish is medium in duration and spicy. Overall: I thought this was mostly bland, the bottle says that it will continue to improve with age for up to five years, but improve into what? I guess that I will have to sock away a bottle and see.

22oz - Aroma of soft chewy yeast which leads into orange peel, oak and white wine.  Flavor is tasty but mellow.  Sour yeast, orange and a touch of oak and wine.  Palate is soft and creamy.  Subtle yet full flavored.

Bomber poured a hazy golden yellow with a lasting creamy white head. Aromas of wheat, yeast, citrus, light spice and a hint of vanilla. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of wheat, yeast, lemon, ligfht pepper and light vanilla with a smooth lingering citrus finish.

My Bottom Line:

Elegant herbal hop spiciness grows through a lively canvas of citrus peel, banana esters, white grapes and mildly honeyed cereals, building a tantalizing Saison-like creation.



Further Personal Perceptions:

-A slim head of foam tops the cloudy straw blond.

-The expansive effervescence and dryish finish make for high drinkability.

-Orange zest is balanced with the just barrel apport.

-The overall flavor profile is quite balanced.

-The herbal hop notes develop basil, sage and even menthol aromas when paired with the already complex interplay of ingredients.



Bottle.

Sampled on 4/9/2010. This saison pours a slightly cloudy yellow orange gold color from a 22oz bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is fruity and sweet, melons, pears and apricot. A medium to full bodied saison. The malts are fruity and sweet, lots of apricot, peach and melon flavors. There is also a touch of tartness at the finish. The hops are herbal. Nice soft lively carbonation. A hint of vanilla. A very delicate subtle beer. There is a hint of wood at the finish. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet with a hint of wood.

Bomber.  Pours a hazy golden yellow with ample carbonation, fizz, and a good 1/2 inch of fluffy, dense white foam that does not dissipate. Nose is faintly bittersweet and barnyard funky, mixed with appropriate and expected citrusy orange peel tones. Saison-classic.  Taste is darker, and heavier  than I would have expected, but pleasant.  The palate on this beer can best be described as, unexpected, and even unpredictable.  I’ve taken 3 tastes now, and not a one has been the same.  The first was dark, barnyard-heavy, the second, more spritely and citrusy light, the third, an oddly tart departure from both the 1st and 2nd.  Interesting, for sure.

Bottle, home.  Excellent Belgian style ale.  Pours a bright lemon gold, fairly hazy, with a small white head.  The aroma is sugary malt, honey, lemons, oranges, moderate funk level and mild but crisp grassiness.  It’s sweet and bright.  The flavor is refreshing.  There’s a dry, believably-Belgian yeast with sweetly tart fruits chiming in.  The orange peel and citrusy hops are pleasantly bitter.  Mouthfeel is clean with an excellent lingering funk aftertaste.  Goose Island makes some awesome Belgian style ales.

A: The pour is a pale golden yellow color with a fluffy white head.

S: The nose is quite fruity with plenty of citrus, pears, and maybe some melon. There’s a definite spice aroma along with some yeast and perhaps even a bit of tartness.

T: I was very pleased by the nose, but the flavors didn’t quite live up to that. The spices are much more pronounced and the tartness doesn’t make an appearance either. There is still some nice fruit character, namely apples, pears, and bananas, however.

M: The body is medium with a very nice tingly carbonation which gives the beer a bit more of a light feeling on the tongue.

D: I liked this much better than some of Goose Islands special releases, but I still don’t know how much of this I could drink. A nice beer to have a small pour of, however.

Bottle from bleeng.
Pours a lively spring yellow with a nice white head.  Aroma is tart, sweet lemon with a light coat of candied sugar.  Flavor is light sour barnyard lemon grown in a horse stall.  Tingly and lingering on the tongue.  WOW.

Bottle from Kahn’s. Bottled in July of last year. This is a very light colored beer, bright yellow but very, very cloudy. A bubbly white head forms. The aroma is cheesy with hints of fields, oranges, coriander, and pepper. Bubbly palate on this one. The flavor is very balanced. I was expecting something more tart for whatever reason, but it’s just dry and fruity. Hints are made at vanilla, cheese, orange, pepper, and flowers. It’s a really delicate offering for an American brewery. Not bad at all.

Sampled at Pacific Park Market, Thanks Ken

This was sort of wit meets saison, or a saison trying to be champagne-like.  Very light and lacking  complexity

Bottle shared by IPFreely: Pale golden color with a thick foamy white head. Yeasty aroma with fiant hints of oak, citrus, and banana. Moderate sweetness, orange zest, and spicy yeast esters.  A hint of oak in the dry finish. Nice stuff.

Re-rate 1/8/11.  2010 bottle.  I liked this so much the first time I had it (2009 version, I believe) I picked up another bottle while traveling.  Big booming white head on top of a slightly hazy golden body.  I pick up much more white wine character this go around.  Citrus, lemon, and flowery notes mix in with light spice, yeast, and wood.  Light-bodied, dry, with a bit of tart funk.  Very clean.  I’m suprised how much better this is than Matilda.  Original Rating:  Bottle from brewblackhole.  Thanks Tom!  Yellowish color, pours a thick fluffy off-white head with pretty good retention.  Orange peel, lemon, wood, yeast and cloves in a pleasant aroma.  Very clean and refreshing.  Flavor adds pepper and citrus which mixes nicely with the clove and yeast.  Simple but very tasty.  Also, the label really fits this beer.  No bells and whistles, clean, and elegant.

Pours hazy yellow with a small white head.  Smells of lemon, some wheat, and clove.  Tastes of lemon, lemon zest, pepper, grass, and coriander.  Nicely seasoned, crisp, yet creamy smooth, and very refreshing.

Pours a hazy light yellow with a large easily excitable white head. The aroma is Belgian yeast, with some light citrus and a hint of funk. The flavor has lots of banana, with lemon zest, barnyard, and some vanilla I only picked out because I was looking for it. Light body with soft carbonation and a dry slightly tart, almost bretty finish. Very satisfying and refreshing.

whoa. rockin good beer here. serious. world class. Hit the sweet spot wiht this. Sophisticated yet so easy and drinkable. no cloying just quaffing. Poured with a fine off white head and a litle lace. Color is a clear amber. Aroma is fresh yeast malt spice grass crotch funk an plasure. Flav’s bout the same, but with a tart edge. Killer body and carbonation. Not just drinkable, but suckable. mmmmm mm mmmm

This beer is gorgeous.  a cloudy lemon yellow with sediment drifting about under a crisp foamy white head.  A dry, mildly spiced aroma dominated by yeast with a faint floral or citrus character.  The body is similarly dry, almost parching.  A little of that sweet character in the finish, which was very dry.  This is the best saison I’ve tried in years.  Worthy of being served next to some duponts.

Pale orange golden, slightly hazed. Foamy head is mostly diminishing and leaves only a small amount of lace. Nose is yeasty, slightly sulfurous w/ a hint of citrus which reminds me of American hops but is probably on account of the orange peel. It’s this flavor and the delicate mouthfeel that really drive the beer. Very light in texture w/ very vigorous but soft carbonation. Orange, lemon and a bit of cloves and vanilla. That the nose has that strange sulfur note in the nose is really unfortunate. It is truly distracting from what otherwise is a very elegant, well-balanced and unique beer.
Bottle @ Copenhaniacs tasting, Pt.1. Pours hazy unclear yellow with a large egg white head and lacings. Nose is yeast, pepper and perfume. Smooth, crisp and dry flavor. Nice

Bottle 22fl.oz.
Clear light medium yellow color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, moderate yeasty, citrus and lemon notes, spicy, coriander notes. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20100314]
bottle thanks to bleeng.  Pours a faded, cloudy yellow with a white head.  Nose is of lemon, yeast and spices.  Taste is of lemon and brett.  Mouthfeel is thin and tart with lots of carbonation.

Pale yellow-grey pour with a diminishing off-white head and ample lacing.  Nose offers a corn-like graininess along with citrus blossoms and light coriander spicing.  Flavor reflects the nose and adds a sweet-tart mandarin orange flavor to go along with the smooth, creamy, vanilla-tinged finish.  Mouthfeel is full of soft carbonation which marries beautifully with the lightly nuanced and refreshing nature of the brew.  As a ’side note’, the bottle artwork is simple but magnificently elegant.  Interesting, fun, and worth trying ... like the most demure, polite, and unimposing saison.  "Sophie" would be a classy date ... deceptively ’fragile’, with a beautiful mind, and a gorgeous smile.

Bottle: Poured a deep hazy beige/orangey color ale with a huge foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of medium-sweet Belgian malt with some notes of orange peel and lightly tart whine wine is quite enticing. Taste is a wonderful mix between some tart notes from the wine barrel with some refreshing notes of Curacao and a nice attenuated Belgian malt backbone. Body is quite full with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. Very well done overall with good drinkability factor and some good complexity.

Bottle thanks to beerad666 (BA)!
Berliner Weisse appearance with pale yellow-gold body and a soapy white head. Nose is predominately lemon and banana with light orange, overall very clean fruit profile. Flavor is light spice with more lemon and dry yeast, again straightforward, clean and fruity. Thin body with fizzy carbonation.

Push over Miller High Life. For this is the true Champagne of beers. This is an enormously interesting beer that challenges me. The color of this drink is a foggy whitish yellow, almost like pear juice but is topped with a suddy head. The aroma is a yeasty spice like coriander, orange zest and white wine. The taste starts off with a bit of malt and melon fruitiness but is quickly overtaken by an overwhelming tartness and dryness. As the tartness fades a light vanilla is all that is left in the mouth. A sharp carbonation bites with each sip. But the body is light and even refreshing.

Bottle at Papsø’s - Thanks. Cloudy yellow - white head. Fruity, yeasty, wheaty, peppery, zesty, citrus, flowery, thin body, sweet notes, elderflowers, freshness, orange, spice, light hoppy. Nice drinkability.

Bottle at Papsø.
Hazy yellow coloured with small floaties and a small white head.
Fruity aroma of citrus, spices and hops.
Fruity flavour of citrus, spices and hops with notes of grass and yeast.
Spicy and citric finish.

Bottled. An unclear yellow beer with a thin white head. The aroma has strong notes of lemon as well as notes of pepper and yeast. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of lemon as well as notes of peber, yeast, and malt, leading to a dry lemony and spicy finish.

cloudy yellow, smooth fine white head.
sweet and fruity faint peachcy.
flavor is sweet and fruity, mild.

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of bu11zeye. Pours a clear yellow with a dense and lively white head. Spicy, yeasty nose. Medium body with a heavy carbonation. Tart fruitiness, quite yeasty and spicy with a dry and somewhat hoppy finish. 140310
Hazy yellow with a tiny white head. Sweet and yeasty aroma with spices and fruity notes. Flavour was sweet with yeast, spices and peachy notes. Finished dry.

22 fl oz bottle. Pours cloudy yellow with a small, fizzy and white head. Aroma is mild estery, dry wheaty. Solid carbonation mouthfeel. Mild fruity and slight spcied. Citric and wheaty flavoured into the finish.

22oz Bottle. Bottled July 17 2009. Oooh. Cool kaffir-lime like aroma, with a bit of mint and herbal characters. Soft and cool. Flavor is a great amalgam of classic Saison characters. Bright pink peppercorns, tropical fruits edging a touch green and bitter, fresh leafy grasses and a restrained, yet expressive yeast character. Super dry, super fresh-tasting. Finishes on a juicy tangerine note, while spanning a spectrum of wonderful summery flavors. Wonderful!

22 oz bottle thanks to Vince. Pours slightly hazy golden yellow with a big pillowy pure white head. Aroma of earthy barnyard yeast, spicy pepper and light wheat. Flavor is very sour and tart up front, the yeast flavors dominate, there are also some bitter hop flavors followed by some very light malt flavors. Light to medium body with very active carbonation and dry tart mouth feel. Very nice beer, full of flavor for it’s light body and abv. Thanks again Vince for another great beer.

Poured a hazed light yellow color with a medium sized white head.  Great aroma with citrus notes and a dry yeasty bretty type funk.  The flavor had some tart lemon citrus notes to it.  Light sweetness.  Semi-dry finish with a mild bitterness.

Pours fairly hazy pale peach tinted gold with a tall, frothy off white head that has excellent retention and leaves very nice lacing, beautiful brew. Aroma is pepper, grass, earthy wet leaf funk, dried citrus rinds, green wood, hints of cellar and other ligher funky notes. Flavor is sweet citrus and light cereal grain up front, followed by warm spices, black pepper, green wood, thistle flower, ginger, white mulberries, basement funk and there is some vanilla and sweet grass to the finish. Palate is medium bodied with a dry feel throughout and a nice active, but not to sharp and velvety smooth carbonation, very nice.

22 oz bomber received in a trade from leaf from ufck. Drank 3.9.10.

Pours a slight hazy, golden yellow that looks beautiful in the glass. Thin layer of creamy, bright white head that lingers for a short time. Smells of hay, grain, orange and a slight lemon zest, with some spicy notes in the background. Taste is magnificent, one of the best saisons I’ve had at this point in my life. The subtle spice flavors are just at the appropriate levels where they’re noticeable, but not controlling the beer. Orange, barnyard, and grassy flavors emerge the further I get into it. Light carbonation gives it a great feel and I definitely had no problem drinking a whole bomber by myself. Would be a great beer for summer afternoons.

Bottle.  Pours clear and sparkling light gold with a medium-large, frothy white head.  Good head retention with fair lacing.  Aroma is light malt with a complex spice bouquet of citrus and pepper, along with some wild yeast character.  Faint notes of oak and wine are present later on.  Flavor is a delicate marriage of light malt, subdued spicy hops, wild yeast, and spices.  Lightly creamy with an effervescent carbonation that finishes dry.  Spices, particularly the orange, linger into the finish and then allow the pepper to join the party late.  Nice, light bodied, smooth, and refreshing ale.
Pours light yellowish golden with a white head. Has a light lemony aroma with some orange zest. Light flavor with a touch of lemon and a peppery spice with a bit of vanilla.
Bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  The look is cloudy, has a white head, yellow to golden in color.  The taste is lemon, yeast, fruits, and sugary.  The smell is sugary, lemon, and fruits.

Bottle date 10/23/09 - Pale golden with a large white head. Very lively looking. Aroma is orange zest, slight dustiness. Flavor is orange, pepper, medium bitter, lightly sweet. Very lively medium-light palate.

Thanks to bleeng for bringing this beer. Pours a light lemon straw with a small head. Aroma of lemon, pepper, green tart and almost a lambic nose. Crisp, effervecent flavors of lemon, spices, tartness and corriander. Drying finish that leaves you wanting more.

Bottle: Pours a clear effervescent golden with a thin, wispy-lacing white head.  Aroma of soft Belgian biscuity pale malts and some mild doughy yeasty notes with a healthy dose of lemon citrus and coriander.  Starts with a mild biscuity sweetness and some earthy hop notes and peppery coriander spice with some citric tartness before a drier finish.  Pretty smooth and drinkable with good authenticity.

Bomber. Pours hazy yellow gold, white head. Aroma is fruity, spicy; a very yeasty aroma. Flavor is similar and meaty and substantial. I find this to be a fairly well-rounded ale. It’s not offensive or watery.

Bomber bottled 12/11/09.  Pours a beautiful bright very clear golden- pilsner-like with a massive white foamy head- nice lacing as well.  The second and 3rd pours get subsequently more hazy with more and more sediment and tiny suspended yeasty particles.  Aroma is yeasty, doughy, definite orange peel-citrus adds to the very light delicate fruity esters of the yeast, almost as if it was a french saison yeast- the wild yeast doesn’t come out yet- or at least not as any kind of funk as of yet, although it was only bottled a few months ago- also gets nice herbal light grassiness which keeps the fruity citrus orange peel in check and hints of bready dough from the malt, and even a touch of sulfur from fermentation.  Flavor is very clean, yet there is still quite a bit of complexity all around- starts off with a nice biscuity bready pils malt backbone which turns a bit leathery, doughy, yeasty light sulfur and the leather almost gets a light musty earthy funk but hardly anything- gets a lot of clean mineral and light salted pils malts and phenols in the midpalate which is nice- and finishes off a bit grassy, with a touch more of a slight oily orange peel, more mineral, and even a bit more salt- slight Margarita like in the finish- almost bone dry and spritzy- which is very quenching and makes it easy drinking.  Very nice saison- a touch unique with that orange peel, but it seems to work, as this is a very delicate refined, well made saison.  I liked this every time I have had it.

bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  poured hazy light yellow with a white head.  aroma was popcorn butter and vanilla with the flavor being much the same and slight orange.  light body with high carbonation.

Hazy golden color with a medium sized, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of citrus fruits, toasted malts, spices, vanilla, wine, and light wild yeast.  Taste of citrus fruits, honey, coriander, pepper, vanilla, grass, light wine, spices, and a dry finish.

June 2009 Bottle Date; Sampled October 2009

A solid pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces a fat-three-finger thick, pale tan colored head.  The beer is a pale honey color that shows a lightly hazed, straw gold color when held up to the light.  It is amply carbonated with a whole lot of streaming bubbles flowing up through it.  The aroma smells of hay, orange blossoms, orange zest, a touch of musty phenolics, lots of pale grain notes, a sort of weed like dried grassiness, some light herbal honey aromatics and a healthy grain note that becomes more prominent the more you dig into the aroma.  As the beer warms the honey like note gets more prominent, though it always remains well balanced with the other aromatic notes.  A touch of alcohol is also noticeable as the beer warms.



My first sip of this tastes quite dry from beginning through the end of the flavor profile.  There is a grassy herbal note that lightly spices this beer as well as some spiciness that reminds me of black pepper, orange zest, some turpene like clove notes, some grassy notes that seem to taste a touch like sage..  This has a lively, peppery carbonation that provides lots of carbonic acid to the finish.  This has a underlying mustiness to it and a general earthiness that makes me think that a Dupont derived strain of yeast might have been used in this beer.  The flavor has a really nice pale grain, pale cracker grain character that is really quite prominent.



My second pour of this is quite murky and full of sediment.  Since I don’t spend so much time examining the nose, the beer is also quite a bit more carbonated, but the sediment doesn’t seem to have affected the flavor too much.  Both the nose and the aroma see me noticing a bit more fruitiness than before; it almost reminds me a bit of some oaked Sauvignon Blanc and / or Chardonnay grapes somehow; there are also hints of melon, pear and a suggestion of kiwi.  The beer definitely is quite herbal / grassy, with perhaps a touch of yeasty wholesomeness that mixes with the crushed grain notes and provides a touch more hearty character to this otherwise light beer.  Speaking of which, this beer is nice and light bodied; while dry, there is enough body to not make this seem watery at all.  This has a certain palate presence that provides just a touch of fullness to this beer; it is quite nicely balanced towards being quaffable and refreshing.  There is a very subtle oak influence, one that I likely wouldn’t have picked out if I didn’t know about it, but it does add some spiciness and some texture to this beer that wouldn’t otherwise be here.



The aroma of this beer has a soft sweetness to it (the honey and orange like notes) that doesn’t translate to the mostly dry flavor.  I definitely like this character in my Saisons, which should be quite dry.  This is a very nice beer; it has a really nice mix of flavors / aromas and is quite easy drinking.  I could easily stand to have quite a few of these bottles about as these will likely age for at least another year quite well.  Without having had Juliet yet, I almost wonder if this is the better beer of the two; I’ll have to confirm that when I crack a bottle of Juliet.  This is definitely a fantastic beer that I find quite enjoyable.  My 22oz bottle of this is too quickly gone & I definitely wish I had more of these.

Sampled at Binny’s Glen Ellyn, IL. After Dinner Tasting. Poured to a small snifter a slightly hazed, straw hue, with modest, white, bubbly foam to the head, and light lacing. The aroma was light fruit, lemon zest, and a hint of spice. The flavor added light tartness, and a vinous nature as dry, white wine. The body was on the light side, and the carbonation was lively and almost fizzy. Very refreshing, and nicely paired with a lemon pastry by Charissa, the GI rep.

(22oz bottle, courtesy of thirdeye11)  Pours a hazy pale yellow body with a medium white head.  Aroma of coriander, lemon, grass, and florals.  Flavor of lemon, florals, clove, subtle pepper, and banana with a soft mouthfeel.

Eagan, Mn. - Big Top Liquors - 22 oz bomber. Pours a cloudy dark golden/yellow with a sticky white head that leaves nice sticky lacing on the glass. Nice, almost pungent aroma with lots of lemony goodness. Spicy flavor with hints of saffron, lemon, vanilla, and yeast. Thick, rich mouthfeel. Overall, excellent.

nice yellowish hue, frothy head. nose is tart and barnyard with some citrus.
flavor is light malts but a slightly acidic flavor and tartness with citrus notes. very refreshing and flavorfull

In short: A very sharp dry/bitter, medium wild and slightly spicy blonde Saison.  A must for the Saison lovers

How: Bottle.  Vintage 2009, consumed when about 6 months of age (bottling date July 17 2009).  Sent to me by rudolf, Thanks a lot Rudy

The look: Partially cloudy blonde body topped by quickly dissipating white head

In long: Nose is very bright and wild with notes of floral hops, grapefruits and white pepper.  Taste is very countryside field.  Dry hay, lemongrass, wild flowers, grapefruits skin, omnipresent bready yeast, bubblegum.  Very farmhouse and wild but not to the point of being funky.  Finish is dry, bitter, tart, like a cross between a basic dry saison and a grapefruity IPA (like AleSmith IPA).  The smooth carbonation and not-too-lively body is a bit lackluster compared to the rest of the beer but that’s unfortunately the case with too many American Saisons.  All in all a great brew.  Few beers, that exquisite nectar, are named after women.  For obvious reasons we name hurricanes after women.

Sampled at the 2010 Crescent Moon Extreme Beer Festival. Very pale yellow with a thin white effervescent head. A bit of a sulfurous aroma. Thin and lemony. Fizzy palate. Perchance, a dash of lime. Nothing special here.

Wow, Goose Island really struck a winner with this one.  Pours hazy yellow with a snow white head.  The aroma has pale malt, earthy Belgian yeastiness, mild orange, light spiciness, dry bubblegum and some nectar fruit ~ quite nice.  It has a medium body that starts on the lighter side and ends a bit fuller with minorly sharp, but frothy carbonation.  The flavor starts sharp and dry with some dry white wine notes along with the aroma traits as well as some pear and spice.  The finish is dry, earthy, fruity and yeasty.  This is one great beer & seems to defy being put into a particular style.

big thanks to thirdeye11for this bottle.  light cloudy yellow with a white head.  florals, earth, spices, yeast, fruits, and wood for aromas.  lively on the palate with flavors of honey, florals, yeast, earth, spices, and fruits.

( 22oz bottle, bottled 7/17/09) Pours opaque yellow with nice lasting frothy head, body is effervescent. Nose of spices, celery, light funk. Taste of dandelion, golden raisins, cinnamon, lemon, with a very carbonated refreshing citrus finish. I could drink this beer all day.

Bottle thanks to thirdeye11. Cloudy yellow pour with medium sized particles. Flavor is lemon peel, pepper, clove. Flavor is lemon, clove, spice. Nice fizzy mouthfeel. Definitely an incredible session beer, could drink this one for hours! Thanks again, Chad!

Bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  Pours a clear, bright yellow body topped with a fizzy white head.  Nose is white wine, floral (not hops), fruity and some spiciness.  Taste is lemony, bubblegum and yeasty spice. Finishes peppery with a bit of funk.  Dry, clean finish.

Bottle courtesy of thirdeye11. Cloudy lemondrop appearance. Frothy white head. Smell has light Belgian yeast, some tart fruit and lightly bittered. Taste is a light tart tingle mixed with sweet light grain. Some tasty notes are present through the finish. This is soft and easy through and through.

Thanks to thirdeye11 for sharing this bottle.

Pours a hazy yellow with a large white head. The aroma is wheat with some Belgian yeast. The flavor is lemon, orange, wheat, light funk and some Belgian yeast. Some other fruit flavors are present including apples.Thin mouthfeel and high carbonation.

Bomber, purchased from Binny’s in Downers Grove. Pours a translucent, brilliant orange/yellow, with a decent white head. Nose is that of citrus (someone sitting five feet away from me asked if I was eating oranges!). Mouthfeel is decently thin, with heavy carbonation. Wheat flavors, along with the expected citrus flavors, and the not-as-expected peppery tones. Leaves the mouth happy. One of my favorite GI brews, and at $8 a bomber, a great value!

Hazy yellow pour with a thick white foamy head and tons of lacing.  Aroma is a blend of citrus and wild yeast.  Apparent flavors are banana, lemon, pepper, and spice.  This beer has a well carbonated medium body with a nice dry and bitter finish.  All in all, a damn fine beer.

Kind of surprised by the high ratings for this saison.  I wasn’t particularly impressed.  Poured from bomber a very bright clear yellow with a 3 finger fluffy off-white head.  The flavor seemed to be lacking any unified body and was mostly a watered down saison.  Some yeast, wheat and citrus but not much from either note.

bottle, pours light yellow with a medium white head.  Aroma is white wine and citrus fruit.  Solid wheat and slightly sour/bitter lemon peel flavors.  Lightly funky finish with a very dry peppery touch.  Solid.

Pours hazy golden with fluffy white head, aroma is full of fruity esters, orange, lemon, and spiciness.  Taste up front is fruity with banana, orange, lemon, that works into yeasty spiciness.  Excellent brew!

22 oz. bottle.  Bottled:  10/23/09.  Pours a slightly hazy glowing gold color with a big and fluffy white head.  A musty, semi-funky aroma of lemons, Mandarin oranges and their peels, baseball card bubblegum, pepper, and a yeasty spiciness.  Full-bodied and a touch creamy here and there.  The flavor starts with bubble gum and bananas.  Lemons and oranges at the end.  There is a Chai tea with vanilla quality along with pepper and a yeasty spiciness throughout.  Great, great stuff.

Cloudy straw color with a giant fluffy white head that settles slowly to leave thick lacing.  Aroma of grapefruit and bubblegum.  Flavor has citrus up front, then banana and bubblegum.  Slightly sour finish.  Reminiscent of a German wheat beer.

22 oz bottle. Some light crackers, citrus fruit cocktail, grapes, and minor spicy funk in the aroma. Nothing too crazy there, but pleasant. The pour was very nice though, with good full, bright white, bubbly foam head that dissipates steadily, a cloudy body, and a mellow golden tangerine color. This was a very easy drinking beer. The medium body started off a bit flat, but livened up through the fruity finish. Orange citrus fruits stand out as far as the flavor profile goes, but other aspects seem to blur together into a slightly sweet, bready, spiced funk clump that almost had some medicinal qualities. I think I really wanted to like this one more than I actually did. Still, it is a pretty decent drink.

Bottle from a trade with FlssmrBrewAlum. Pours hazy hay color with white head. Aromas of citrus, spices, floral hops, bubble gum and wild yeasts. Lots of citrus and wild yeast flavors with some spices.  Light to medium body with effervescent carbonation and a dry finish. I’m really liking this one. Thanks Adam.

Bottle shared by JoeTheYounger.  Pours a golden cloudy yellow with a 2 finger white head.  Aroma is fruity bubblegum, pears, and berries.  Flavor is citrus and other fruits, spice, and quite dry.  Light to medium bodied with lots of carbonation.

2009 22oz bottle. Pours a hazy golden color with a rich white foamy head. Nose is flowery and lightly fruity. Very effervescent body. Palate is very tingly and very much alive. Flavors of light grassy and floral hop notes with a toasted biscuit malt that is very pleasant.

Bomber courtesy of tytoanderso – thanks Tyler!  Pours clear light yellow with a one finger snow white head.  The nose is grass, lemon, peppery yeast and spice.  The taste is faint funk, spice, bready yeast and citrus zest.  Medium prickly mouthfeel.  Tasty stuff – very refreshing.

22 oz – Hazed gold, creamy white head.  Lemony oak and white grape aromas warm to soft swirls of yeasty pineapple and funk.  Soft peppery orange-lime and herbal wood tones round with a touch of drying grassy funk and yeast from beginning to end.  Borders dry white wine territory at times.  Medium bodied with prickly carbonation.  Complex and elegant…

Gold color with a thin head.  Aroma of wheat, hay and lemons.  A little yeast and a bit of bubblegum.  A moderately tart lemon taste, plenty of hay, grass and other barny qualities.  Light yeast.  Very carbonated.
Pours wispy light golden with a mostly receding thin off-white head. Notes of chamomile, herbs, citrus, and sweet yeast. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. This is a very nice beer, more please!

Pours bright gold into a snifter.  Bright white micro head with medium retention recedes to skim surface leaving spot lacing. Lemon and brett aromas. Sweet and sour coriander upfront turning to a dry lasting brett finish.
Aroma has lots of clove and spicy citrus. Flavor has too much hot alcohol, but some redeeming spice characteristics. Very slight brett b like dryness.

Pour is a cloudy yellow with a big white head.  Aroma is lots of lemon peel with some clove and mild funk.  Flavor is a little toned down with some citrus and spice but not much else.  A little corriander is left on the tounge but it finishes kinda watery.

22oz bomber. Pours a cloudy neon yellow with a bright white poofy head that has good retention and lacing. Very little lacing. Aroma is canned pineapple juice, white pepper. Taste is grainy, dry, watery, plain, dull. Wow this really sucks. Slightly oily mouthfeel (but on a saison? yuck). People hate on saison thinking it is not complicated or rich enough, but let me tell you, plenty of breweries get their ass kicked trying to recreate a Belgian farmhouse.

Elegant saison, a little funky yeast aroma, along with white pepper.  Pours light colour with lots of foamy head.  Refreshing taste and mouthfeel, very good with supper.  Elegant and not compelx, with a bit of the orange peel.  Nothing really funky about the taste.

Number 1600.  Cloudy ultra straw yellow with a pearly white moderately dissipating minor lace maker of a head.  Aroma of Belgian yeast, fruit, toasted malt and orange peel.  Taste of Belgian yeast, orange peel, bready malt, grassy hops and something salty like chicken soup.  A bit too sudsy for my liking.

I don’t how true to style this is, but t hit the spot for me. Clear yellow with a big beige head and vigorous carbonation. Crisp spicy and herbal aroma. Flavor is very dry and herbal, with a lot of dry winy and spicy notes.  Crisp finish. I could have drank an awful lot of this. Thanks Secret Santa!
Banana, pear, and white wine.  Light yellow.  A bit of hop bitterness.  Fizzy, not particularly distinguished.  Goose Island has a great thing going with the elegance of the bottle label.
Nice, straightforward belgian style. A good bit of pear and a bit of funk in the flavor. A dry finish, just a touch of hop at the end. Nicely balanced ale.
Bottle (small sample). Very light yellow pour. Aroma of spice and citrus - smells and tastes like a Belgian. Somewhat carbonated. Nice brew.

I thought I had rated this, but I guess I didn’t. Here’s from my notes, circa Nov ’09. Pours hazy straw blonde, soft medium sized white head. Aroma: yeast, orange peel. It tastes like a standard Belgian blonde to me. Soft carbonation. Or a toned down tripel. Golden Monkey’s little sister? Not very exciting.

Hazed golden color/ lingering white head. Nice peppery, salty, citrusy pale malt aromas with mild barnyard piss. frothy light mouthfeel. Very good citrusy, clove flavors with dusty pale malts, peppercorn, mild barnyard funk. Great beer.

Half of the pint pour was white foam and it seemed like forever before it faded.  Sticky and stringy lacing.  Appearance is slightly opaque honey.  Nose is pleasant with fruit and funk which is as it should be.  Flavor is complex fruit, spice, and that funk again.  It is surprisingly dry.  Aftertaste is oranges and bubblegum with a very faint bitterness.  This saison is too much like a hefe to be a great beer.  Still, it is a pleasant and enjoyable offering.
10.29.09 Bottle. Pours golden with nice light white head full of big bubbles.  Aroma is slight, sweet, fruity, candy, bubblegum.  Tastes sweet, fruity, tart, nice bite.  Very carbonated.

Bottle.  Very bright golden yellow, with a tall stack of tight white bubbles for a head.  The aroma is quite esthery, with a hint of tropical fruit.  Quite the light, pleasant drinker -- frothy and fruity, with pineapple, banana and very light malt.  I do believe I’ve discovered the perfect breakfast beer!  Outstanding.

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden yellow with a bubbly white head. Aroma of light fruits, light toast, yeast, grains, slight sourness. Flavors are bright with lemon/zest/citrus, dry bread, light spice. Mouthfeel is light and lively sweet and a touch tart with a sort of creaminess that leads to a dry somewhat tart finish. Pretty tasty overall, this would have been awesome in the Summer or Spring, too bad it’s 25 degrees out and snowing presently.

Straw colored brew with a massive ivory tower that produces a significant amount of lacing.  Aroma is yeasty, biscuit, lemongrass, pepper, and citrus.  Flavor shows tons of orange peel, lemon rind, slight funk, and spice.  Highly carbonated...pretty good brew.

2009 bottle from Oct. 23 thanks to Secret Santa. Pours with a hazy golden body with a large, white head. Aroma of coriander, orange peel, white pepper, anise, jasmine and candied tangerine. Taste is a bit tart, with a harsh grain notes. Some citrus, pepper, florals. No brett at all as far as I can tell. Dry and bread like. Very effervescent and supremely dry.

Pours a light yellow color with a decent yeast haze and thick frothy white head.  Aroma is of bright fruit, orange and lemon are very upfront with light up spice funk.   Taste is almost radler like.  Very citrusy with lemon and orange as well as a subtle spice and odd funk.  Very crisp and refreshing.  Solid.

Pours a light straw-yellow color with a medium frothy-white head which leaves some webbed lacing.  Aroma is your typical Belgian ale - light green grape, Belgian spices, and a little Belgian funk.  Taste is rather light - light Belgian spice, bright citrus, a little bit of sparkling green grape.  Rather enjoyable for a style that is quickly losing my interest.  Not as spicy with more focus on the citrus notes.

22oz bottle. Pours a bold, slightly hazy, medium straw color; significant bright white head with excellent retention and resilient lacing; an absolutely gorgeous pour; lightly effervescent; shimmering head. Lovely, crisp aroma: mineral and herbal bitterness, very charismatic yeast character (dough, light funk, nicely dry), with touches of white pepper; this is exactly what I want in the aroma of a saison: crisp, lively mineral notes, charismatic yeast, a light funk, nothing sticky, and mouthwatering acidity; hints of citrus throughout; this is a very attractive nose. Medium mouthfeel: following the aroma, lots of dough, white pepper, with hints of minerals and light citrus throughout; the core is nicely toasty, reasonably dry (though not quite as dry as the nose suggests); some heavier banana and bubblegum esters at the core of things; definitely shows some close similarities to Orval: the pleasant hoppiness, the light funk, the clarity of expression; a really lovely beer altogether. Lasting finish of toastiness, light minerals, nicely dry overall.

Pale straw gold colored body with a long lasting off white head. The nose was sweet pears with notes of funk and wood. There was also a lot of bubblegum and orange juice. The taste is straw with orange peels and a little hint of vinous character. There is a slightly soapy finish along with ginger and a little black pepper that tends to linger. The mouthfeel is soft with lots of carbonation that is not irritating. A nice experiment that is like the best of a wit combined with a saison and a little hint of wine. Well done.

Bomber. Light golden body, slightly hazy. Huge white head, mostly lasting. Citrusy aroma of orange and lemon along with pale malt with a hint of clove and pepper. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter and lightly acidic. It finishes lightly to modertely sweet, lightly bitter and moderately acidic. Medium body, watery texture and spritzy carbonation. Great dry, tart finish after initial tastes of orange, lemon and spice with a hint of mold. Mouthfeel reminds me of champagne. A little too citrusy. It masks any subtleties the beer may offer, but otherwise this is an enjoyable, easy-drinking saison.
Pours light yellow with a big bubbly white head. Tastes very dry, orange, vanilla, some tartiness. Very good saison.

Very fruity and spicy saison. I don’t get the "wild yeasts" so much as a fairly nice and strong saison. Lots of carbonation. Good taste. Bought for our hotel room in KC from the Sunfresh grocery store. I wanted to stock up on Boulevard BBQs, but I feared that they couldn’t handle six days in the airport parking lot in December.

Thanks to Hatchy for picking this up for me in Chicago. Pours a hazy golden with a medium bubbly white head that laced.  Aroma of citrus, grapefruit, floral, banana, clove, acidulated malt, bubblegum, honey and orange.  Flavor of banana, clove, citrus, I’m guessing the Chimay yeast strain, honey, orange and white wine.

22oz bottle shared thanks to TomDecapolis. 2009 Bottled July 17. Poured a medium and hazy yellow color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of yeast, fruity, citrus, and some spices. Tastes of the same...fruity and spicy. Lively body with a Dry and clean finish.

Aroma beautiful tropical fruit aroma, the kind you get from the salads using wonderful fresh fruit in good restuerants, orange,mango,papaya, banana, and some kindergarten glue, flavor is much the same, alittle initial sweetness ,a little bitterness,and then oddly  it dries out in finish,aroma more enjoybale then flavor,but  still an excellent Saison

22 ounce bottle, bottled on 10/23/2009.  Served in a tulip glass, the beer pours a hazy light gold color with about an inch white head.  Head retention and lacing are both pretty good.  Aroma is lemon, orange peel, peppery spice, and wheat.  Taste is pretty much the same as the aroma, but with the addition of some green grapes.  Mouthfeel/body is light/medium, it has high (but soft) carbonation, and also has a dry finish.  Drinkability is good, it’s a nice and refreshing brew.  I liked this beer, I’d buy it again.

2009 22 oz Bottle -- Pours cloudy yellow with a big white head.  Smells of orange, lemon, apple, and wheat.  Mellow sweetness with a good tartness.  Alcohol is very present on the finish.  Peppery and dry finish.

Pours staw yellow with avoid sized white head. Aroma of Belgian yeast and citrus. Taste is tart up front with lemon peel and orange in the middle.  Moves to pepper and sometype of danker taste I can’t put my finger on. Finishes dry

Bomber Bottle from Champanes, 2009 bottle marked ‘Bottled Oct 23’ &#40fresh bottle&#41,
sampled in a Kuhnhenn Tulip and Gouden Carolus Chalice glasses, 

has a almost clear &#40but there are fine particles in this brew which give a faint haze&#41 pale yellow pour with light orange hues, gave a white head, medium or so effervescence, bottle had some light colored sediment on the bottom, Chalice produced more effervescence than the tulip glass, 

lots of lemon citrus, lemon skin and some orange citrus on the nose, a little white sugar sweetness in the background and faint floral aroma to,

flavors of lemon and orange with pale malt, light fruit and honey sweetness, has a tart and a little pepper at the finish which ends dry,

mouth feel is around medium, seems to be a little under carbonated, could use more carbonation, chalice gave a better mouth feel but the nice mouth feel appeared to fall off as the ale warmed to room temperature, 
this is a nice Saison but sort of typical in many ways.

This seems entirely more like a "Belgian ale" than a Saison. Pours a lightly hazy blonde with a slightly loose great big head that leaves plenty of lace. The aroma is lots of pineapple, some bubblegum, some farmyard, and some fresh hops. The flavor is dry and hoppy and spicy and features notes of citrus, some tartness, some pineapple, lemon rind, non descript fruit, some pineyness, and some bubblegum. The beer is very well balanced between fruity flavors, funky flavors, and a remarkable dryness. The palate is sharp and the carbonation level is perfect on the tongue.

Bottle from rciesla. Nose is slight barnyard funk, slightly sweet with some pink peppercorn and orange peel (the pithy part). Taste is barnyard and straw with a nice dryness. Finishes slightly fruity at first, with a light dry bitterness initially that fades as it warms. As it warms, the fruit in the finish becomes a little cloying and it takes on a pronounced Orangina soda flavor/feel, which isn’t great. All in all, this was nice and close to great early in the glass. I would allow a little longer for the wild yeasts to do their thing and take the edge off that orange soda sweetness. Would drink on the cold side. Thanks, Ryan, have been wanting to try this one for a while.

Bottle:  The aroma consists of yeast, orange peel, pepper, and a hint of lemon.  It pours a hazy, bordering on cloudy, gold with a half inch white head with sporadic lacing left behind.  The flavor starts with light orange, orange peel, and faint floral notes.  The finish is lightly peppery along with some light lemony sourness.  It’s light bodied with lively carbonation that is fairly soft.

The Dan Journal #312.  Tasted 10/24/09.  22oz bomber.  Hazy with a golden yellow hue.  Ring of white head.  Aromas of bananas and citrus.  Multiple types of grains.  Full bodied with a huge effervescence and a blast of big citrus.  Totally tangy with a bitter palate.  Just a ton of fruity notes.  Peppery and spicy.  Very well crafted and very tasty.  Great complexity and layering.  This is solid!
Thanks Cloudskipper.  Poured hazy golden yellow, delicate, CO2, citrus, funk, little citrus rind, little spice.
Pours a bright light golden with a two finger frothy white head. Nose is light and citrus with a touch of barnyard influence. Very delicate mouthfeel with citrus and funk in the flavor.

Sample at the Goose Island tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits on 11/19/09. Pours a hazy lemonade yellow with a medium white head. Peppery yeast aroma with lemon, orange and sweet malt. Sweet and dank malt flavor with peppery yeast and a bitter finish.

Appearance:  pale orange color with a slight golden hint; medium-to-long lasting rocky white head; hazy with effervescence

Aroma: low-to-medium floral, spicy hop aroma;  strong fruit aroma but not predominantly citrus; does appear to be a clove presence as well; pretty nice cohesion

Flavor:  beautiful and textbook; fruit and spice;  similar profile to the nose shows genuineness; low alcohol presence followed by a nice tart sourness; fairly strong spice component; low hop bitterness; sufficient malt background

Mouthfeel: medium body; low alcohol warming; carbonation but not too strong

Overall:  only major drawback is the fact that the hop presence could be stronger;  otherwise, a great saison prototype!

22oz. Bottle:  Complex aroma of yeast, coriander, spices, basil, white pepper, and a hint of lemon.  Poured yellow in color with a medium-sized, loose, white head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Full of tiny, small, and medium-sized particles throughout.  Flavor is lightly sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of yeast, spices, light lemon, light coriander, slight white pepper, slight hops, and a hint of wood.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Yeast, spice, white pepper, and lemon finish is dry.

This was a really pleasant and light saison-style beer, but given the price tag and the description, I thought it was a bit under-whelming.  There was nothing unpleasant about it, but it lacked the full mouthfeel, intense sourness, and funkyness that I expected from this beer.  It was drinkable and light and pleasing, but not the genre-buster I thought it might be.

Color was a light lemonade color with a meringue-colored head.  Aroma was lightly sour and wheaty.  Flavor was a touch sour, light, and effervescent.  Mouthfeel was very light and delicate, and pleasing, although not what I expected.  Pretty good.

A big thank you to SurlySober for bringing this beer over to my house to share.

2009 bomber.  Light, clear, yellow pour with a big, fluffy, white head.  The aroma is lightly sweet with just a hint of clover honey, there’s some very subtle sour funk, lemon, and some bubblegum Belgian esters.  The flavor is very bright and light with some great notes of citrus, and nice gentle sweetness balanced by a little tartness and a peppery finish.  I get just a hint of buttery oak on the finish.  The body is light, dry and very effervescent.  Excellent saison!
Bottle.  Fruity taste at the front of your mouth and proceeds to get dry as it washes to the back of your mouth.  Definitely getting a champagnish hint on the palate.  The color is a terrific cloudy.

Wow. Nicely done. Soft, subtle all around, but with the smallest hint of brett to call it a saison, a wee bit of orange, and you can call it creamy, even though it’s got great small-bubble carbonation. Well put together.
Pours a bright golden, cloudy color with a slight head.  Citrus and vanilla aroma.  Flavor seems to be almost a lemon flavor which is muted by the vanilla to make it very drinkable.

Bomber from ditmier - thanks, Eric! Very pale gold pour with a crisp and very active carbonation, sweet malts and a hint of pinot grigio in the nose. Soft palate and a very nicely lingering feel to the beer, quite swirlable. Lightly bitter flavor initially, with some saison funk and pepper, tapering off to a modestly dry table white (albeit with champers carb). An interesting effort at the style, and I wish I had another bottle to age.

Bottle from Party Town.

Poured a hazy amber color with an average fizzy white head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate spice, citrus, and yeast aroma. Medium body with a dry texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy balanced flavor with a medium to heavy sweet & sour finish of moderate duration.

I enjoyed this beer.

Bottle… October ’09 O-Town Throwdown… Hazy straw-colored ale with a small, fizzy, white head. The bouquet is spicy, buttery and musky.  Medium-bodied with fizzy carbonation. Sweet, but not cloyingly so. The flavor is bitter and herbal with gentle acidity. Tangy, tongue-numbing finish. Bottle provided by SoLan!

Poured from bomber into Tulip.

Cloudy pale yellow with huge frothy pure white head that leaves lots of lacing. Looks fantastic for a few minutes, then it all dies down, and it turns kind of dull. But those first few minutes were something.

Aroma of coriander, orange peel and pepper. Overall, exceedingly dry smelling, bordering on tart.

Peppery, spicy, dry and slightly tart. The orange peel is very evident and there also quite a bit of coriander, even though I did not think that was added. Pretty Witbier-like, except not so wheaty.

Dry, dry and dry. Spritzy, light mouthfeel. Never knew that I could ever think a beer is almost too dry.

Very refreshing, but I expected more complexity. Nevertheless, a very good Saison that straddles the Saison/Witbier divide.

22 oz. bomber from Princeton’s Liquor.  Citrus aroma.  Lots of frothy white head.  Appearance is cloudy blonde in color.  Very bubbly and effervescent.   Finish is a bit tart and sweet at the same time.  Enjoying it more as it warms up.

22 oz bomber from Princeton’s.  Cloudy light orange pour with big foamy white head. Yeasty citrus aroma.  The spice and orange come out nicely in the flavor, the finish is smooth and dry.  Looking forward to aging a bottle or two to see how it changes.

Bottle from Binny’s South Loop.  Hazy gold pour with a fluffy  white head and drippy drippy lace.  Aroma of lemon and fresh cracked pepper.  Slightly funky flavor .  Cheese, toast, orange zest, and floral notes.

Bottle. Pour was light golden with a frothy head. Aroma was of lemon, orange, yeast, and a brett-like tartness. Flavors were barnyard hay, aged cheese, lemon, and orange. I got a little pepper, but that flavor in particular seemed a bit weak. Good brew. Nice blend of flavors making a nice complex brew. I’d probably buy this one again.

[Bottle] Pours a clear yellow with a white head of clear bubbles. Aroma is quite dry, minerally, some white grapes, yeast, some blue cheese, and a touch of pepper. A subdued and soft but complex nose. The flavor doesn’t quite follow through, though. The mouthfeel is a little too thin and watery. The cheese is prominent, some bitterness, the wine character is there, but there’s not much in the way of tannin. Orange peel coming through on the front, with a strong yeast presence on the back of the palate. This beer has most of the ingredients it needs to be a great saison, but it’s just missing something for me that I can’t quite put my finger on.

Bomber rating.  Pours slightly hazy golden with active legs.  Egg white head which diminishes quickly.  Flavor is floral, crackers, pepper, orange peel, and stinky cheese.  Just a very small tart note as well.  For me this ranks slightly under some of the best saisons, but holds its own with most in its style.

Bomber via trade thanks to dug on BA.  Awesome extra.  Pours an amazing brilliant hazy golden color with a large lasting white head and great lacing.  Straight-up nails the appearance.  Aroma is Belgian yeast, funk, floral hops, and citrus.  Flavor is slightly sweet pale malt, wheat, Belgian yeast, spices, orange peel, white pepper, and floral hops.  Somewhat complex and very tasty.  Very yeasty.  Finish is slightly dry and palate is clean and refreshing with soft carbonation.  Excellent beer overall.

Bottled July 17, 2009.  Pours a hazy, light yellow-green body with white foam head.  Spicy aroma of belgian malts along with hints of honey and citrus.  There is also a weird funkiness in the aroma.  Flavor is not nearly as complex as the aroma; it’s mainly belgian malts and spices with a slight pepper tone.  The palate and mouthfeel is really where this beer is interesting - it’s medium-bodied with a very smooth, soft mouthfeel.  The finish is delightfully dry and clean.

22oz bomber, bottled June 1, 2009, with another thanks to FlssmrBrewAlum!  Pours a clear pale golden with a large fluffy bright white head that slowly recedes while leaving some nice lacing.  Aroma is belgian yeast, light spice and floral, and some grass and citrus hops.  Flavor is more belgian yeast, some more spice and floral and a little grassy hops.  Gentle and enjoyable stuff, thanks again Adam!

Bottle at Monk’s Café, Wallingatan
Hazy blond color. Medium aroma strength, earthy and spicy. Dry mouthfeel, not so strong; dry herbal toffee flavor, light camomile, grassy. Strong ending bitterness. A peculiar Saison, but not impressive.

bomber - thanks after4ever!!  clear, straw gold with thin white head fading quickly; soft, lemony, mild yeast spice aromas; bone dry with a bready, light texture; touch of fizz on the lips; not overly fruity or sweet, but a very nice "plain jane" kind of saison

Bottle at Iowa City Brewfest. Poured a hazy pale yellow color with a white head. Smelled of baking spices, citrus, and fruity pastry. Light to medium bodied with subdued farmhouse funk, but no significant acidity. I tasted mixed spices, yeasty bread dough, and citrus fruit. Decent.

Small glass as part of Goose Island beer and cheese tasting at Teller’s in Cincinnati.  Pours cloudy yellow with a small white head.  Pleasant citrus aroma with coriander and malt.  Dry citrus flavor with malt, and yeast.  Juicy, fruity, dry, sweet, crisp, and just a tad tart.  Light to medium bodied.  Dry finish.  Very nice saison.

Thanks to Phil from Goose Island for sharing a 22 oz bottle. Pours a nicely hazy soft orange color with a billowing white head. Aroma is a nice spritz of citrus, orange and lemon zest with that dry white wine sort of sharpness.This all balances with a wheat and spice character. Flavor starts with a strong wheat and spice note that dominates. Opens up beautifully to a brett and sharp fruit flavor that really grabs the tongue. Very nice dry finish and a good lightly fizzy carbonation. Well done
