This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a medium sized head of foamy fine to medium sized white colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a hazy uncarbonated yellow-white colored body. The mild aroma was malty banana and coriander. The crisp semi-thick mouth feel was tingly at the start with a mellow finish. The flavor contained notes of malt and mild coriander. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

Killer beer. The head was a little frothy, not so tight. The taste was just a tad sweeter/spicier than I had hoped but still overall a dry saison, well executed. Some really nice grassy and hay flavors, aroma was killer. Nice sparkliness in the mouth. Wonderful ABV. I want more.

Cloudy, lemon-gold pour with a fast-dissipating white head, only temporary, spotty lace. Really nice yeasty must aroma with a strong carbonic element, light citrus, promises a dry taste. Flavor starts off similarly, yeasty, citric dry, estery hints of peach and hawaiian punch, but also a flatter generically malty side to it that peeks through an otherwise really nice golden ale. Medium body, lightly astringent in a good way, dry, warm, very lively.

Incredibly delicious. Best saison I’ve had, maybe best Belgian wheat I’ve had &#40how much wheat is in here? - or does it just have wheatish spices?&#41 Orangey tangy sweetness with a bit of funk, banana, clove, sparkly vanilla.. Light and refreshing too! So good.

Goose island sophie lightly tart lemon nose soft spicy notes touch of wheat a little yeast. Hazy golden nice foamy head. Nice lemon notes light spice. Touch of dust. Light grainy notes lightly sweet. Clean lemon dry finish. Pretty dry. Lingering light sweet yeast notes but solid interesting. 7 4 7 4 15

Bottle. Hazy yellow-orange to straw body, medium off-white head. Wheaty nose with banana, clove, pepper, and some tart lemony notes. Body of wheat, banana, and clove, estery and spicy. Medium body. Decent.
Shared with Rudolf, his bottle. Pale yellow pour. Aromas of pear, peach, nectarrine. Taste is dry, champagne like, fruity,peach, white peach. Very good
Cloudy, light straw color. Modest head. Typical Belgium spicy taste upfront, but orange tang in aftertaste. "Wine" style label is an attention grabber!
Lightly hazy light pilsener gold, white head.  Nose is lemon candy, light mustiness, tart orange.  Flavor is lemon candy &#40not too sweet&#41, a bit of earthy funk, nice hop bitterness.

looks like cloudy pee with a thick white head. something i see way too much of, only not with a head.  i really need to drink some water someday. syrupy nose that is floral with a touch of yeast. really thick and chewy, tastes sweet nectar of some light fruit.whew, not one to let warm up. gets a bit sulphury. i’m not fond of the spices. all in all it ain’t bad, a bit too wit-ish for me.
3 6 6 2 12
Bottle at toncatcher? tasting.  Nice easy to drink saison.  Light yellow mild yeasty saison aroma.  Nice.

Bottled at Monk’s Café Wallingatan, Stockholm. Pours out in a hazy golden colour with a small white head. Yeast, mild white pepper, mild lemon, pears and funk in the aroma. Medium-bodied with notes of brett, wood, mild lemon, yeast, spices and banana. Crisp spicy finish with woody undertones

Bottled at Monk’s Café Wallingatan, Stockholm.  Hazy golden, brief head. Funky pear aroma. Mid-sweet, medium bodied with well rounded mouthfeel. An elegant beer with notes of wood, vanilla and light alcohol.  Finishes with fairlyu low bitterness. A subtle, non-assualting beer with good balance.

2009 Bottle - Thanks beernbourbon! - Pours is neon yellow with a lasting white head...aroma is tart and inviting, light spice and doughy yeast...flavour is interesting, I almost get a Lemon Lime Gatorade thing going on, along with the peach, clove and light citrus...finish is also tart, which I dig, with ample carbonation throughout...very tasty!

A lightly tart and refreshing Belgian ale.  Wild yeast, dough, and spice are present.. seasoned with traditional Belgian spice, orange peel and coriander.  Light but interesting..   brightly carbonated and not too sugary, making this sessionable.  Goose does not let down.
Ehh, aroma is sugary malt.  Flavor is same, with some fruit in it.  Not that good.

2009 bomber.  Poured paler golden with lots of rising carbonation and a well-retained cap of white head.. some lacing followed it down.  The aroma was very spicy with orange peel, coriander, and white pepper over some light fruity sweetness.. more tartness as it warmed up.  The flavor had sourdough bready notes at the core supporting lemon and orange &#40kind of like orange juice&#41, dry Belgian-inspired yeast, coriander, and white pepper.. the tartness drove through the finish, picking up some white grapes and banana.  Medium-bodied, very dry, and very carbonated on the palate.. tartness and spicage were just too agressive.. I was prepared to love this after reading the description, but it just wasn’t quite there.
Pours a cloudy golden color with a thick creamy head. You can taste orange  coriander, lemon,vanilla  and with a hint of cinnamon. Goes down very smoothly.

Pours a pretty light hazed yellow with a thin sheet of lacey small but visible bubbles.  Nose was thick, yeasty and vividly reminscent of dried banana chips, spicy, and with notes of orange peel and vanilla.  yeasty flavors with a citrusy background sourness, but the yeast is so thick and banana-like, it’is like drinking a banana cream pie and even though I like banana-cream pie, i like my banana flavors to be coming from bananas and not yeast.  bananaish and spicy belgian yeasts make me vomit...not really, but i dont like them in most cases, and this is no exception..its just too damn chunky, banana spice, meh’

Bottle from Binny’s South Loop. Pours a hazy golden amber with a pillowy white head and nice webby lacing. Nice bold aroma of tropical fruits and orange blossoms. Lighter side of medium bodied with that fine, slightly spritzy Belgian mouthfeel. Flavor of pale malts sits behind  flavors of clove and white pepper. Dry , yeasty, and semi-tart finish with subtle accents of orange. Attenuation is just right. A nice Saison, especially if you like a little kick.
Bottle. Aroma of candy sugar, yeast, lots and lots of orange and orange peel. Flavor sweet with so much of that orange peel as well as spicy/clove notes. So much orange for me, didn’t jive.

Bottle: Pours a hazy yellow with a white film of head. Mild grains in the aroma with evident warm fermentation esters- a touch of sour dough- no oak or vinous qualities. Fizzy feel with a mild flavor. Some bready character, warm fermentation esters, a spicy banana note and bread crust dryness. One dimensional and has gained nothing from the wine barrel aging. Perhaps I have to revisit this because it sounds so interesting, and I was let down with this bottle.

22oz bottle. Pours a hazy, golden yellow body with a finger-width, pure white head that dissipates quickly leaving behind a good amount of lacing. Aroma is a nice perfume of wheats, tart lemons, white wine, banana cream, and more bret as this warms up. The flavor is slightly more bright and spritzy. Slightly breadier and more of a noticable peppery yeast as well. Still slightly tart lemons with more noticable orange, banana cream again, and a light bret. White wine as well before it finishes dry with a crisp, but  bready tartness before lots of lingering citrus, creamy banana, bret, and wheat. Palate is light to medium bodied. Overall, a really tasty beer. Lots of flavors going on that blend very well together. Nice body and finish with a pleasant aftertaste. This is very well done.

Bottle purchased from GI Clybourn brewpub. Today it’s about 90 degrees outside, so this light refreshing beer is really hitting the spot. Pours a very pale yellow with vigorous carbonation. Flavor is white wine, mild citrus, champagne, and a hint of spice. Soft and dry on the palate. Finish is dry and light. Well done.

Pours a very lemon yellow with very light white head. Aroma is very earthy, hay and wheat. Definite notes of lemon coming across. Flavor has a lot of wheat tones with lemon citrus notes. Very crisp flavors. Body is light with high carbonation.

(bottle - 22 oz) Hazy gold pour with a fizzy white head. Aroma is earthy and tart with a good amount of spice and cloves. Flavor is earthy and funky. The yeast and spice are very present with a strong grainy and earthy middle. Finishes with a slightly sweet and spicy note and a lingering bitterness that sneaks up on you.

Pours a burnt golden color with a medium sized bubbly head. Nose is spice, corn, honey, citrus, and vanilla. Taste is similar but grainy and sort of husky. Sweet and medium length finish. Not really to style...low carbonation and sweet rather than dry finish. Hmm.

Bottle @ Goose.  Aroma of belgian yeast, and some citrus.  Interesting brew, it had some lively carbonation.  Light and refreshing.  I was hoping it would have some more sour characteristics from the wild yeasts, but it was still well done.

Very light golden pour with fluffy white head, releasing the wild yeast fruitiness I expected.  Very nice sparkle in the mouthfeel, along with the citrusy tartness, light yeasty/tart/sour funk,  vinous qualities, and dry peppery finish.  Kept thinking, from beginning to end, how nicely this one would pair with so many different kinds of foods (especially seafood, I think).  Not particularly complex or overly fussy, just a really pleasant and refreshing brew.
Bottle rerate.   Pours a clear yellow with a big puffy white head.  notes of lemongrass, orange, some funk, spices.  Grassy fog.  Musty.  smooth.  Effervecent.  Refreshing.
Aroma is surprisingly hoppy like fresh hops with nice hints of belgian yeasts. The flavor is spicy, refreshing, with a hint of tart and an exhale of orange peel.

22oz bottle, Jun 2009 bottling, courtesy of a couple of very generous Chicago BAs.  Poured into a tulip.

The is a lighter than I was expecting, a super clear golden straw with tons of bubbles streaming to the top, feeding a huge creamy white head that doesn’t back down for a long time.  The lacing is nice and thick.

Smell is excellent and starts out very subtle with lots of sweet light fruits, especially pears and apples.  But as it warms, the peppery spice and lemon zest come out a bit more and even a faint funk that’s just starting to enter the fray.

The taste starts out with a much more earthy tone than the aroma, definitely featuring the yeast a bit more.  The middle starts to taste more like the sweet fruits of the aroma, with some slightly tart green apples.  The finish is dry and earthy and much less sweet than I though when I smelled the beer.

The mouthfeel is light to medium bodied and very active on the palate with a strong carbonation.  It’s dry with a spicy zing on the palate in the finish.

This is a great saison from GI and extremely drinkable with plenty of sweetness in the aroma and some earthy characteristics that come through more in the taste.  A great summer afternoon beer.

Hazy gold with big, foamy white head / Perfumed, elegant nose of honey and banana / Light to medium body, a touch watery, creamy with low carbonation, with good balance and fair finish / Flavors of clover honey, flowers, banana, orange peel, and white pepper / Nice, but needs a little work.  Not picking up the wine barrel aging.

22oz bomber (Bottled June 01, 2009) served in a tulip.  Hazy light golden/orange pour with a two-finger thick head of slowly fading off-white foam.  Lots of bubbly lace.  The aroma included orange peel, honey, white pepper, berries, and a hint of white wine.  Very estery.  The flavor had sharp orange peel, wheat, dried fruit, and graham cracker.  Finished with a light sweetness, but mostly dry.  Light-bodied with crisp, moderate carbonation.  Refreshing.  An interesting variation on the style.  The wine barrel presence is very subtle.  Nice.
Bottle from Pantanap.  Thanks.  I really think this is a nice saison.  Zesty carbonation, slight residual sweetness, nice spice character.  Extremely refreshing.

Bottled in Jan. 09. 22oz. bottle served in the new style Blvd. Smokestack Chalice Poured a pale gold with a finger of fine bubbled, white head. Lots of carbonation. Coriander and orange peel in the aroma. Fairly light bodied. Spicy finish from the yeast. More citrus and orange peel. Very dry. After drinking the Juliet, this was a bit of a let down. Nothing wrong with it, but it just didn’t do a whole lot for me.

22 oz bomber.  Straw yellow body with a big white head.  Light, fruity aroma.  Flavor is wheaty, a bit fruity, slightly sweet, but overall very subtle.  It reminded me of a Belgian Tripel crossed with an American macro lager.  I tasted the Belgian style flavor, but I think this beer would be quite palatable to Joe Table down at the corner bar pounding the Buds....

22 oz bottle shared by JB.  Pour is slight haze yellow golden with a smallish white head.  Aroma of apricot, slightly earthy, soft honey sweetness, some grainy maltiness.  Fresh and engaging.  Taste is grain wheat, sweet apricot fruit and mild honey.  Less integrated and complex in taste then I was expecting from the nose.  Palate is medium, mid to low carbonation, the finish is long - grainy and semi-sweet.  Nice, quite drinkable.  I will certainly buy more of this when it is available locally.  Thanks for opening this John.

Bomber from BBB63.  Pours a rich cloudy sunflower yellow with a bright white head.  Nose is quite nice, very fragrant, a bit of a citrus spice, but more flowery.  Taste is peppered with spice mostly pepper and a lot of wonderful citrus mostly a lemony feel but perhaps a bit of orange too.  High carbonation, and a great refreshing Saison for a hot night like tonight.

Bottle shared by hophead22 from pantanap... Pours a very light golden color with a white head.. Aroma is a little peppery with some lemon and orange notes.. Taste was alot of oranges with a slight pepperyness to it..Thin and light body with lots of carbonation.. I like.

batch #2.  aroma of yeast and light citrus sharpness. some fruity esters as well. appearance is of prosecco. flavor is lightly tart, perfectly toes the line between a saison and a sour (in terms of tartness). very dry. subtley hazy straw colored and well carb’d.

22 oz bottle.  Hazy straw with a puffy white head.  Nose is yeast and fresh lemon juice with hints of tarragon, marjoram, funk and candi.  Crisp and bubbly with an airy mouthfeel.  Taste is soft lemon pith, pear and honeydew.  Banana emerges in the finish.  Lovely.

Bottle.  Aroma is pungent lemon, and rich funk, full and spicy.  Pours pale golden with a big billowing white foamy head that leaves streaky lacing down the glass.  Rich, lemony with a strong bitter finish, some clove and sour notes.  Nice lively carbonation.  Rich medium body.

A light yellow pour with creamy white head and lace. A sour note, with a tad of pepper/lemon citrus. A bit of a perfumy, flavor with a hint of paper and pepper. Medium bodied with good carbonation with a nice dry finish.

Sofie 09 @Pilsner Petes East Coast Gathering-22oz bottle–pours a white head and hazy straw color.  Aroma is lemon, bret, creamy, barny.  Taste is lemon, bret, creamy, barny.  Easy, nice. Thanks goldtwins for sharing.
Bottle from Hophead22 beer tasting. Very cloudy yellow color. Aroma of orange peel and pepper. A little bitter finish. Lots of carbonation.
22oz bottle fron pantanap, thanks Kan. Gold/yellow pour with a white head. Peppery aroma, lemon. Spicy, peppery flavor, slightly bitter, more from the citrus than anything else. Not bad.

Bomber bottle and served in my NB Worthy glassware, crystal clean golden hue with a fizzy head and minimal lace. The aroma has notes of oak, apples, oranges, white grapes, heavy biscuity malts and wheat husks, some clove and pepper, an a bit of barnyard funk and medicinal vapours. The taste is surprisingly mildly acidic and fruity with a moderate wheaty background. Touch of basic spiceness upon the finish. Rather clean and refreshing finish with a effervescent mouth feel. I like this for the most part (love the orange peel addition) but as I drank it I kept thinking "it seems to be missing that something". Also it starts tasting too chalky as it warms.

January 2009 bomber, consumed in June 2009.  Pours a lightly hazy, bright, yellowish-golden hue.  Streams of champagne-like bubbles effervesce towards the surface, pooling into a small, splotchy blanket at the head.  A sudsy wash quickly slides down the glass, leaving no lace behind.  The aroma is beautiful and complex, notes of lemongrass, spicy orange peel, coriander, and white pepper lending plenty of bright, summertime spicing to an underlying base of lightly sweet, candied pale malts.  Mildly bretty and distinctly Belgian, the dry, bready yeast profile works perfectly.  A surprising dose of delicate, aged floral hops lends a mild, dry bitterness that balances things out perfectly.  Flavors follow suit, running the gamut from creamy citrus chiffon to bold, spicy pepper and lemongrass.  Moderate oak lends a soft kiss of vanilla, while the brett offers up mild farmhouse funk and tartness.  The palate is medium bodied and appropriately prickly and dry, near perfect for the style.  Aged, grassy hops linger on the finish.  Delicious brew, and absolutely perfect for the summer.  Another contributor to the recent American saison renaissance.

Pale golden pour.  The nose is of lightly sweet pale malts.  Lovely lavender floral aroma along with a bit of lemony tartness.  Fresh and tart smelling with a bit of herbal notes as well.  Well-balanced with the lean body being well-complemented by the spicy yeast and the other floral notes.  Fairly unique and very delicious.

Bottle at PilsnerPeter’s Ratebeer Spring Gathering. Very pale straw-coloured pour.  Aroma is very bright and fruity with a lot of flinty character to the malts.   Funky and tart with a very juicy/fruity yeastiness.  Loads of yeasty complexity with a kiss of spice and funk on the back of the palate.  Bone-dry finish.  Awesome stuff.
8 4 8 4 17

Bottle at PPRBSG09.  Pours a cloudy very light yellow.  Aroma of funky barnyard and sweettart candies.  Flavor is very similar--with more of a sour bend along with the sweet tartness.  Very smooth, light on the palate, and mellow.  Good stuff!
8/4/8/4/15 (3.9/5)



Update: Bottle thanks to FlssmrBrewAlum.  Pours a cloudy light orange with a very small head.  Aroma of mint gumdrops, grapes, lemon, orange peel, and a light sourness.  Flavor is rather citrusy with lots of that orange peel (which I didn’t get in my previous tasting).  Very tasty, just different.  I didn’t really get any sour notes this time.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy pale gold.  Pleasant aroma of lemon, a bit of funk, and a touch of spice.  The flavor is a bit more sour than the aroma with lemon, spice (I see now that it is pepper, but I wasn’t sure at the time), and some funk.  Dry finish.

(PPSG09, 22oz bottle) Medium off-white head atop cloudy straw body.  Aroma is medium sweet, lemon sour, yeast, cream.  Taste is medium sweet, lemon, some yeast, light banana, cream.  Light-medium body, some effervescence.

Bomber. Thanks, pantanap! Pours murky medium gold with bright highlights. Nice dense creamy white head. Big brright lemony nose. Bubble gum and watermelon and a bit of white pepper as well. Fizzy medium body, with more sweet fruit and mild pepper on the mid-palate. Mild tart finish.
Very different. Saison or sour. Nice spice essence overall. Golden color. Aroma has pepper, a hint of pleasant funk. Taste is smooth and sweet, almost tart but mostly dry. Nice.

Bottle at PilsnerPeter’s Spring Gathering.  I think Larry brought this one, and I brought the Juliet, and the picture of them side by side (empty of course) is one of my favorites I took that day.  Pours a hazy yellow with a little bit of a white head.  Light brett notes, and a touch of musty old attic. Light funk and a bit tart.  Finishes crisp and wheaty.  Delicious.
PPRBSG09.  Bottle, pours a pale golden body with a white head.  Dry Brett, leather, dry earth, hints of citrus and pepper to finish. Nice.

Shared by goldtwins at Peter’s NY gathering - hazy gold, fizzy body - soft herbal aroma, with notes of lemon, tangy character, wheat, white grapes - the aroma reminds me a bit of a berliner weisse - refreshing herbal flavor, with a light tartness and moderate notes of white wine - mildly acidic, with notes of peach and lemons on the back end - quite nice.

Sweet orange nose, very light almost creamy yellow, hazy, sour, floral orange taste. Tastes like white wine with that sweet/sour bite. Savory food aftertaste, light body and light carbonation. very nice.

Bottle shared by Miketd.  Thanks!!  Pours golden color with white head.  Aroma is lemon zest, some white pepper, and yeast.  Medium mouthfeel with a lot of carbonation.  Flavor follows the nose and finishes slightly tart.  Easy drinkin brew.

Pours a golden golden color with a very thick white head and a ton of carbonation.  Aroma really hits the nose from afar, lemon citrus seems to abound, a very yeasty note is there as well and clove all of which seem to contribute to a slightly sour aroma profile. Flavor is a more pronounced citrus mix of orange and a little stronger lemon, light wheat and yeasty presence in there as well, some very light spicy notes at the end and a modest alcohol ending.  Beer has a moderate density, very effervescent feeling in your mouth and is very smooth. Overall a very good offering from GI, the lemon citrus is very refreshing and really makes the beer great.

Sampled from 22-oz bomber during Dark Lord Day ’09, at table 1. Pours a semi-clear golden pale brew with a fast dissolving white head that dissipates clean. Aroma of light orange zest/coriander, critus zest, white pepper, a touch of yeast and light multi-grain malt. Taste is medium bodied, very light carbonation, with flavors of yeast, light orange zest and clove, a touch of earthy herbs and golden grain malt, Finish is semi-sweet, with a spicy/herb and yeast aftertaste.

Nose made up of pepper, coriander, and lots of spicy yeast aroma. 
Pours a bright straw yellow with a thick white head
Nice carbonation
Tastes faintly of lemon, corriander, not much pepper, nice and dry.

Pours a hazy pale yellow color with a fluffy off white head that left decent lacing.  Light Brett on the nose as well as lemon peel, clove and a slight funk.  Very crisp mouth feel, and a nice dry finish.....A great Saison.

4/25/2009:  Goose Island Sofie is a very pale straw color and looks more like white wine in the glass than beer.  It has a clean aroma and flavor that is sweet with lots of perfume/floral notes and just a slight amount fruit/citrus.  This Saison feels delicate on the palate and effervescent enough to make the gentle spiciness of the beer tingle.



Sample from bottle at Dark Lord Day 2009.  Rating #18 for this beer.

. . . . . . . . . .


3/02/2011:  Goose Island Sofie...  Aroma:  Dried citrus
(lemon) peel; spicy along with some sour fruits.  Appearance:  Cloudy,
pale yellow color with a fluffy, long-lasting white head; rapid
carbonation.  Flavor:  Light, fruity maltiness; bready and yeasty
middle followed by some sweet and spiciness; white wine with some
tanginess in the finish.  Palate:  Medium-bodied; good carbonation;
soft mouthfeel.  Overall:  Very nice; not as sharp or clean as the
bottled version.



Pint (draught) at Marty’s Hops & Vines in Cincinnati, Ohio.  Score: 3.7

bottle at DLD 2009 ... pale yellow ... bright lemon hop nose ... light fruit ... easy drinkin ... some tart fruits.

keg at six degrees north Edinburgh... Light yellow.. thin white lacing.. soft floral grassy fruits nose... Light floral fruit 3.6

Bomber (2009) in a tulip glass, shared w/ Mike. Part of it was fermented w/ orange peel and the orange rind is very evident in both the nose and the flavor; pours a golden, Riesling color w/ some bubbles- looks like a wine! Smells winey w/ hay, oranges and some spiciness. Flavor is orange, citrussy and spritzy. Ends very, very dry and woody. Interesting brew, very Champagne- like.

Tried this one at a tasting at the Lakeview Binny’s in Chicago.  This was pretty heavy for a Saison.  I’m not saying there is anything wrong with that. Nice citrus flavors mixed with the sweetness of vanilla. Tasty.

Adam shares another great one at DLD.  Thanks again!!  Yellow pour.  white head.  Aroma is funky, spicy, earthy and tart.  Flavor is tart and funky as well.  Nice tingly carbonation.  And what a bargain...if you can find it.  Very neat beer.  Thanks adam!

Date: April 25, 2009

Mode: Bottle

Source: Tasting, DLD

Appearance: clear pale yellow

Aroma: sweet and spicy aroma

Flavor: light sweet malt flavor, lots of spicyness

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20

Rating: 2.9/5.0
Drinkability: 7/10

Score: *4

22 oz bottle I brought and put out for sampling at DLD ’09 (Munster, IN). Poured a yellowish straw hue, white small head laces a bit and clings, decent haze, with some luminescence to the body. Aromas are a touch tart, with light funk and some decent orange peel and spiciness. Body has some good lively carbonation, and is thinner, but still works for me. Nice tartness and dryness work, especially being brought up as a Champagne person. Decent body, light and flavorful, carbonation helps it balance on the palate. Aging will likely change this brew’s makeup. Glad I grabbed several more, as this is very good!

Thanks to Honkeybra for this one.  Crushed with Jakebra.  A very nice brew.  Nothing compared to some of saisons I crushed this weekend, but it’s pretty solid.  Spicy, tart, some citrus and kinda funky.  Dug it.

22oz bottle. 2009 vintage. pours hazy straw color with foamy whtie head. nose has notes of lemon tart, hay, grass, and foral. flavors are tart, hay, musty, lemon, mildly sweet citrus finish. the body is thin with fairly low carbonation for the style. finish is a tad watery as well. aging should bring the brett out and add more carbonation.

Bomber from the Binny’s in Orland Park, IL:  This pours a lightly hazed blonde body with a short-lived frothy head.  It has an almost perfumey aroma with the blending of lemons and citrus rind, soapy yeast, pale malt, and white pepper.  It has a medium-to-medium-light body with a spritzy, peppery mouthfeel.  The flavor sees the addition of a lightly funky tartness.  The finish is dry, a tad tart, and peppery.  Very nice beer.

22oz bottle. Pours golden with a frothy white head. Nice head retention for almost the entire beer. Aroma is of yeast, citrus, pickles, hops, and honey. I couldn’t for the life of me tell you why I picked up the scent of pickles, but I did. Taste is of yeast, with funk, more goddamn pickles, mild hops, citrus, and honey. Has a nice malt backbone on it. Nice dry wine characteristics and some woodiness come through. Mouthfeel is very light due to the carbonation. Finish is very peppery. The barrel aging doesn’t come through very much, since it tastes like it was aged in Klausen pickle jars. Aside from the pickel taste, it was a very good brew.

Hint of haze in the straw colored liquid. Big billowy white head. Not rocky, but some smooth moguls as a settles. Nice tatting on the side on the glass. Lips curl slightly upward with the first sniff. A sudden burst of scents, with pale malt, lemon curd, dough, horse blanket, white pepper, sweet basil, rosemary, and orange blossom honey rising in the nostrils. Pale malt in the start and well into the middle. Floral and herbal hops in the middle balance the light sweetness. Just hints of citrus and spice to make this one crisp and light. Linger has a return of pale, lightly buttery malt. I see the description says Champagne, but I ’m thinking Chardonnay. A nice airy feel, but yet there is some real meat/heft to be found in this one. Quite Hennepin-esque and approaching Temptation. So... good company in my book.  Hope to pick up a few more of these.

Bottle.  Clear, straw colored pour with a fine white head.  Bready and yeasty aroma, belgian sugars, spiciness and citrus are soft and well integrated.  Some woody and funky notes, and an herbal, almost minty, hint.  Flavor is much more subtle, and very delicate.  Really light hops and approachable yeast character.  The wine barrels are apparent only at the very beginning, along with some vanilla.  Really soft on the palate with very fine carbonation.  Well brewed.

This is a really nice blended Saison style from Goose.  It’s got a nice effervescence and aromas of citrus and orange.  It’s a bit dry on the finish, but I think it’s got some great potential to shape up really nicely!

Bottle from Binny’s on Grand. Pours a nice, soft and hazy yellowy-gold. Fizzy head that dissipates. Nose is lemon, a touch of funk, very earthy and grassy. Taste has a tinge of tartness from the Brett, though mostly a dry, earthy saison, which is what I can really appreciate. Some citrus and floral notes come through, but really pretty clean. I’m so glad GI is finally bottling some more of their interesting beers. Excellent.

Staw yellow pour with thick white head that disipates into a white film. Arpma of tangerines, orange peels, green apples, light oak, grass. Flavor is strong citrus, mostly tangerine and oranges, with hay, grass, and a light funkiness. A predominating green apple flavor. Finishes long and tart. Another stunning ale.

22oz bomber.  Pours a very light, slightly cloudy straw color with a medium white head.  Aroma is citrus, hay, grass.  Flavor is light apple, green grape, citrus and the earthiness of a saison.  Finish is crisp and delightful.  Solid beer.

[New 22oz bomber] First rating woot!  Pours a clear glowing golden with a medium white frothy head that fades into fizzy soda bubbles.  Strong aroma, sweet tart green apples, spicy like coriander, lots of orange peel, touch of vanilla, nice brett notes.  Quite tasty, a bit sweet, lots of orange peel, seems like some wheat, touch of bitterness, dry green apple, slightly tart, refreshing brett and orange peel finish with a long malty aftertaste.  Medium bodied, very crisp, larger sharp carbonation, lightly sticky.  [Small amount of yeast/sediment in bottom of bottle... barely noticeable]  8.4.8.4.16 . . . . .[rerate 4.29.10] 7.4.7.4.15
